**The Orthodox Classic of the Divine Chess: Preface**

The *Orthodox Classic of the Divine Chess* is a work of uncertain authorship, annotated by Yan Youming of the Jin dynasty and continued by He Chengtian of the Liu-Song dynasty. It comprises two scrolls. The base text is derived from the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Tai Xuan* section. Collated versions include Dunhuang manuscript P.4048, volume 719.

**Preface to the *Divine Chess Classic***

The origins of the *Divine Chess Classic* are unknown. Some say Emperor Wu of Han commanded Dongfang Shuo to employ it, and none of his ancient divinations failed—his art relied on this book. Others claim the Yellow Stone Elder bestowed it upon Zhang Liang. Still others recount the esoteric affairs of the Prince of Huainan, also attributing them to this text. Likely, later admirers embellished its reputation to exalt its art, but how could it truly be the work of all these figures?

Though I had long heard of it, I paid it little mind, deeming it not a classic or historical work. By the end of the Kaicheng era, as I prepared to journey to Min, I heard of the Jian River, where rocks barred the surging rapids, and boatmen scaled perilous crags. Even the bravest warriors would sweat and tremble—how much more so a coward like me? As a scholar, I could not resolve my fear.

Upon reaching Si, I encountered my cousin An and confessed my timidity. An said, "I’ve heard the Jian River is not so treacherous—those tales are exaggerated." He possessed a divination book that could dispel doubt, so I asked him to consult it. The oracle read:

*"Above and below, the heart is at peace,
No treachery arises within.
Stand firm, free from care,
Heed not idle rumors."*

I laughed, and indeed, the rumors proved false. An then entrusted the book to me, and I carried it to Min. My journey was untroubled, and I came to trust its wisdom. Whenever I sought answers to other doubts, they were as clear as if I had witnessed them myself.

Alas! What the world dismisses may yet be a supreme treasure, while what it esteems may not be truly fine. A single volume of this book resolved my uncertainties—how could it not be prized?

From this, I understood that a scholar’s rise or fall, wealth or poverty, is fated, and cannot be judged by a single path. Examining the book, it seemed the work of one who had attained the Dao. Twelve chess pieces are divided into three sets of four—upper, middle, and lower—cast to form a hexagram, then matched to the text to reveal its meaning.

The upper four represent Heaven, the middle four Humanity, and the lower four Earth—the trinity of the Three Powers. Each of the twelve pieces bears an inscription, akin to the judgments of the *Zhou Changes*. Cast together, they form a hexagram, hence the name *Divine Chess*.

Later, while serving as an official in Fuzhou, I had ample leisure. I gathered dozens of versions, collated and corrected them, removing errors and preserving truth, compiling them here. Future scholars may study it without doubt.

During my time in Min, the distance from my homeland stretched thousands of miles across land and water, leaving me uneasy. One day, I cast the pieces and obtained the hexagram *"The Broad Way of Heaven"*, its words most auspicious. I trusted its promise. Yet, days after leaving Min, an imperial decree summoned me as an imperial censor. The divination had foretold this—was it not divine?

Written in the ninth month of autumn, the ninth year of Huichang, by Li Yuan, Gentleman for Ceremonial Service of the Ministry of Justice.

---

The *Divine Chess Classic* is a legacy of the Yellow Stone Elder. Some say it is Dongfang Shuo’s method of divination. Others claim it was composed by Zhang Liang or the Prince of Huainan, Liu An, annotated by Yan Youming of the Jin and He Chengtian of the Song, with a preface by Li Yuan of the Tang. Transmitted through the ages as the Yellow Stone Elder’s work, the *Bibliographic Treatise of the Tang Dynasty*’s *Five Elements* section records only its title.

Its method employs twelve round pieces carved from jujube wood struck by lightning. The oracles number one hundred and twenty-four. Four pieces symbolize Heaven, inscribed with "upper"; four symbolize Humanity, inscribed with "middle"; and four symbolize Earth, inscribed with "lower." After prayer, they are cast, and the oracle is consulted to determine fortune or misfortune.

The *History of the Southern Qi* records Jiang Mi’s divination, yielding: *"A guest comes from the south, bestowing fine wealth—treasures, jewels, golden cups, and jade vessels."* Yang Wengong’s *Garden of Talks* records that in the first year of Xianping, while seeking an external appointment, he cast three upper, two middle, and one lower pieces, matching Jiang Mi’s oracle. At the time, the compilation of the *Veritable Records of Taizong* was unfinished, so his request was denied. Soon after, he was appointed as an envoy for a prince’s birthday and received gifts of silver vessels. Later, he cast again, obtaining four middle and three lower pieces, the *"Avoiding the World"* oracle, which read:

*"Petty men prevail,
Noble ones lose the Way.
Leave my home,
Enter the deep grass."*

He indeed fell ill and returned to Yangdi. Other divinations were equally accurate, but each casting pertained to a single matter—repeating it yielded no result. As the saying goes: *"To profane is to receive no answer; divination is not repeated."*

Zhu Xi, in his discussions with Lin Zhengqing on the *Changes*, remarked: "Recently, someone asked about the *Changes*. I replied, 'Have you seen the *Divine Chess* oracles? The *Changes* is much the same.'" Observing the prefaces and annotations from the Jin, Song, and Tang dynasties, as well as the words of two Song masters, one trusts it as an ancient text. Great sacrifices to the divine tortoise, divination methods—all are preserved. Even methods like milfoil stalks or tile divination are usable; how much more so an ancient text from the Qin and Han?

Alas! The ruler’s mandate extends across the vast heavens; the sun’s brilliance endures as if present. Above, as if present; beside, as if present—such is the power of the spirits. Knock, and they respond; move them, and they commune. Is not the spirit of the heart worthy of reverence?

Master Zhang Nanxuan, during a drought in Bagui, cast the pieces under the scorching sun and obtained the sixty-second oracle, *"Yin Prolongs"*:

*"Water deep in the courtyard,
Boats row beneath the hall."*

Soon after, heavy rain fell. This is recorded in his *Recorded Sayings*.

This book was once in my late father’s collection. Its oracles distinguish yin and yang, odd and even; only when yang prevails over yin is it auspicious.

Through one’s own sincerity and devotion, none fails to receive a response.

The *Divine Chess Classic* was originally transmitted by the Marquis of Liu to the Yellow Stone Master during the Han, enabling foreknowledge of events yet to come. Initially used for divining the times, deploying troops, and setting out on journeys, it proved infallible. By the reign of Emperor Wu, Dongfang Shuo was ordered to test its accuracy across myriad affairs, and it invariably struck true. Some say the Eight Masters employed this method, passing it to the King of Huainan; a retainer from Huainan later obtained it, guarding it in secrecy so that none might receive it.

By the Tai Kang era of the Jin, the Daoist adept Chang Fahe of Xiangcheng declared: An old man clad in yellow hempen robes appeared, bearing this book in a bamboo tube, and bestowed it upon Fahe. Fahe then transmitted it to the world.

Its method employs twelve pieces made from thunderstruck wood, or catalpa, jujube, or sandalwood, each one cun and two fen in diameter, three fen in thickness. Four pieces are inscribed with the *upper* character, four with the *middle* character, and four with the *lower* character.

When divining, one must first compose the spirit, purify with incense, don proper attire, and sit in stillness. After a moment of focused contemplation, hold the twelve casting pieces with reverence, exhale upon them, and offer a prayer. Then cast all twelve pieces at once, arranging the resulting *upper*, *middle*, and *lower* characters in sequence to form a hexagram. Discard any scattered pieces and consult the manual to interpret the outcome. For each matter divined, cast the pieces only once—repeated casting renders fortune and misfortune uncertain.

During the Song era, Wang Yin and his brothers, along with He Chengtian, deliberated upon this classic. Those who approached it with sincere devotion invariably found its judgments accurate. Yet many, failing to grasp its subtle principles, dismissed it as ineffective and treated it with disdain. He who discerns the incipient knows more than half the truth; he who remains unaware of the incipient misjudges even the slightest movement. To know both the incipient and the movement is to comprehend more than half the Way. Whether one withdraws or advances, accepts or rejects, these paths diverge—one cannot assume that a single auspicious phrase confirms predestined fate.

Thus, "In the northeast, friends are lost," yet in the end, there is cause for celebration. "The traveler gains an ox," but this portends disaster for the villagers. "Darkness in *Mingyi*," "Greatness in *Feng*’s upper trigram"—these cannot be discussed as equals. The hexagrams, divided into *upper*, *middle*, and *lower*, embody the *Yijing*’s principle of the Three Powers. Through permutations, they yield a total of one hundred twenty-four hexagrams, with odd and even numbers determining fortune and misfortune. Odd numbers are yang, and yang is auspicious; even numbers are yin, and yin is inauspicious. By this method, fortune and misfortune become clear.

The words accompanying each hexagram are its *yao* text. The diviner must focus solely on their truth or falsehood, for therein virtue and vice are determined. If the meaning of the words does not align with the situation, one should carefully consider their intent. For instance, phrases like "majestic and resplendent, attaining without seeking" bode well for matters such as pursuing fugitives or recovering lost items, but not for divining illness or marriage. Similarly, "A year of prosperity, a month of flourishing—how can one know the stability of Mount Tai?" suggests that when treading danger, seeking wealth is auspicious, yet for one wandering far from home longing for return, the outcome remains uncertain.

Again, "Ruler and minister exchange positions, great fortune arises"—this is auspicious for the noble person but dire for the petty. Or "Thieves plunder my home, the worthy conceal themselves and advance"—this is auspicious for the petty but inauspicious for the noble. All such interpretations must be deduced by analogy. The distinction between noble and petty lies not in rank or power but in orientation: those who turn toward the Dao are noble, while those who turn away are petty. The wise employ this method without confusion.

"For whatever doubts reside in the heart, simply speak them aloud."

#9 "Whenever one wishes to divine, one must first compose the spirit, purify with incense, don proper attire, and sit in stillness. After a moment of focused contemplation, take up the twelve divination pieces and, with reverent heart, exhale and invoke them."

The Dunhuang version reads: "Each time one performs divination, one must first purify with incense and sit in quietude for a while. Then, holding the pieces, recite the incantation: *'Earthly servant so-and-so humbly invokes the gods of the Four First Months, the gods of the Four Mid-Seasons, the gods of the Four Seasons, the Twelve Celestial Offices—above, I beseech the Heavenly and Earthly Parents, the Supreme Primordial Elders, the Sun and Moon, the Five Planets, the Northern Dipper’s Seven Stars, the Four Seasons and Five Phases, the Six Jia and Yin-Yang, the Twenty-Eight Constellations, and the Year’s Bright Hall: so-and-so harbors doubts in the heart and requests a decision. If auspicious, declare it auspicious; if inauspicious, declare it inauspicious. Of gain or loss, right or wrong, let the forms appear upon the earth. For whatever doubts reside in the heart, simply speak them aloud.'"

#10 Immediately cast all twelve divination pieces at once, then arrange the resulting "upper," "middle," and "lower" characters in sequence to form a hexagram. Discard the stray pieces and consult the manual to interpret it. For each matter divined, cast the pieces once—casting again will render the auspices uncertain.

The Dunhuang version reads: *Cast the pieces to determine "upper," "middle," and "lower," then arrange them into a hexagram to fix the auspices. Once determined, do not divine again, for a second casting will leave the auspices uncertain.*

#11 The hexagram’s "upper," "middle," and "lower" positions correspond to the *Yijing*’s principle of the Three Powers. Through permutation, a total of one hundred twenty-four hexagrams are formed, all distinguished by odd and even lines to determine auspices.

The Dunhuang version reads: *The "upper," "middle," and "lower" positions embody the principle of the Three Powers. Through permutation, one hundred twenty-four hexagrams are formed, all distinguished by odd and even lines to determine auspices.*

#12 Odd lines are yang, and yang is auspicious. Even lines are yin, and yin is inauspicious. By this principle, the auspices may be discerned.

The Dunhuang version reads: *Odd lines are yang, even lines are yin. By this principle, the auspices may be discerned.*

#13 Then it is fitting.

The Dunhuang version reads: *Fitting.*

#14 For instance, when the signs are towering and resplendent, gains come unbidden. In such cases, divination for matters like pursuing fugitives or recovering lost property is auspicious, but for illness or marriage, it is not.

The Dunhuang version reads: *For example, when the signs are towering and imposing, gains come unbidden. In such cases, divination for pursuit, recovery, or seeking wealth is auspicious, but applying it to illness brings misfortune.*

#15 When treading perilous ground, divining for wealth is auspicious. For those traveling afar who long for a swift return, the signs will indicate they have not yet arrived.

The Dunhuang version reads: *When in distress, divining for wealth or dwelling places is auspicious. For those wandering in distant lands who hope for a quick return, the signs will indicate they have not yet arrived.*

#16 Likewise, when ruler and minister exchange positions and great fortune arises, the noble encountering this will find it auspicious, while the petty will meet great misfortune.

The Dunhuang version reads: *Likewise, when ruler and minister are in their proper places and great fortune arises, the noble encountering this will find it auspicious, while the petty will meet misfortune.*

#17 All must be deduced by category.

The Dunhuang version reads: *Deduce by category to grasp the hexagram’s meaning.*

#18 The terms "noble" and "petty" are judged by alignment with the Way, not by rank or power. Those who turn toward the Dao are noble; those who turn away are petty. The wise apply this principle and remain free from confusion.

The Dunhuang version reads: *The terms "noble" and "petty" are judged by virtue and conduct, not by rank. Those who uphold the Dao are noble; those who abandon it are petty. Those who value benevolence and righteousness while scorning bribes and profit are noble; those who slight trust and righteousness while prizing rank and emolument are petty.*

In ancient times, before the sages composed the *Yi*, the people used spirit divining blocks, which were modeled after the *Yi*. The Way of the *Yi* is profound and difficult to comprehend, thus they created the symbolic system of spirit blocks. Though it does not exhaust the subtleties of the *Yi*, without mastery of the *Yi*, how could one compose the oracles of the spirit blocks?

The system of spirit blocks takes three as its warp and four as its weft. The three positions—above, middle, and below—represent Heaven, Humanity, and Earth. They also signify the ruler, the minister, and the people. The four configurations—one as *shaoyang*, three as *taiyang*, two as *shaoyin*, and four as *laoyin*—pair *shaoyang* with *shaoyin* as harmonious, while *taiyang* with *taiyang* becomes adversarial. Harmony brings joy, while adversity sparks conflict—this is the constant Way. Yet sometimes, losing the Way, harmony may invert into enmity; or by aligning with its course, adversity may transform into utility—such are its permutations.

When yang prevails, paths align and mutual illumination follows. When yin dominates, intentions diverge and discord arises. This marks the division between the noble and the petty. The alternation of yin and yang, the differentiation of forms, and the shifting of names—such is the Way of the *Yi*. The *Yi* draws its symbols from chariots, buckets, arrows, hares, foxes, and the like; yet by extension, it encompasses all things under Heaven. It speaks of a horse yet signifies a dragon, or names water yet implies transformation—this is the meaning of the *Yi*. Without penetrating the mysteries of all under Heaven, one cannot grasp it. Thus, the spirit blocks were created in emulation of the *Yi*, and only those deeply versed in the *Yi* can master them.

I have always admired the accuracy of its divinations but lamented that interpreters fail to fully convey the author’s intent. Therefore, I have expanded upon its principles and elucidated its meaning.

**Method for Crafting the Blocks**
Use *pili* wood, catalpa, jujube, or white sandalwood, measuring one *cun* and two *fen* in diameter, three *fen* in thickness, and perfectly round, calibrated to the *zhou* ruler. Cut the wood on a *jiazi* day, inscribe it on a *bingzi* day, carve it on a *wuzi* day, apply cinnabar grains on a *gengzi* day, and store it in a case on a *renzi* day. The case should be made of *ziwei* wood.

**Preparation of Pokeweed (Shanglu)**
Take any quantity of pokeweed root, pare away the thin outer layer with a bronze knife, and slice it thinly. Soak it in east-flowing water for two nights, then steam it in a steamer, layering it with bean leaves. Steam from noon until midnight, remove the bean leaves, dry the root in the sun, and finely chop it for use as sacrificial jerky.

**Invocation and Incantation**
*"Heaven is clear, Earth is tranquil; the River Chart holds its numen. A single censer of sacred incense purifies the ten directions. Three rolls of the ritual drum summon all spirits to heed."*

**Prayer**
*"Heaven and Earth unite their virtue, sun and moon their brightness; the four seasons keep their order, ghosts and spirits align with fortune and misfortune. August Heaven is impartial, aiding only those with virtue. On this day, in this year, this month, this day, [name and native place], I reverently burn incense and invoke the gods of the Four First Months, the Four Middle Months, the Four Seasons, the Twelve Earthly Branches, the Celestial and Terrestrial Parents, the Supreme Primordial Sovereign, the Sun to the left and Moon to the right, the Five Stars and Northern Dipper, the Twenty-Eight Constellations, the Four Seasons and Five Phases, the Six Jia and Yin-Yang, the Hall of Light and Yearly Virtue, the Twelve Celestial Gods, the Twelve Terrestrial Spirits, the Year, Month, Day, and Hour Officers, and the Attendant Messengers of Merit: I, born at this hour, humbly present my purpose regarding [state matter]. My heart holds a wish, my mind harbors doubt; hesitant and uncertain, I seek your judgment. Favor or ill, fortune or misfortune—let the oracle decide. I reverently await your sagely illumination and manifest response."*

**Incantation**
*"Om hum hum ma-ni da-li hum cha chi."*
Recite three times in a single breath.

Then cast the twelve blocks at once, forming a hexagram according to the upper, middle, and lower positions. Consult the oracle’s words to determine fortune or misfortune.

**Closing Prayer for Sending Forth the Spirits**
*"Having invoked your presence and reverently consulted the spirit blocks, I have received your gracious response. Now I humbly send you forth. May you return adorned with clouds and mist, ascending to your palaces in the celestial vault. As you came, you bestowed grace; as you depart, leave blessings behind. Whenever summoned, return as before."*

**Sacrificial Rite**
On the seventh day of the first lunar month each year, fast and bathe according to the ritual. By the waterside, prepare a mat, wine, fruit, incense, jerky, and paper candles. Invoke the spirits as previously described, then clasp the left hand in a mudra, bow, and sigh:
*"Heaven is clear, Earth is numinous; dragons and tigers hold their power. The Six Jia and Six Ding spirits follow my command. Banish evil, uphold the right, emerging from darkness into light."*

I now receive your summons—descend swiftly without delay.
Form, shadow, sound, and qi shall instantly dissolve into dust.
Dare any resist or defy? Lightning and thunder shall strike them down.
Hasten, hasten, as the statutes command!

Offer three sticks of incense, pour the libation, and bow according to ritual—with utmost sincerity, none shall fail to be moved.

**Prohibitions**
On the six *wu* days, divination is forbidden; any attempt will yield no verification.

**Ascending Prosperity** Divination – *Great Passage* Hexagram  1-1-1
*From small to great, without stumbling or collapse.*
*From low to high, attaining wealth and eminence.*

*Fitting to journey forth, inauspicious to conceal one’s brilliance.*
Yan says: *Aspiring from small to great may lead to wealth and nobility. If the great aspires to the small, there will be peril and ruin.*
He also says: *Heaven and Earth having taken their places, the sage harmonizes with them. Ordering the primordial chaos, inaugurating the origin of creation—thus it is said: from low to high.*

*Establishing merit and creating systems, nothing is not auspicious. Secret schemes and covert plans are inadvisable; the elderly, the ill, and marriage unions are unfavorable, for pure yang is difficult to harmonize. Travelers have not returned; those imprisoned will be released; merchants profit.*

He says: *For official advancement, visibility is auspicious, concealment inauspicious. The ill should not remain in dark places; it is fortunate to avoid them by going elsewhere. Slander brings no harm; households prosper greatly. Military campaigns are auspicious; battles are victorious. Pregnancies yield sons; fields, silkworms, fishing, and hunting bring great bounty. All is auspicious.*

Explanation: *From small to great—yang begins to grow. Three hearts in accord—journeying forth is fitting. Inauspicious to conceal brilliance—its way is radiant. This divination’s three positions are all yang; lesser yang is just rising, thus the image of ascending from small to great, from low to high. Those who obtain it—whether initiating enterprises, seeking fame, or pursuing profit—all is auspicious. Litigants should seek justice through upright means; travelers are fortunate but have not yet returned. Secretive or deceptive schemes must not be undertaken. The ill will worsen; avoiding them brings fortune.*

**Gradual Peace** Divination – *Receiving Blessings* Hexagram  1-1-2
*Dwelling in tranquility, establishing one’s enterprise—possessions increase. Both wealthy and noble, though emolument and rank have not yet arrived.*

Yan says: *Calm the heart and steady the will to await the seasons—then all will be auspicious. If one seeks hasty fulfillment, it will not come to pass.*
He also says: *Yin and yang having taken their rightful places, the Dao of Heaven and Earth is thus attained by humanity. This is the image of settling into one’s vocation. Seeking office, pursuing wealth, managing fields and silkworms—all are auspicious. Marriage is initially difficult but later easy. Travelers will arrive; households are at peace. Legal matters do not come to fruition; imprisoned persons will be released through effort.*

He says: *Distant travelers arrive; pregnancies yield sons. Legal matters and imprisonment will be absolved by imperial pardon. The ill will not die; all affairs are auspicious.*

Explanation: *Dwelling in tranquility and managing property—firmness and softness are balanced. This is not desired outwardly, yet blessings are received in reality. In this divination, two yang are above and one yin below; the positions of the Three Powers are all fitting. Thus the image of being both wealthy and noble—it is fitting to preserve this and not indulge in insatiable desires, then all will be auspicious. Households and marriages are settled; legal matters encounter no obstruction. Travelers have not returned; seeking office leads to attainment and governance. Hearing of misfortune, one need not grieve; though illness has not yet abated, it brings no harm.*

**Abundant Fortune** Divination – *Auspicious Celebration* Hexagram  1-1-3
*Resplendent and illustrious, the household possesses gold and silk. Supplies are complete, affairs are settled—without seeking, one obtains.*

Yan says: *Having gold and silk, there is no need for seeking. Dwelling at home is auspicious; travelers have not returned.*
He also says: *Heaven generates the myriad things—its principle is ever-abundant. Without need for striving, all naturally comes to fruition. This hexagram is pure yang; marriages are not harmonious. The imprisoned are without guilt; fields and silkworms succeed. All other affairs are auspicious.*

He says: *Travelers are about to arrive; pregnancies yield sons. Merchants profit; legal matters and imprisonment are absolved by pardon. Pursuits and suppressions all succeed.*

**Explication:**
*Resplendent and illustrious*—this is pure yang. *The household possesses gold and silk*—the earthly Dao shines. *Supplies are complete, affairs are settled*—its power is abundant and strong. *Without seeking, one obtains*—its fruitfulness flourishes. This hexagram has three yang lines with the lower position thriving; the earthly Dao produces things, thus gold and silk overflow and affairs are settled. The fullness of yang is rooted below, while lesser yang rises above—like a tree with a flourishing root and abundant fruit, hence the image of obtaining without seeking. For one who casts this divination, all pursuits are auspicious. Managing property is most favorable; in war, great victory; in pursuit, the fugitive is captured. In litigation, one spends wealth but prevails; in illness, it is inauspicious; those in hiding cannot escape.

**Divination – *Abundant Prosperity***
Hexagram 4
*Abundant wealth, utmost nobility—the Dao of Heaven turns and shifts. Following the course, rising and falling, waxing with the times, waning with the seasons. Descendants by the tens of thousands, by the hundreds of millions.*

Yan says: *One who dwells in wealth and nobility yet does not forget poverty and lowliness will have a name that flows to posterity. If one cannot practice humility and retreat, ruin will surely come. Travelers are on the road; it will be long before they return.*
He also says: *From the second to the fourth line, the earthly Dao is twice fulfilled. The principle of wealth and nobility reaches its apex here. Yet when fullness is attained, it must wane; when high, it is perilous—hence "turns and shifts." If one follows the ebb and flow of yin and yang, not opposing the times, one can preserve body and reputation, and blessings will extend to descendants. This hexagram favors humility and retreat; prisoners will have difficulty leaving. Those awaiting others will face slight delays; travelers will not depart.*

He says: *The ill will recover slowly; it is fitting to sacrifice to the heavenly spirits and seek blessings. Marriages and weddings are auspicious; those accumulating wealth should not add further. Distant travel is inadvisable; hasty words may lead to official disputes—it is best to seek those who uphold the law.*

**Explication:**
*Abundant wealth, utmost nobility*—the household’s enterprise is complete. *Following the course, rising and falling*—to preserve fullness. *Descendants by the tens of thousands*—it is not fitting to contend. This divination has yang above and old yin below, with upper and lower in their proper places. It bears the image of position and substance, wealth and nobility at their peak, with nothing left to add. Thus, one should follow the course of the times, know contentment, and avoid recklessness—then one may preserve one’s own success, and descendants will guard it without loss. Marriages are auspicious; seeking office, pursuing wealth, and awaiting matters have all reached fruition—one must not overreach. Those awaiting travelers should cease, for it is auspicious; in official matters, seek harmony—if pressed further, there will be regret. Illness will recover; in war, one should not act rashly—if an encounter occurs, halting is auspicious. Trust in others is lacking; when matters reach their extreme, they must reverse. What was auspicious may turn inauspicious, and what was inauspicious may turn auspicious. The Dao of joy and harmony leads to the *Surprise and Delight* Hexagram.

**Divination – *Surprise and Delight***
Hexagram 1-2-
*Firm without, yielding within—harmony and unity are all-encompassing. Nurturing nature, preserving life, roaming with the spirits.*

Yan says: *What is sought is contrary; one should only preserve oneself. The ill have not recovered; it is fitting to make offerings and pray—there is no cause for worry. Official duties will not advance; matters will not succeed. Prisoners will have difficulty leaving.*
He also says: *Marriages are auspicious; pregnancies yield sons. The ill should seek the spirits; merchants profit; in war, great fortune.*

He says: *Yin occupies a yang position—hence "firm without." One should not force advancement; nurturing nature and preserving life is the image of self-sufficiency.*

**Explication:**
*Firm without, yielding within*—it is fitting to be in accord with others. *Planning carefully, acting cautiously*—to preserve one’s whole person. *Roaming with the spirits*—this is not inauspicious. This divination has one yin line amid two yang lines, hence the image of firmness without and yielding within. Yin occupies a yang position—it is not fitting to act. Thus, one should harmonize, be circumspect, and preserve—then it is auspicious. In illness, there are malevolent spirits; sacrifices are auspicious. Litigation will not succeed; marriages and commerce are auspicious. In war, do not fight; prisoners will have difficulty leaving. Rumors are often false and deceitful—secret plans are fitting. The *Fright* Hexagram leads to *Minor Peril.*

**Divination – *Fright***
Hexagram 1-2-2
*A rooster crows at noon, climbing the roof and stretching its neck. The hen is below the wall—startled by a fox. Cutting off its cry, it flees—its body is spared harm.*

Yan says: *In all matters, initial difficulty and distress will ultimately bring no other misfortune. In all undertakings, there is first ruin, then success. Travelers have not arrived; illness should be treated early.*
He also says: *The upper responds to the lower, but is blocked by the middle—unable to aid one another, hence the fright. Yet, dwelling in a high position, it ultimately controls and governs; cutting off its cry, it flees—disaster is averted.*

The male belongs to yang, the female to yin—the natural predator of chickens is none other than the fox. This hexagram portends that official matters will not succeed, and prisoners will only be released with powerful assistance.

He says: Travelers may encounter bandits; seeking office, marriage, or trade will all be unfavorable. Borrowing or seeking aid will be difficult, and desires will be thwarted. Fields and silkworms will yield no harvest. In all matters, there will first be worry, then good fortune.

Explanation: One male and one female—there is secret contention. The firm and strong reside above, and the yielding cannot overpower them. Moving in accord with the proper response ensures no collapse. This divination shows a young yang occupying the honored position, while the two yin below both desire to act. The upper and lower correspond but are blocked by the middle, hence the image of the rooster crowing atop the roof while the hen below is startled by a fox. Yet, as yang holds the superior position and governs, and the middle yin is not yet dominant, they ultimately unite without harm or ruin. Divined affairs will require effort—first peril, then peace. Travelers will return but face obstacles midway. Military campaigns will bring fear; illness should be treated urgently. Seeking office or marriage will be obstructed by others. One must rely on the powerful—all will first be difficult, then obtained.

**Abundance – *Year of Plenty***
Hexagram 1-2-3
*First month, noon hour—year in Great Beam. The east wind thaws the ice; plowing and mulberry thrive. By year’s end, the harvest will be abundant, and joy will be boundless.*

Yan says: For all endeavors, the years, months, and days of *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you* will be auspicious, though results may come slowly. Without these years, months, or days, fields and silkworms will not prosper, yet no misfortune will arise.
He also says: This is the image of yin departing and yang arriving—the year resides in the *you* month, Great Beam.
The *Diagnosis* says: When the Great Year is in *you*, even begging for water yields wine—such is its abundance.
This hexagram governs fields and silkworms as auspicious. Officials will not yet attain their posts, but those in office will have no worries; the ill will suffer no harm.

He says: Travel by water or land, marriage, and harmony—all are greatly auspicious, the hexagram of talent.
Explanation: Heaven and humanity are in harmony, yin following yang. The land is fertile and expansive—fitting for fields and mulberry. At the juncture of *wu* and *you*, fortune is unstoppable. This divination shows young yang above, with young yin in the middle following it—the positions of heaven and humanity are proper. Vigorous yang occupies the earthly position; above is harmony, below is abundance, hence fields and silkworms thrive. The "first month" refers to the initial line, and "Great Beam" is *you*. The lower three form *Li*, which is *wu*; the middle two form *Dui*, which is *you*. All divined affairs will proceed as desired, with results manifesting in the years, months, or days of *wu* and *you*, or in the *you* direction.

**Minor Excess – *Minor Success***
Hexagram 1-2-4
*Disaster arises from below—beware a single servant. Secret plots converge, hands and feet poised to act.*

Yan says: Though yang holds its position, it is plotted against by the many yin. Thus, a servant harbors secret schemes to cause harm. Be wary of those nearby. This hexagram portends worry in all matters, though no great misfortune will arise. Official affairs will nearly conclude, but prisoners will struggle to be freed—due to yang’s weakness.

He says: Travelers will encounter bandits; those at home will face troubles. Servants will cause harm; groups will stir gossip. Endeavors will not succeed; the ill will be cursed by subordinates.
Explanation: A solitary yang above is weak in power. Yin thrives within the household—there is concern over servants. This divination shows one yang above, with strong yin below and young yin in the middle. The weak and yielding cannot control what lies beneath, hence the image of disaster arising from below—beware the servant. All divined affairs will be unfavorable. This and the sixth hexagram both feature one yang above, yet their divinations differ. In the latter, the lower position is young yin, which harbors the intent to follow above but is blocked by the middle. Here, however, the yin is mature, acting wantonly below, and the middle cannot restrain it. It is like a weak husband and young wife managing a household, where fierce servants and defiant maids refuse their master’s commands—its inauspiciousness is self-evident.

**Attaining Aspirations – *Self-Sufficiency***
Hexagram 1-3-1
*Ambitions clearly attained, in harmony with the times. Wealth and resources are abundant, with no lack of servants.*

Yan says: Aspirations are fulfilled, resources are sufficient, and servants are at hand.
He also says: Pure yang governs—this is the image of attaining aspirations. With utmost impartiality in heart, wealth and resources are fully provided.
Master Han says: When King Wen campaigned against Chong, he reached the ruins of Yellow Crane. His sandal strap broke, and as he turned to fix it, all around him were worthy men—none could be dispatched, so he tied it himself. This is the way of the noble person, holding to the Dao of utmost impartiality.

He says: Officials will enjoy abundant emoluments; distant travelers will arrive. The ill will recover; prisoners will be freed. Pregnant women will bear sons; trade will be profitable. This is the image of great success in all endeavors.
Explanation: The dragon attains the proper center—greatly in accord with the times. Above and below harmonize and follow, sufficient for great deeds. This divination shows vigorous yang occupying its position, attaining aspirations and the times, with the young yang above and below united in purpose. What worry could there be over insufficient resources or lack of servants? For the diviner, nothing sought will not be obtained—this is the most auspicious of divinations.

**Fulfillment – *Coming Prosperity***
Hexagram 1-3-2
*Once desires were unmet—now they are fulfilled. All things attain their proper order; affairs proceed with clarity.*

Yan says: First, one attains aspirations, with loyalty and goodness as the foundation. Private matters are not fitting. Travelers will return; the ill will recover.
He also says: The positions of the Three Powers are correct; yin and yang are harmonious. This is the Dao of the noble person—here, it is prosperity. Promotion and longevity will increase; trade will be profitable. All affairs will be auspicious.

He says: Marriage and harmony will unite; undertakings will greatly succeed. Fields and silkworms will thrive; the distressed will attain their aspirations. Prisoners will be freed; endeavors will fulfill desires. Travelers will arrive soon. Affairs proceed with clarity—all things attain their proper order.
Explanation: *Once desires were unmet*—the yielding was within.

The yang flourishes and acts externally—this is the time of opening and prosperity. Upright and selfless, its Dao thus becomes great. In this divination, the positions of the Three Powers are correct, yin and yang harmonize, and the noble person’s single Dao prospers. One should not engage in private or hidden matters but rather in upright and magnanimous affairs. The diviner who obtains this will find great fortune.

**Talent Flourishes, Divination of Peace and Auspiciousness** *(1-3-3)*
Abundant are the scholars, their virtuous power shining brightly.
Meetings bring joy, lasting happiness without misfortune.

Yan says: One advances by talent and will receive aid from noble persons. By year’s end, success will come, and its strength will not be singular. The ill will recover, travelers return, and all affairs will be auspicious. If one seeks audience with kings or lords or pursues fame, it will be even better.

He says: Seeking office will fulfill aspirations; travelers will arrive. Trade, fields, and silkworms will be profitable; marriages will be auspicious. The ill will recover, legal matters will not succeed—this divination is highly favorable.

Explanation: *Abundant are the scholars*—they follow those above. *Meetings bring joy*—the journey will be honored. In this divination, one yang occupies the upper position, while the middle and lower positions are all three yang. This resembles a ruler possessing firm and enlightened virtue, with many worthy followers. For commoners, it signifies the assistance of noble persons and good friends. Divining for office, meeting superiors, marriage, trade, or military affairs—all will be auspicious. In warfare, one will gain worthy allies; in endeavors, one will receive assistance—all is fortunate.

**Leisure Divination, Divination of Joyful Travel** *(1-3-4)*
Riding dragons and driving steeds, roaming the four directions.
Joyful and content, boundless delight in travel.

Yan says: Follow your heart’s desires—east, west, south, or north—nearly all matters will succeed. Travelers have not yet returned; the ill will recover on their own. *The Book of Changes* says: *At the right time, ride the six dragons to govern the heavens.* It also says: *The mare belongs to the earthly kind, traveling the earth without bounds.*

He says: Lost thieves and stolen goods will be recovered; a male child will be born. Trade will be profitable; marriage will naturally align. Fields and silkworms will flourish; those in bonds will have no worries—all affairs will be resolved.

Explanation: *Riding dragons and driving steeds*—the lower submits and supports. *Roaming the four directions*—none dare oppose me. In this divination, one yang resides above, while the middle and lower positions are balanced. The three yang are dragons, the four yin are steeds—each finds its proper place and serves me. Thus, one may roam the four directions, delighting without end. The diviner who obtains this should boldly advance. Only in inquiring about travelers will they not return, though they will fare well abroad.

**Worry Divination, Divination of Isolation** *(1-4-1)*
Above alone, below solitary—schemed against by the treacherous.
The illness of the heart’s chamber cannot be swiftly cured.
Only when the season of yang spring arrives will one regain freedom.

Yan says: One will constantly harbor fear, dreading harm, but with the rescue of a noble person, all will ultimately be without fault. For the ill, recovery will come in the second or third month. It is also said: Two yang are separated by layers of yin, beyond aid. This resembles treacherous ministers usurping power, first harming petty men. It is an omen of worry and harm—few affairs will be auspicious, and travelers will encounter obstacles.

He says: Managing property will not be auspicious; one will be plotted against by thieves. The ill will recover slowly; prisoners will not be released—this divination is slightly inauspicious.

Explanation: *Above alone, below solitary*—yin flourishes within. Petty men create barriers, and aspirations cannot be communicated. Upholding integrity and awaiting the right time will preserve the center. In this divination, the upper and lower positions are both one yang, while four yin reside in the middle, forming a clique of petty men. This is the omen of the true Dao being obstructed. All divined matters will face barriers and misfortune. One should uphold integrity to guard against disaster. This resembles the fifth divination, but here, the worry arises because the four yin form a clique, their power vast and difficult to remove. Thus, one must wait for the yang season, when the solitary yang’s assistance arrives, to resolve the crisis.

**Vigilance Divination, Divination of Thieves** *(1-4-2)*
Heaven and earth are vast and relaxed; petty men act freely.
Prohibitions are unenforced; thieves invade my home.

Yan says: One will lose property, and the head of the household will fall ill, recovering only by autumn. This divination greatly favors upholding integrity; it is not suitable for pursuing affairs. Travelers have no set return date; those chasing fugitives will not succeed.

He says: Medicine will not benefit the ill; legal matters will not be resolved lightly. Seeking wealth will yield little profit; one must guard against thieves at home—this divination is highly inauspicious.

Explanation: *Heaven and earth are vast and relaxed*—laws and orders are implemented. *Thieves invade my home*—one cannot oversee them. The sigh of the noble person is the joy of the petty man. In this divination, a multitude of yin surrounds one yang. Yin flourishes in the middle position, and though the lower originally responds to the upper, it is blocked by the middle and instead allies with it. Thus, the noble person’s chamber is occupied by thieves. The diviner should guard against thieves. Matters of home, property, trade, office, warfare, or travel—all will be inauspicious. Only in fleeing or hiding will one find fortune.

**Destroying Thieves, Divination of Enforcing Orders** *(1-4-3)*
The lord’s command oversees affairs, punishing and eliminating treachery and villainy.
Wielding spears and brandishing halberds, great undertakings will follow.

Yan says: One should be employed by others or employ others; acting independently will lead to failure. The ill are afflicted by spirits—exorcism is advisable. Travelers are safe; pursuing them will be auspicious. Divining for suppressing rebels or capturing fugitives will ensure victory. Treachery within, villainy without—this divination favors small victories over great ones. Trade will be profitable; seeking office will succeed. Fields, silkworms, and marriages will all be auspicious.

He says: The king’s punitive expeditions will prove effective. Legal matters will resolve themselves; no affairs will be inauspicious.

Explanation: *Yin obstructs the middle*—seeking to rectify it. *The lord’s command punishes*—military strength is abundant. *Wielding spears and brandishing halberds*—to strike at illness. In this divination, yin obstructs the middle, but the lord’s command to punish it is backed by formidable force. Thus, one wields weapons to eliminate harm. The diviner who obtains this will find great success in advancing.

In this divination, a single yang occupies its proper position above, while three yang forces flourish below, with four yin forces residing in the middle. Though yin seeks to obstruct, the three yang powers unite in virtue. Thus, yin’s treachery is exposed, giving rise to the image of the lord’s command and officers mobilizing to eliminate villainy and calamity. For military campaigns or capturing fugitives, great victory is assured. The sick will recover upon treatment; in legal disputes, the righteous will prevail. Travelers will remain unharmed; obstacles will be overcome. All undertakings will be auspicious.

**Defeated in Battle: The General’s Loss Hexagram**
*One-Four-Four*
Jackals and tigers roar,
Endless rains flood the land.
Battles yield no victory,
Weak troops and valiant warriors alike.
Overwhelmed by raiders,
Many perish or flee.

Yan says: To weaken one and strengthen another—both defy principle. All affairs grow difficult; travelers should return. Mid-journey, terror strikes; punitive expeditions are ill-advised.

He also says: Yin’s influence grows ever stronger, while the lord’s Way daily wanes. Jackals and tigers, external raiders, connect on all sides—enemies cannot be overcome.

He says: Regional lords guard the borders, yet officials fall prey to bandits. Even atop high ridges, they suffer deluges. The sick grow gravely ill; prisoners remain firmly bound; lawsuits stall. Cycles repeat endlessly. Trade, fields, silkworms, and seeking office—all prove unfavorable.

Explanation: Jackals roar and waters overflow—yang’s path stands alone. Great villains conspire together, their peril beyond rescue. In this divination, a single yang perches atop accumulated yin, hence the images of roaring jackals and ceaseless rain. All affairs turn inauspicious; deploying troops is most ill-omened. Only in times of great drought will prayers for rain succeed.

**Three Images, Upper Sixteen Hexagrams.**
**Divine Aid: The Spirit’s Protection Hexagram**
*Two-One-One*

The Great Unity deploys troops, the Jade Maiden stands beside. The shaman becomes an immortal master, dispelling misfortune.

Yan says: The household’s elder will fall ill, for a female ghost brings harm—best to perform exorcism. Most affairs remain obscure; even the traveler cannot return for this reason.

It is also said: The celestial deity, the Venerable Great Unity, has the Jade Maiden as his aide, while Wu Xian was a worthy minister of Yin. These are but auspicious titles. This hexagram brings fortune through prayers and exorcisms. If the sick are afflicted by spirits, hasten to dispel them. Seeking office, pursuing matters, trade, and marriage—all prove favorable.

He says: The traveler arrives soon; no harm comes from slander. Legal troubles end without worry, and one gains human aid. Best to seek blessings and avert calamity—what is undertaken will succeed.

Explanation: The Great Unity deploys troops to dispel misfortune. Yang, though solitary amid yin, does not long abide with evil. Here, though yin resides above, two yang lines find fellowship, forming a united resolve to expel wickedness. The upper yin, in turn, serves our purpose—hence the omen of the Great Unity leading troops. The Jade Maiden at his side mirrors the radiant aid of Wu Xian. Though affairs may seem doubtful, one ultimately gains friends’ assistance to succeed. The sick recover through exorcism; the traveler returns; battles end in great victory.

**Decaying Hexagram of the Seduced General**
*Two-One-Two*
Two women, one man—above and below drive each other. Yin’s qi seizes yang, leading to depletion and emptiness.

Yan says: Man and woman clash; marriage begins but later dissolves. Though the traveler returns, bandits await on the road.

It is also said: The outer is no Jade Maiden, the inner betrays the Great Unity. One yang, subdued by two yin, forms a hexagram of depletion. The sick grow worse.

He says: What is sought brings no benefit; what is done fails to harmonize. The traveler does not arrive; silkworms and fields yield no hope. Legal troubles prove hard to resolve; the sick worsen. All affairs turn greatly inauspicious.

Explanation: Two women, one man—yang is trapped by yin. It resists essence yet surrenders to seduction, leading to depletion and ruin. Here, one yang is ensnared between two yin. Both yin and yang are weak; the lesser seeks union, but yang cannot rise, overpowered by yin, hastening depletion. All matters divined under this sign prove ill-fated.

**Rectifying Hexagram of Disciplined Order**
*Two-Zero-Three*
Heaven darkens, clouds ascend; yang stirs from below. The noble governs chaos; the petty fear punishment.

Yan says: Yin usurps yang’s place, rising like clouds. Mighty yang lies below, poised to ascend to the ninth five. It quells rebellion and restrains violence—all evil dissipates. Minor punishments serve as great warnings. This hexagram excels in governance; all affairs begin with worry but end in joy.

He says: What is sought is not obtained; what is done does not succeed. Upholding justice to quell chaos, the petty fear guilt. The sick do not recover; the traveler returns but gains no profit, only slander.

Explanation: Heaven darkens, clouds ascend—like a dragon leaping from the abyss. Using rectitude to expel evil is like water flowing in order. Here, though yin and yang are misplaced, one yang stands at the center, three yang below, forming the image of the noble governing chaos and the firm overcoming the yielding. Divined for governance, civil rule, pursuing fugitives, or quelling rebellion—all prove auspicious. Lawsuits end in righteous victory; secrecy brings no good. For the noble, this is greatly fortunate; for the petty, the opposite holds.

**Unreturned Hexagram of Exile**
*Two-Zero-Four*
Fields lie barren, earth grows hollow; the people relocate. Awaiting a bountiful year, they return to their homes.

Yan says: This hexagram marks yin’s extreme rise, which yang cannot restrain. Fields lie waste, people scatter—only in a year of plenty do they return. The sick recover slowly; silkworms and fields prove unfavorable.

He says: Officials lose emoluments; travelers do not return. Silkworms and fields lose their capital. Though this hexagram is not auspicious, it cannot harm. Best to endure poverty and remain tranquil—seeking blessings brings good fortune.

Explanation: Fields lie barren, earth grows hollow—nothing to rely upon. The petty harbor divergent desires, never uniting. Upholding rectitude and awaiting the moment, one surely attains their place. Here, yang is trapped by yin, while the lower position teems with yin—hence the image of barren fields, hollow earth, and fleeing people. Yet the lower yin, being mature, does not seek union. The petty, having their way, reach their limit and decline, while the lesser yin above instead aligns with us—thus, one ultimately returns to the old home. All affairs meet obstruction; remaining tranquil and awaiting the right time brings good fortune.

**Cautionary Hexagram of Hoarded Wealth**
*Two-Two-One*
Burying gold and hiding jade, one boasts of supreme nobility. Ghostly debts remain unpaid; the spirits withhold blessings.

Yan says: Yang is deemed noble, hence "gold and jade." Boasting of supreme nobility, the spirits do not protect. The sick are haunted by ghosts—best to hasten exorcism. Legal troubles require human aid to resolve.

He says: Hoarding wealth invites calamity. Though treasures exist, one must fear bandits. The sick do not recover; travelers do not return. Prisoners remain confined; silkworms and fields yield no harvest. Deploying troops brings no advantage—one is seized by ghosts. This is ill-fated.

Explanation: Burying gold and hiding treasure—yang lies below. The ghostly path ascends; blessings cannot be borrowed. Here, a solitary yang is suppressed beneath two yang, unable to act. Two yin above, weak and yielding, take this as their treasure—thus, no blessings come, only worries. The diviner must expect ruin from greed.

**Peaceful Hexagram of the Adorned Garden**
*Two-Two-Two*
The year is abundant, the month prosperous; fields and lands expand. Steadfast as Mount Tai, no misfortune befalls in the end.

Yan says: Broadly open the fields, awaiting the year’s end. Divide heaven and earth—no calamity or fault arises. Unshaken, steadfast as Mount Tai. At home, all is auspicious; silkworms and fields yield great harvests. The sick suffer no pain; the traveler has not returned.

He says: Holding office, one enjoys emoluments; wealth and silk come of their own accord. Troops prevail in battle; the pregnant bear sons. Those with learning—this hexagram is greatly auspicious.

**Explication:**
"Abundant year, prosperous month"—all share the same aspiration. Gentle and yielding, favorable and upright, blessings know no end. "Steadfast as Mount Tai"—beginning and end are as one. This divination’s three positions are all yin, yet attain central correctness, bearing the image of dwelling in peace, abiding in compliance, and harboring no external desires. Thus, fortune prevails, misfortune vanishes. For inquiries into household affairs, fields and silkworms, official posts, or market trade—all are greatly auspicious. In campaigns, land is gained; the sick recover without treatment; lawsuits incur no blame; the traveler has not yet returned.

**Heavenly Emolument Divination: Hexagram of Rising Fortune**
*Two-Two-Three*
Receiving Heaven’s emolument, ascending like the sun. From youth in office, rank and stipend flourish.

Yan says: Auspicious for seeking wealth at home; the traveler has not returned. The sick should perform exorcisms; offer sacrifices to seek blessings. It is also said: Heavy yin stirs into motion, ascending like the sun—this approaches pure auspiciousness. Not suitable for reclusion or rebellion. In market trade or hiring servants, desires are difficult to fulfill; the rest is auspicious.

He says: Endeavors are lofty and distant, all coming to fruition. The sick suffer no pain; military campaigns are fortunate. Favorable for praying to the stars; all plans succeed. No matter should be kept secret.

**Explication:**
Yang flourishes below, strength following softness. Cultivating virtue and refining conduct, one receives Heaven’s favor. In this divination, two yin reside above while vigorous yang lies below, advancing upward—an image of the sun’s ascent. For seeking office or advancement, it is greatly auspicious. This divination is purely fortunate, except for reclusion, exile, market trade, or servants.

**Abundant Wealth Divination: Hexagram of Unimpeded Prosperity**
*Two-Two-Four*
Wealth like a wellspring, though used, never exhausted. All sought is attained; joy knows no end.

Yan says: All matters are auspicious; at home, there are celebrations. The traveler returns soon; wealth flows like a wellspring, inexhaustible in use. All desires are fulfilled, bringing unparalleled joy.

He says: Officials attain high promotion; livelihoods grow rich and ample. Fields and silkworms yield double harvests; good fortune and joy abound. The sick recover; prisoners are released—this hexagram is greatly auspicious.

**Explication:**
"Wealth like a wellspring"—one gains the advantage of the land. Softness and compliance move above and below; nothing sought goes unfulfilled. In this divination, the lower position is rich in yin, not clashing with the upper, thus forming the image of fertile land. The two yin, gentle and compliant above, do not act recklessly but enjoy peace—hence their prosperity is unceasing. All inquiries into matters are auspicious.

**Later Fortune Divination: Hexagram of Sorrow and Joy**
*Two-Three-One*
The heart bears sorrow, restless and sleepless. Fearing calamity, fortune arrives instead. Celebration and joy bring great benefit.

Yan says: Initially there is sorrow, but in the end, joy. It is also said: Yin occupies Heaven’s position, where it does not belong. Thus, though there is sorrow, the three yang unite to resist, unable to cause harm. This hexagram brings minor sorrow first, then great fortune—hence no blame.

He says: Gossip comes to nothing; the traveler is on the way. In marriage or trade, difficulty precedes ease. The sick first suffer, then recover; legal matters turn from ill to good; lost items are hard to retrieve.

**Explication:**
Yin overpowers yang—its position is not esteemed. Anxiety subsides, and fortune is gained through firmness in the center. In this divination, yin occupies the upper position while yang resides below—an image of misplaced position. Yet one yang lies below, vigorous and centrally situated, while weak yin cannot restrain strength. Initially, there is doubt, but in the end, good fortune prevails. All matters begin with sorrow but conclude with joy—sorrow is empty, fortune is real.

**Peaceful Divination: Hexagram of Latent Flow**
*Two-Three-Two*
Above and below are at peace; the heart harbors no deceit. Upright and free from worry, do not heed rumors.

Yan says: A righteous heart brings good fortune; do not believe rumors. The traveler arrives; prisoners are released. Though this hexagram has yin above and below, three yang reside in the center. Initially, there is worry, but each abides in its place—no regrets remain. All matters proceed naturally; sorrow precedes joy. Serving rulers and forming alliances is especially good.

He says: Marrying brings a fine wife; the traveler is on the way. The pregnant bear sons; the sick encounter strange omens but suffer no harm. Legal matters dissipate; fields and silkworms prosper. In campaigns, trade, and all matters—greatly auspicious.

**Explication:**
Above and below are both soft, relying on the central ruler. Upright and unyielding, they gain the people’s support. In this divination, three yang occupy the center while above and below are yin. Lesser yin is not yet dominant, avoiding conflict and fostering harmony. Yang’s vigor and yin’s abundance cannot prevail—thus the image of universal peace, with omens but no misfortune.

**Averting Evil Divination: Hexagram of Flourishing Virtue**
*Two-Three-Three*
The multitude loves me, warding off calamity. Fierce dogs do not bite; ten thousand things come to fruition.

Yan says: All matters are auspicious, gaining others’ assistance. The traveler returns; wealth is acquired; at home, all is fortunate. It is also said: Though yin resides above, it is not in its rightful place. Yet yang’s vigor prevails, able to dispel misfortune—all love it. In the three preceding hexagrams, yin usurps yang’s position, but virtue is not lacking. Cultivating it brings good fortune; sorrows cause no suffering.

He says: High ministers and regional lords gain worthy aides. Marrying secures a virtuous wife. The sick recover; prisoners are released; others lend assistance. In war, victory is won; the pregnant bear sons; trade is profitable.

**Explication:**
Modesty and brilliance reside above—all find them lovable. Worthy aides assist in succession, ensuring no harm.

Here the yin resides in the upper position yet does not wield its power. The host of yang below remains steadfast and upright, free from perversity. Though fierce dogs do not bite, they instead serve to ward off misfortune for me. In divination, one gains the support of many, ensuring success through their aid.

**Hexagram of Great Capture, Governing Things** (2-3-4)
The Han Lu hound pursues the hare—its steps cannot stretch forth. The biting dog lies ahead; the pursuer follows behind. Layer upon layer, they press so closely that escape is impossible.

Yan says: At home, all is auspicious; the traveler returns, arriving both before and after. It is also said: The three yang reside in the center, able to restrain the multitude of lesser forces. The fierce dog’s pursuit of the hare leaves no room for flight—speaking of success in the turn of a heel. In all matters, what begins small will grow great. This hexagram favors the capture of fugitives, the pursuit of wealth (which will be abundant), and divination concerning property. For illness, it bodes ill.

He says: Officials and those in sericulture all find their pursuits favorable; travelers meet with good fortune. The sick grow distressed; prisoners remain confined; legal matters prove difficult to resolve; military campaigns return empty-handed. It is also said: Though this path is arduous, why sigh over toil and labor? Cast your line into the deep pool, and you shall surely land a great turtle.

**Explication:**
The three yang occupy the center—vigorous Dao prevails. Though the petty man is yielding, he cannot contend. Even if he seeks to leap and surge, in the end, he submits to fate. In this divination, though the three yang are situated amid two yin, with lesser yin above and elder yin below, the desires of old and young differ. They are constrained by the firm and cannot act. Thus, it takes the form of the Han Lu hound pursuing the hare. For the diviner, it is highly auspicious for capturing fugitives, suppressing rebels, seeking wealth, pursuing profit, and marriage. Travel will meet with obstacles; prisoners will find it hard to escape; the sick will be in grave danger; at home, there is no misfortune. Most matters will come to fruition, but attempts at resolution will fail.

**Hexagram of Decline and Revival** (2-4-1)
The sagely and the worthy succeed one another; the faint revives and flourishes anew. Like the melon vine stretching endlessly, it gradually ascends.

Yan says: Affairs that were askew now reunite; seekers obtain what is hidden; all things follow the heart’s desire. It is also said: Though yang is faint and weak, its aspiration lies in uprightness. Rising from below to above, it resembles the melon vine’s tendrils, extending ceaselessly upward. With a sincere heart in one’s endeavors, one revives what is fading and restores what is broken. This hexagram favors official promotion, the bestowal of grace and fortune, and the seeking of heirs.

He says: Studies come to fruition; the traveler arrives soon. Sericulture yields great harvests; trade is profitable; the wife one marries is virtuous and fair; officials ascend in rank; all desires are fulfilled. The sick grow distressed—praying to the spirits will bring good fortune. Lost items will not be recovered.

**Explication:**
Yin flourishes in the center, but when it reaches its extreme, it must decline. Like the melon vine stretching endlessly, yang returns. Gradually ascending, the upright Dao is restored. In this divination, lesser yang resides beneath the host of yin, perilously isolated. Yet lesser yin lies above, with elder yin in the center—they lack the will to unite. The petty man, though at his peak, is doomed to discord, while lesser yang rises from below. As they wane, it advances, like the melon vine’s ceaseless ascent—a sign of revival after decline and the restoration of order. All matters bode well.

**Hexagram of Avoiding Disaster** (2-4-2)
Summer departs, autumn arrives; frost brings calamity. Birds and beasts grow thick fur; grasses and trees shed their leaves.

Yan says: In all matters, spring’s beginning follows the heart’s desire; at home, all is auspicious; the traveler has not yet returned. It is also said: Summer emerges, autumn retreats—yang scatters as yin reaches its peak. Thus, birds and beasts shed their fur, grasses and trees fade in color. The noble man, in a time of obscurity and stillness, cannot advance with the affairs of the age. This divination leans toward misfortune.

He says: Officials face unjust accusations; prisoners and rebels harm one another. The sick grow distressed; military campaigns meet with misfortune; legal matters are hard to resolve; travelers do not return; livelihoods are lost; there is gossip, theft, and banditry.

**Explication:**
Summer departs, autumn arrives—yin qi flourishes. Grasses and trees wither and yellow; stillness preserves uprightness. In this divination, the host of yin holds sway, with elder yin in the center—a time when the noble man’s Dao is obstructed. The diviner should withdraw, remain still, and guard their integrity; seeking advancement will not bring good fortune. All matters will fail to achieve their aims; the sick will face great distress.

**Hexagram of Enlightening the Obscure** (2-4-3)
Yin at its extreme transforms into yang; hibernating creatures stir and emerge. The imperial pardon is proclaimed; the bells and drums resound grandly.

Yan says: Through yin, yang is aroused; reverently employing the multitude of creatures is like striking bells and drums to grant broad amnesty, opening the gates of the dark prison. This is the hexagram governed by the celestial immortals. It is highly auspicious for official advancement but ill-suited for marriage, for yin and yang injure one another and lack harmony.

Sunzi says: Do not intercept a formation with banners arrayed in perfect order; do not strike a battle line drawn up in full strength.

He says: Imperial grace descends; prisoners are released; officials attain high rank; livelihoods multiply tenfold.

**Explication:**
Yin at its extreme transforms into yang—thunder arises from within the earth. The bells and drums resound grandly—the voice of virtue spreads far. In this divination, the three yang succeed the yin at its peak, like the thunderclap that awakens hibernating creatures—a time when the noble man’s Dao flourishes. All matters bode well; when deploying troops, it is fitting to display civil virtue.

**Hexagram of Hidden Illness** (2-4-4)
Yin’s excess brings minor illness; one lies prostrate, filled with sorrow. Gazing upward at the heavens, then bowing low in submission.

Yan says: One’s desires are unfulfilled; the traveler faces misfortune. It is also said: Yin’s harm arises subtly, not yet reaching its extreme—hence, it is called minor illness. Yet lying prostrate and gazing at the heavens, one sees no savior; thus, one bows low in submission, consumed by worry. This hexagram bodes ill for all matters; only secrecy is advisable.

He says: The sick cannot be saved; prisoners’ sentences are sealed; reasoning proves difficult; travelers encounter misfortune—this hexagram is inauspicious.

**Explication:**
Yin’s dominance spreads insidiously—distress and hardship follow. Bowing low and gazing at the heavens, sorrow reaches its extreme.

Here, two yin lines are exhausted below, while one yin line perches above—this portends misfortune for the world. In divination: illness leads to death, prisoners remain confined, the besieged find no rescue, and all matters turn inauspicious.

*The Classic of Spirit Chess, Upper Scroll of the Orthodox Canon* concludes here.

**Hexagram of Minor Advancement in the Yang Divination (311)**
*Office and salary come in due season; emolument aligns with one’s years.*
Diligently attend to affairs—take heed, lest you lose the moment.

Yan says: Official salary arrives in its time; in retreat or advancement, the cold season of one’s years brings both fortune and emolument. Be vigilant and cautious; do not grow lax or negligent.
For the sick, swift recovery. The traveler, though returned, gains something along the way.

It is also said: Dispelling accumulated yin, one governs the host of yang, doubling brightness and radiance.
Beholding the beauty of the state, one speaks of position—all affairs are in great harmony.
Other external matters may also be pursued in season: marriage and official pursuits are especially auspicious.

He says: For all one seeks, choose an auspicious time.
For the sick, offer prayers and supplications for blessings. The traveler will arrive at once.
For the imprisoned, seek those who enforce the law—they will surely secure pardon.

*Explanation*: The brilliance of yang is upright and direct; the path of office is greatly flourishing.
The noble person’s time for service is to act in due season. In this divination, the three yang lines occupy their rightful positions, while the middle and lower lines are yang in ascent.
The Dao of yang is unimpeded; yin’s perversity is cast aside. For those in office or pursuing the Way, this is the moment to act.
All matters are highly auspicious—advance without missing the opportunity. Every affair is favorable, save those of secret yin.

---

**Hexagram of Heaven’s Blessing: The Path (312)**
*Ascend high and gaze afar—above, one sees the celestial thoroughfare.*
The Jade Maiden, most sagely, bestows upon me a divine talisman.
Eternal bestowal of agelessness, to preserve my body.

Yan says: This is the image of receiving things, matters arising from a woman.
At home, all is auspicious. The traveler has not yet returned but will surely obtain rare treasures. The sick will recover of themselves.

It is also said: Heaven and Earth’s positions are now correct; Heaven and humanity unite in virtue. It is like ascending high to observe the six directions, yet below, one responds to yin.
When one finds their match, the divine talisman may be sought and seen.
A century of venerable age may be attained in tranquility.
This hexagram is an omen for the noble: yin and yang are in their rightful places, without mutual harm. All affairs are auspicious.

He says: For those at home, fortune. Marriage brings beauty.
The traveler’s road is unimpeded; the sick will recover at once. In official matters, seeking high ministers brings good fortune.
Silkworms and wheat flourish; the pregnant will bear sons. Merchants profit; the traveler returns. This hexagram is greatly auspicious.

*Explanation*: Ascending high to gaze afar is to occupy the superior position.
The Jade Maiden bestows the talisman—yin’s mutual response.
Centered and correct, one receives Heaven’s blessing.
Here, a single yang resides in the middle, above supporting the firm and luminous ruler, below responding to the young yin’s match—its fortune is unparalleled.

---

**Hexagram of Nobility: Encountering the Auspicious (313)**
*Virtue shines brilliantly; ten thousand years without end.*
The Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper guard and defend me.
Attaining promotion and emolument, generation after generation brings prosperity.

Yan says: Above and below are both yang; within and without, all is illuminated.
This is no hexagram for the common folk—it is the sign of the honored and wise.
Even those who would meet the lord may draw a comparison.

It is also said: All one seeks will be obtained; the traveler returns.

He says: Officials will be promoted; scholarship will bear fruit. Leading troops, one gains advantage; the army suffers no harm.
For the sick, pray to the celestial spirits. Marriage is fitting; merchants profit. The traveler returns; silkworms and wheat thrive. Official matters disperse. This hexagram is greatly auspicious.

*Explanation*: Virtue shines brilliantly—the Dao of yang is manifest.
The Northern Dipper guards and defends—yin’s treachery is dispelled.
In seeking office or planning affairs, one gains the power of the noble.
For grave sites or dwellings, this is an auspicious location.
For those at home, movement; for travelers, companionship. This is the divination of the noble.
Even common folk who obtain it will know extraordinary joy. Prayers are fitting.

---

**Hexagram of Prayer and Exorcism (314)**
*Numerous strange anomalies appear—summon the shaman to perform the rites.*
Pray and supplicate for blessings; calamity vanishes, misfortune ceases.
Great and small find peace—by the power of the gods and spirits.

Yan says: The subject will encounter strange events. At first, matters do not proceed as desired, but later, all conforms to the heart.
The traveler will arrive; there will first be tidings. At home, all is auspicious.

It is also said: Through accumulated yin encroaching upon extreme yang, one remains still while witnessing anomalies.
The so-called shaman responds to the superior position—prayer is fitting.
By harmonizing and dispelling misfortune, is this not the protective power of the gods?
All affairs are slightly auspicious.

He says: Fear calamity and misfortune—perform good deeds to avert them.
There may be quarrels, disputes, lawsuits, or hardships; evil dreams or strange anomalies. Former misfortune, later fortune; beginning difficult, end easy. Fortune and misfortune are evenly matched—only vigilance and exorcism are fitting.
For the sick, sacrifices to the celestial spirits bring good fortune. Marriage will be promptly settled, for within and without, there is response.

*Explanation*: Witnessing anomalies gives rise to doubt.
The household harbors an old ghost, whose power cannot be overcome.
Appeal to the divine—security is preserved without loss.
Here, accumulated yin resides within, while the superior position is replete with yang. Thus, the middle position speaks of the diviner obtaining it.
The household will encounter strange events—exorcism brings good fortune. For illness or lawsuits, prayer and exorcism are fitting. Seeking others, one gains their power. In all matters, initial worry yields to later fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Bestowing Goods: Initial Auspiciousness (321)**
*A guest arrives from the south, leaving me fine wealth.*
Precious goods and rare treasures: a golden platter, a jade cup.

Yan says: Someone will send things; at home, all is auspicious. The traveler returns, obtaining treasures and wealth.

It is also said: Yin occupies the center, responding to external yang—friends arrive from afar, is this not fitting?
The south is the position of yang, hence "from the south."
Precious goods and rare treasures are the resources of the noble; the golden platter and jade cup, the vessels of a fine feast.

He says: Marriage is auspicious; all one seeks will be obtained. The sick will recover; merchants profit. Official matters disperse; the traveler returns. This hexagram is greatly auspicious.

*Explanation*: A guest arrives from the south—firm and yielding respond.
The golden bowl and jade cup express reverence.

Here the divination shows Lesser Yin dwelling at the center, with one yang aligned below, while abundant yang holds its proper place above. Yin, through its yielding compliance, responds to external yang—thus obtaining precious goods. The "south" refers to the upper three lines forming *Li*, the southern direction. The "golden bowl and jade cup" arise from the lower single line as *Qian*, for *Qian* represents gold and jade, and the round vessel—hence the image of a golden bowl and jade cup. The first line corresponds to the upper and aligns with the center; the center is even, signifying a guest’s gift. For the querent, all matters are greatly auspicious, with seeking wealth and marriage most favorable.

**Peaceful Land Hexagram** (3-2-2)
The land is at peace, without hardship or difficulty.
Sow and cultivate as you wish; journeys and returns are favorable.

Yan says: The lower position does not encroach upon the upper, hence "the land is at peace." Planting is timely, trade is profitable, official ranks advance, illness poses no threat, travelers are safe and will soon arrive, marriages are harmonious, and dwellings are auspicious.
He says: Seekers attain their desires, the sick recover lightly, official matters bring no worry, and all affairs are tranquil—this is a hexagram of great fortune.

*Explanation*: "The land is at peace" because the yielding dwells in lowliness. "Without hardship or difficulty" comes from an untroubled heart. With no deceit between above and below, what could go amiss? Here, firm yang resides above while the middle and lower positions harmonize in compliance—thus the land is at peace and free from difficulty, so movement and stillness, advance and retreat encounter no obstruction. All matters are auspicious.

**Reverent Harmony Hexagram** (3-2-3)
Above, one stands upright; below, people fulfill their duties.
Households live in harmony, young and old unite in effort.
With unopposed resolve, all one seeks is obtained.

Yan says: Yin occupies the central position, embodying the Way of compliance—hence "below, people fulfill their duties." This hexagram unites the strength of all below, so all requests are fulfilled.
He says: Marriages are auspicious, husbands and wives harmonious, dwellings secure, travelers return, business and sericulture prosper, sons are born, and all matters are greatly fortunate.

*Explanation*: Yang’s firmness above is fitting and proper. With vigor and compliance mutually supporting, those below fulfill their duties. Households live in harmony, and nothing sought is denied. This hexagram brings good fortune in office, at home, on journeys, in work, marriage, and trade—nothing is not favorable, making it a greatly auspicious sign for all plans.

**Defiance Hexagram** (3-2-4)
Below does not follow above; the center cannot restrain the outer.
Above and below clash in defiance, discipline and order collapse in ruin.

Yan says: The Yin path steadily grows, while yang cannot contain it—such discord leads to chaos, hence "ruin." The sick grow worse, and medicine proves ineffective. Armies suffer defeat, and travelers do not return. This hexagram bodes ill for all matters.
He says: Nothing sought is obtained, nothing undertaken succeeds. One will see households scatter, property lost, armies defeated, distant journeys plagued by disaster, the sick distressed, official matters entangled, legal troubles unavoidable, and all exits leading to death’s gate—nothing is auspicious. Do not act or change course; only with the new year will fortune return. If obtained in the first month, it is inauspicious.

*Explanation*: "Below does not follow above" because yin prevails. "Above and below clash in defiance" through mutual aggression. "Discipline and order collapse in ruin"—they cannot prevail in the end.
