Here, above and below clash while yielding yin occupies the center, unable to govern the petty yet also unable to rightly follow above—this inevitably leads to ruin. All matters are inauspicious for the querent.

**Hidden Virtue Hexagram** (3-3-1)
The Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang,
Cultivating nature and walking the Dao.
Inhaling and exhaling primordial qi,
One may attain agelessness.

Yan says: Though this hexagram is pure yang, the lower position governs, approaching the image of a noble retreat—thus one may nurture its purity. All matters are secure and auspicious, except marriage, which is unfavorable due to its pure yang nature.
He says: Officials ascend to high rank, sericulture and farming should begin early, travelers return at once, official matters disperse immediately, the sick recover on their own, and trade, home life, and all affairs prosper—this is an omen of great fortune.

*Explanation*: The Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang illuminate while dwelling in seclusion. Inhaling and exhaling primordial qi allows for leisurely ease. Here, double yang occupies the upper two positions, a time of brilliance under heaven. Yet with one yang below, only the Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang can match this. For the querent, it is fitting to dwell in peace and uphold integrity, enjoying the blessings of health and tranquility—do not seek advancement from others.

**Growing Firmness Hexagram** (2-1-3)
Two people share one heart,
Both as inner and outer.
Dwelling together in one state,
They rely on each other like lips and teeth.

Yan says: Gain comes from others, loss from oneself. Also: Three yangs reside above yin—hence "two people share one heart." Home life and all other matters are auspicious. Officials fare even better, marriages bear minor flaws, the sick recover slowly, and those seeking counsel find success. Travelers have not returned but will surely receive news.
He says: Rulers and ministers observe propriety, friends share one heart. Trade is profitable, sons are born, silkworms and wheat bring minor fortune. Official matters find aid, the sick suffer no harm, and medical treatment is advisable. This hexagram brings no calamity—greatly auspicious.

**Explanation says:**
"Two people share one heart" signifies doubled firmness. The yielding and compliant reside below, unharmed. Withdrawing to rely on each other like lips and teeth, they form a steadfast barrier. In this configuration, one yin dwells beneath doubled yang—yielding yet without conflict. Two yangs above act in unison, serving as inner and outer, embodying the image of dwelling together in one state. Like lips and teeth, they depend on each other and cannot be separated. For matters concerning rulers and ministers, brothers, husbands and wives, or friends, all are auspicious. One must not harbor groundless suspicions. In household affairs and commerce, great joy prevails. Do not heed slanderous words. Planting yields abundance, and silkworms and wheat bring harvest. Pregnant women will bear sons, official matters find resolution with aid, and the sick should seek medical treatment and perform blessings for protection. Marriages are harmonious, matching fine partners. For travelers, though they have not returned, news will surely arrive. This hexagram, when consulted for affairs, trade, or household matters, is an omen of great fortune. One version states: If one seeks elsewhere, it will not be favorable.

**Hexagram of Strong and Prosperous Forces (3-3-3)**
A multitude thrives and regains strength,
Already wealthy and flourishing.
Favorable for establishing merit,
None can resist or oppose.

Yan says: In this hexagram, each of the three positions holds three yangs—truly at the height of prosperity. Thus, in establishing merit and undertaking affairs, none can obstruct. In all matters, one should follow the straight path without partiality, never straying into crookedness—only then will it be auspicious.
He says: This hexagram is in its prime. Pregnant women will bear sons, travelers will return at once, business ventures are profitable, fields and silkworms yield double, hunting and fishing bring gains, relocation is auspicious, those raising armies will triumph, and those guarding borders will find peace. Homes are fortunate, illnesses recover, official matters disperse, trade is profitable—this hexagram is greatly auspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Three yangs share the same virtue, thriving and regaining strength. In establishing merit and undertaking affairs, they act with bold resolve. This configuration, with all three positions as yang, is firm, vigorous, and grand, reaching the height of wealth and prosperity. Thus, it is favorable for establishing merit and undertaking affairs. For those who obtain this hexagram, it is greatly auspicious to take action, especially in military matters. However, for illness, it is severe, and for marriage, it is unfavorable—due to its pure yang nature.

**Hexagram of Noble Beauty (3-3-4)**
Green windows and purple chambers,
Within dwell ladies of grace.
With radiant countenances and fragrant hues,
Orchids and irises bloom.

Yan says: The yin position flourishes, and matters arise from women. The sick recover on their own, and all sought-after goals are attained. Also: Pure yin resides below, corresponding above to heaven and humanity. Their essence and qi are fresh and fragrant, like orchids. Travelers return at once, marriages are most favorable, the sick find peace, and all affairs are auspicious.
He says: This is the hexagram of inner nobility. For marriage, the noble can be obtained, but the humble cannot. As a yin hexagram, it is unfavorable for yang matters. In planning, litigation, or encounters with influential figures, as well as with inner nobility, monks, nuns, or Daoists, it is auspicious. At home or abroad, financial gains and blessings abound, people admire you, and all matters are peaceful.

**Explanation says:**
Doubled firmness above shines with the Dao of yang. The multitude of yin below submits, resembling ladies of grace. Their descendants will surely flourish. In this configuration, though the multitude of yin is strong, it resides in the lower position, while the Dao of yang shines brightly above. The yielding dare not encroach, thus forming a proper correspondence. In all consulted matters, there is harmony. Travelers return at once, marriages are greatly auspicious, friendships deepen, and illnesses are not fatal.

**Hexagram of Gaining Emolument and Rising Fortune (3-4-1)**
Ruler and minister exchange positions,
Just as great fortune arises.
Messengers and letters travel,
People act with self-indulgence.

Yan says: Relocation is auspicious, and this direction brings profit. Pursuits will surely meet success. Travelers have not returned, but news arrives first. For the sick, their dwelling must be changed—moving away will avoid harm. Perhaps perform sacrifices, but do not partake; if one does, it will be auspicious. Also: One yang below, with a multitude of yin above—hence "exchanging positions." As merit and enterprise rise, they rely on others to succeed—hence "messengers and letters travel." In this hexagram, matters initially do not harmonize, but later bring great fortune—difficult at first, easy afterward.
He says: The lines of those in office undergo change, and affairs are auspicious. Travelers by water and land all return, livelihoods multiply tenfold, pregnant women bear sons, and marriages secure fine partners.

**Explanation says:**
"Ruler and minister exchange positions" signifies yin submitting to yang. "Messengers and letters travel with self-indulgence" means losing their proper allegiance. In this configuration, three yangs reside above, while one yang is below—this is called "ruler and minister exchanging positions." Moreover, four yins occupy the middle, overpowering it, while the three above, firm and strong, dwell externally and cannot attend to their ruler. Instead, they ally with the multitude of yin to pursue great fortune. Messengers and letters travel, acting with self-indulgence—this is extremely inauspicious. This hexagram is the exact opposite of the fifteenth hexagram in the "Three Images, One Above" section. Comparing and observing them reveals the author’s intent.

**Hexagram of Doubt and Hesitation (3-4-2)**
Intentions are glimpsed,
Yet fear they cannot be realized.
Advancing and retreating in hesitation,
Uncertain of what to do.

Yan says: In all matters, if one wavers in advancing or retreating, affairs will not be single-minded. Without single-mindedness, they cannot succeed. Also: Yin resides in the lower position, corresponding above to yang. Desiring action, the multitude of yin internally obstructs—hence the hesitation. Yet if one strives with determination, there will ultimately be gain. In this hexagram, all matters begin without success but end with it.
He says: What is sought is not obtained, what is undertaken does not succeed, livelihoods are unprofitable, officials retreat, travelers are confused, official matters are difficult to resolve, the sick face danger—this hexagram is an image of bewilderment.

**Explanation says:**
"Intentions are glimpsed" because the response lies below. "Fear they cannot be realized" due to the obstruction of petty people. "Advancing and retreating in hesitation" means doubt prevents resolution. In this configuration, yin resides in the lower position, corresponding above to yang, but is separated by the four yins in the middle.

The upper yang seeks to respond to the lower, yet is constrained by yin—thus doubt arises and cannot be resolved, giving birth to worry and misfortune. Divination reveals confusion without success: the sick waver between improvement and decline, and all matters prove unfavorable.

**Evil-Dispelling, Clarity-Shining Hexagram**  ☰☰☷
*Three-Four-Three*
The sun rises in the eastern sky, blazing with radiant brilliance.
Though malevolent qi lingers, it is scorched and consumed by the flames.
The multitude of worthy ones shatters the yin, and calamities dissolve.

Yan says: Amidst the prevailing yin, it is called "malevolent qi." The surrounding yang, through its searing heat, purges it.
All matters begin in discord but end in fortune.

He says: Official matters fail, yet one receives assistance. Prisoners free themselves; the sick first suffer but later recover. Travelers return at once; trade and official pursuits, though initially thwarted, ultimately yield great fortune.

**Explanation says:**
"Blazing with radiant brilliance"—both above and below are luminous. When malevolence reaches its extreme, it declines and cannot persist. The multitude of yin is shattered and dispersed, and the human Dao prevails. In this hexagram, two firm yangs assail a dominant yin: though effort is required at first, success is ultimately assured. All divined matters are auspicious; though perilous, there is no blame. However, divining yin matters brings misfortune.

**Upright Yang Hexagram**  ☰☰☷
*Three-Four-Four*
Above stands a worthy ruler; below lurk slanderous ministers.
Sun and moon cast their light, yet dark dust remains unseen.

Yan says: The three yangs above form the image of a worthy ruler. Though sun and moon shine brightly, they do not illuminate the dark dust.

For those in high positions, fortune prevails; slander does not take root. Marriage brings a virtuous wife, and the sick suffer no distress.

He says: Though the yang above is luminous, the multitude of yin gazes upward in reflection. Though sun and moon shine, dark dust still arises. This hexagram portends frequent regrets. Seeking office is somewhat difficult, but divining marriage is auspicious, for yin and yang respond to each other. The sick waver between improvement and decline, recovering only at the onset of spring. All matters bring minor fortune, flourishing only when spring stirs.

**Explanation says:**
The firm yang occupies its rightful position—above stands a worthy ruler. The accumulated yin below resembles dark dust. Obstruction lingers unresolved, and aspirations cannot be fulfilled. In this hexagram, the firm yang ascends to the celestial position, yet the middle and lower positions are filled with crooked yin, jointly causing obstruction. There is a ruler but no ministers, hence his will cannot be enacted. Divined matters often bring regret; only marriage, through mutual resonance, is auspicious. This hexagram holds equal measure of fortune and misfortune.

**Orphaned-Poverty Hexagram: Encountering Difficulty**  ☷☰☰
*Four-One-One*
Emerging from warmth into cold, clad in thin garments.
Departing from my loving mother, I suffer this calamity and transgression.

Yan says: Two yangs lie below, obscured by the multitude of yin. It is as if one leaves what is beloved and encounters harsh pity.
In this hexagram, all matters are inauspicious. Travelers do not arrive; the sick worsen, bearing the image of separation. It is best to maintain the status quo. Obtaining this in the first or second month brings fortune; in other months, misfortune.

He says: Officials make no progress; livelihoods yield no profit. Dwelling in solitude and poverty, one endures hardship to the end. Prisoners struggle to be freed; the sick do not recover. Nothing aligns with one’s desires. Marriages lack constancy; all matters demand caution. Only with the arrival of the new year does vitality return.

**Explanation says:**
"Clad in thin garments"—lowly and orphaned. The dominant yin above obscures all, leaving none to accompany him. In this hexagram, two yangs reside beneath the dominant yin yet receive no response, like an orphaned child. Moreover, the fourth line, with its crooked yin above, resembles a jealous wife regarding the orphan—his plight is extreme. Divining illness portends danger; travelers face prolonged hardship; officials encounter obstacles; livelihoods falter; military campaigns meet resistance. All matters are inauspicious.

**Hidden Dragon Hexagram: Awaiting the Hour**  ☷☰☷
*Four-One-Two*
Shun tilled the fields, reaching Mount Li.
The soil was fertile, the harvest abundant—ten thousand measures reaped in a year.

Yan says: All matters begin in the third or fourth month and conclude in the eighth or ninth month.
Again, it is said: The hidden dragon tills the fields, responding to the year’s abundance—who but Yu Shun could achieve this? This hexagram aligns with the first yang line of *Qian*, preserving one’s integrity in reclusion to cultivate the ruler’s virtue within. Whether matters are great or small, acting with benevolence is fitting; seeking through calculation is difficult. The sick will recover only by the end of autumn.

He says: Suitable for farming and sericulture; what is sought will be obtained. Trade brings profit; households prosper. Travelers return; pregnant women bear sons. Marriages harmonize. This hexagram brings great fortune in all matters.

**Explanation says:**
The accumulated yin above is exhausted, leaving none to accompany him. His virtue flourishes and finds resonance below. When the time arrives, he rises—none can resist. Though this hexagram places a single yang amidst the multitude of yin, the upper yin, having reached its extreme, has exhausted its path. The lesser yin below aligns with me. Though the upper does not regard me, the lower responds—hence the image of Shun plowing Mount Li. Though not loved by his parents, his profound virtue ultimately ascends to renown.

**Beneficial Friend Hexagram: Responsive Divination**  ☷☰☷
*Four-One-Three*
A noble scion arrives, knocking at my gate.
He speaks of fortune and blessing—going forth, I shall surely receive favor.

Yan says: One should go only when summoned. To be called and not go is inauspicious. The words advise going; if a traveler is abroad, calling him will bring his return.
Again, it is said: The inner responds to the outer, not remaining within—his aspiration lies in going, for the middle position aids him. When a guest knocks at the gate, who could be nobler than a scion? This hexagram is timely for marriage and all the more favorable for seeking. One version states: Seeking from others brings misfortune.

He says: Officials gain merit; farming and sericulture are auspicious. The sick recover; legal matters disperse. Travelers return; seekers attain their desires. All matters bring great fortune.

**Explanation says:**
"A noble scion knocks at the gate"—the response lies without. "Going forth, I shall surely receive favor"—the journey brings assistance. In this hexagram, exhausted yin resides above, while flourishing yang lies below. Yin, having reached its extreme, seeks the yang—hence the image of knocking at my gate. The noble scion is a person of high standing. The middle position, a lesser yang, neither competes with me nor aids me, thus going forth brings blessing.

Divination favors advancement, for one shall receive assistance from a noble person. The sick will encounter skilled physicians; in military affairs, allies will respond. All matters bring good fortune.

**Long Treachery Hexagram (Many Difficulties)**
*Four-One-Four*
Separated and distant, with repeated obstructions.
All undertakings prove unfavorable; nothing prospers.

Yan says: In all endeavors, the heart’s desires remain unfulfilled, and one encounters only alarm and dread, for a single yang cannot prevail alone. Though it occupies the central position, it suffers repeated harm. Retreating into concealment, survival itself becomes difficult. This hexagram is wholly inauspicious—one must maintain the status quo and avoid new ventures, for all new schemes bring misfortune.

He says: Travelers by land and water meet with repeated setbacks and ruin. The sick recover with difficulty; prisoners remain confined; merchants gain no profit. This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Separated and distant, one is beset by isolation. Already solitary and weak, how can anything be accomplished? This hexagram shows a lone yang submerged within accumulated yin, unable to rise—thus nearly all matters bring misfortune.

**Divine Assistance Hexagram (Utmost Adversity Reversed)**
*Four-Two-One*
Four ghosts and two shamans bow in supplication.
Heavenly spirits descend to release the imprisoned.
Afflictions vanish; blessings from Heaven are attained.

Yan says: All entanglements dissolve. Heavy yin prevails in the heavens, and ghostly qi transforms. A single yang stands alone—who but the heavenly spirits could respond thus? All matters begin inauspiciously but conclude favorably.

He says: Collaborating with others brings good fortune. Marriages harmonize; prisoners are freed; the sick recover; travelers return; pregnancies yield sons; silkworms and wheat yield modest harvests; enmities resolve themselves; seeking office or wealth first brings worry, then good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Four ghosts and two shamans—yin flourishes and ascends. Heavenly spirits descend with blessings, for adversity has reached its extreme and now gives way to prosperity. In this hexagram, yin prevails, assuming the form of ghosts and spirits. A lesser yin occupies the central position, drawn to its own kind. Though the single yang is weak and cannot rise on its own, the young man and young woman will surely unite if they seek it. Thus, they can entreat the spirits above on my behalf, bringing down blessings and dispelling calamities. What was once a surging yin above is no longer a ghost but a heavenly spirit. This is the image of adversity reaching its limit and the Way of Peace returning. Divination indicates reliance on others will prove effective, with initial hardship followed by joy.

**Expiatory Sacrifice Hexagram (Auspicious for Offerings)**
*Four-Two-Two*
Tombs and high mounds—ghosts and spirits roam above.
Hasten to perform expiatory rites, and you may avoid misfortune.

Yan says: Accumulated yin with no yang forms towering, ghostly mounds—the image of tombs. Ghostly and spiritual forces flourish; only wholehearted sacrifice can avert misfortune.

He says: If one has vowed offerings to spirits but not fulfilled them, doing so now brings good fortune. Should strange omens appear, it is auspicious to sacrifice to the spirits of hills and mounds. This hexagram is middling—official advancement, seeking wealth, recovery from illness, and legal matters all begin with difficulty but conclude favorably. Travelers abroad face obstruction from a yin person but will return by summer; all else remains peaceful.

**Explanation says:**
Tombs and high mounds—ghostly qi thrives. Perform expiatory rites swiftly to accept fate with reverence. In this hexagram, four yin lines occupy the upper position, while the middle and lower positions hold only lesser yin, with no yang—thus the image of tombs and high mounds. Only through reverence and compliance can one avoid disaster. The diviner should avoid contention; in all matters, adopting a gentle, upright, and honest approach brings good fortune.

**Later Laughter Hexagram (Auspicious for Prayers of Blessing)**
*Four-Two-Three*
The essence of metal stirs, but the primal scholar restrains it.
Pressing down with the left hand, one obtains favor and protection.

Yan says: Metal belongs to the west, the position of lesser yin, governing weapons and slaughter. The "primal scholar" is a great person. The left is yang, meaning that when yin qi stirs to bring harm, the great person assists. Pressing down with the left hand, the harm is dispelled—yang can restrain yin. In this hexagram, worries do not come to pass, and extreme disorder turns auspicious.

He says: This hexagram brings initial sorrow followed by joy. In all undertakings, one attains good fortune through the assistance of others. In ventures and aspirations, there is first sorrow, then joy. All matters ultimately gain the aid of a noble person, transforming misfortune into blessing. In affairs, good fortune prevails. Those with powerful officials may avoid calamity, but they must remain cautious and adhere to constancy in all things.

**Explanation says:**
Lesser yin ascends, and the essence of metal stirs. The three yang lines restrain it, causing it to halt on its own. In this hexagram, exhausted yin occupies the upper position, while lesser yin resides in the middle—two forms the image of *dui*, hence the "essence of metal." The three yang below correspond to the upper lines. Lesser yin cannot act, for the left is yang. In all matters, one gains assistance from others, first through caution, then through joy.

**Initial Auspiciousness Hexagram (Auspicious for Prayers of Blessing)**
*Four-Two-Four*
In ancestral temple rites, harm ceases and misfortune halts.
Blessings fill the gate, while calamities flee ten thousand miles.

Yan says: The multitude of yin above forms the image of ancestral temples. Official matters disperse, the sick recover—it is fitting to seek blessings and offer sacrifices to the spirits. When encountering omens or in all matters, one should perform rites at the ancestral temple to attain good fortune.

He says: If a daughter is conceived, guard against great fire.

**Explanation says:**
The ancestral temple rites are where the spirits reside. By reverently upholding them, blessings come without misfortune.

Here is the translation:

---

This divination shows four yin both above and below: the upper as ancestral temples, the lower as burial mounds. The second, with its lesser yin, occupies the central position, like one who serves gods and ghosts. By reverently and obediently upholding the rites without fail, one receives blessings and avoids misfortune. The omens thus mirror this auspiciousness.

**From the Heart Divination (Treading the Peaceful Hexagram)**
*Four-Three-One*
The dark clouds gather above, while below no slanderers remain.
All matters flow smoothly, each returning to its true nature.

Yan says: In all matters, follow the heart, and others will assist. He also says: Yin occupies the upper position, revered by the multitude of yang. Misfortune departs, blessings arrive—all through ancestral rites. This hexagram favors grand sacrifices at the ancestral temple, ensuring household peace and ultimate safety from blame.

He says: A son will be conceived; the traveler returns at once; no bitter disputes arise. The sick should perform rites and seek blessings to recover. Fields and silkworms yield harvests—greatly auspicious. This hexagram is most effective in autumn.

**Explanation says:**
The dark clouds above signify yin ascending. Below, no slanderers remain, for the yang path is unimpeded. This divination shows four yin above, while the two lower positions are yang, forming the image of dark clouds. The third, central, and first positions each occupy their rightful place. With yang unobstructed by yin, no slanderers remain—this is the image of all matters flowing smoothly. The omens for all affairs are auspicious; the traveler returns immediately.

**Loss and Gain Divination (Overcoming Strength Hexagram)**
*Four-Three-Two*
My treasured pearl is gone, now lost upon the heavenly thoroughfare.
Unexpectedly, the thief lurks in hidden malice.
Yet the dark crow comes to my aid, driving the foe away.
The wind stills, the waves calm—I return to my home.

Yan says: In all matters, one is first restrained, then follows the heart. If objects are obtained through others, they will soon depart. First hardship, then success—such is the nature of most affairs. He also says: Four yin bandits violently steal my rare treasure. Yet yang remains, and in the end, treachery is cut down, like the dark crow pursuing evil birds. The storm subsides, and one may return to the old dwelling. This hexagram is first inauspicious, then auspicious.

He says: First restraint, then success—all matters follow this pattern. Fields and silkworms prosper; a son is conceived—this is a greatly auspicious hexagram.

**Explanation says:**
"My treasured pearl is gone" signifies yin’s exhaustion above. This divination shows four yin exhausted above, while two yin grow below, forming the image of my pearl stolen and the thief’s hidden lair. Yet three yang reside in the center, aligned with the upper position. The lesser yin is too weak to oppose them and thus cannot cause harm. The omens promise initial fortune followed by peace, with good fortune attained through others’ assistance.

**Seeking Aid Divination (Receiving Assistance Hexagram)**
*Four-Three-Three*
The Controller of Fate descends, inspecting the threads of destiny.
Though life’s span is not yet exhausted, one suffers unjustly.

Immediately summon Bian Que to open the jade flask.
Bestow a single pill of medicine, and life is restored.
Yan says: The sick should take nine doses of medicine; what they seek will be obtained, and the traveler will return.
It is also said: The Controller of Fate is the Celestial Physician.
Though the host of yin resides above and the multitude of yang dwells in the center, though they occupy their proper positions, they become obstacles instead. If the innocent are drowned in unjust calamity, Heaven commands Bian Que to save them, and the disaster is dispelled.
This hexagram brings fortune through misfortune, life through illness.
He says: In official matters, there will be documents and confusion before resolution; it is also called "rest and dispersal."
In all affairs of this hexagram, misfortune precedes good fortune; in official matters, one gains the power of a noble.
**Explanation says:**
Yang is obscured by yin, yet no great guilt exists.
The doubled firmness ascends—it cannot ultimately be defiled.
This divination shows pure yang in the middle and lower positions, with four yin above, forming the image of the innocent being trapped. Yet yang is in its prime; though momentarily suppressed, it will not sink into ruin. Moreover, yin at its extreme must decline, while the Dao of yang is in full vigor, and one shall receive the aid of celestial spirits.
The omens promise initial hardship followed by prosperity, fortune through misfortune.
The sick will be weary but not die; in warfare, peril will yield victory; in all matters, initial sorrow will turn to good fortune.

**Great Passage Divination (Unobstructed Hexagram)**
*Four-Three-Four*
The celestial thoroughfare lies smooth and broad,
Five paths open, six ways connect.
I travel within it,
Riding clouds, mounting dragons.
Yan says: The three yang occupy the center, their position noble and virtue abundant—I am yang. The celestial thoroughfare is unobstructed; riding clouds and mounting dragons, one commands the six directions. Like the Nine-Five of *Qian*, if the common people encounter it, they cannot bear it and will instead invite misfortune. Yet if one assists in governing a bright era, one may remain blameless. Whatever is sought will be obtained, following one’s will.
It is also said: The sun rises in the east,
Illuminating my hundred paths.
Its lingering light extends
Even to the hidden valleys.
Official matters will disperse; the sick will recover; the traveler will return; merchants will profit greatly; marriages will harmonize—this hexagram is a sign of great good fortune.
He says: When the Yellow Bell meets the *zi* hour, the yang qi flourishes.
Gradually, harmony and peace will come—no need for sighs.
All affairs follow the heart; all matters bring joy.
**Explanation says:**
The celestial thoroughfare lies smooth and broad—
the soft cannot overcome the firm.
Riding clouds, mounting dragons—
the position is central and upright.
This divination shows old yin above and below, incapable of action, while three yang reside in the center, firm, bright, and mighty, unstoppable in any direction. Thus it forms the image of the celestial thoroughfare smooth and broad, five paths opening, six ways connecting.
For the one who obtains this, it is fitting to govern the state, pacify the common people, eliminate the cruel, and expel the violent—nothing is impossible.

**Obscured Survival Divination (Faint Survival Hexagram)**
*Four-Four-One*
Breath comes faintly, lingering,
Without strength.
Face upturned, one calls to Heaven;
Head bowed, one cowers low.
Seeking brings no connection;
Seeing brings no attainment.
Yan says: Only a single yang remains,
Sunken beneath the earth.
Bound by yin’s dark veils,
Head bowed, cowering low.
How much life remains?
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.
The sick will be gravely ill; fields and silkworms will yield no profit; on distant journeys, one will encounter bandits.
He says: In all matters, nothing is fitting—
only sighs remain.
In office or private life, one faces slander and disputes,
Deep and hard to clear.
Guard stillness and retreat.
Or travel a thousand *li* to escape disaster.
Official matters are hard to avoid; illness is hard to cure; merchants will lose capital; distant journeys will bring calamity.
Whatever one plans will be unfavorable—
it is fitting to cultivate blessings to avert misfortune.
**Explanation says:**
Breath comes faintly, lingering in servitude,
Head bowed, cowering low—
utter destitution, with none to appeal to.
This divination shows a single yang obscured beneath layers of yin, the image of extreme hardship.
The sick will surely die; battles will be lost; prisoners will not escape; litigants will not prevail—all matters are inauspicious.

**Yin Growth Divination (Middle Suppression Hexagram)**
*Four-Four-Two*
Layers of yin reside above,
Ghostly qi drifts and wanders.
Water pools in the central courtyard;
Boats sail beneath the hall.
Yan says: A hexagram of pure yin,
Inner and outer do not respond.
Disasters of official ghosts all belong to yin.
In all matters, this is an omen of misfortune and decline.
Though inner and outer do not respond,
If official power aids it, it may instead turn auspicious.
A daughter will be born.
He says: The traveler will encounter bandits; in all matters, nothing is favorable.
Yin schemes and slander—
one must be cautious.
It is also called the "Enlightenment Hexagram"—
in small matters, slight good fortune.
**Explanation says:**
Layers of yin reside above—
the Dao of yang is blocked.
Water runs deep in the central courtyard—
fear of drowning.
This divination shows pure yin, the image of misfortune without response.
For the one who obtains this,
Yin people, bandits, and thieves will cause harm.
The sick face great misfortune.
It also portends yin schemes, curses, official ghosts, and slander—
all matters are inauspicious,
Except for seeking rain.

**Worldly Divination (Extreme Hardship Hexagram)**
*Four-Four-Three*
Trapped in misfortune,
One sits alone behind closed doors.
Followers scatter;
There is no way to obtain fire.
Yan says: The yang qi has lost its position,
With none to follow—
Thus it is called "sitting alone."
Fire is yang, the resource of transformation.
The host of yin blocks it—
there is no way to obtain it.
The household faces ruin;
In all matters, nothing goes as desired;
Marriages will have no descendants.
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious—
one must be especially cautious.
The sick will not recover; the traveler will not return.
He says: The sick have no qi; official matters are hard to resolve.
**Explanation says:**
Trapped in misfortune—
yin rides over yang.
No way to obtain fire—
darkness and obscurity.
This divination shows yang losing its position and lacking support,
While yin ascends and its faction flourishes.
For the one who obtains this,
There will be unprovoked disaster—
a greatly inauspicious divination.

**Multitude of Misfortunes Divination (Utmost Peace Hexagram)**
*Four-Four-Four*
Misfortune strikes violently;
In all matters, nothing is favorable.
Illness lingers endlessly;
Every movement brings stumbles.
Yan says: All three positions are yin—
misfortune arrives secretly.
In action or stillness, speech or silence,
Nothing is auspicious.
He says: This hexagram brings a multitude of disasters;
The sick face extreme peril.

Desires unfulfilled, all matters unfavorable.
Proceed with caution—gradually, things will stabilize.
Flowers bloom in frost-laden skies,
A sight of blossoms fills the eye.
Though one exhausts all human effort,
Human affairs remain fickle.

**Explanation says:**
Utmost yin with no yang—
the extreme of exhaustion.
In movement, one stumbles,
No strength can be applied.
This divination shows all three positions as exhausted yin,
A multitude of misfortunes arise,
All endeavors meet obstruction,
One can only await ruin.

**Bitter Endurance Divination (Heavenly Yang Hexagram)**
*One-One-Zero*
Dwelling in poverty, enduring hardship,
No doors or household to call one’s own.
Trapped within narrow paths,
No ground even to plant an awl.

Yan says: Standing apart from the crowd,
One dwells alone in the outer realm.
No inner resonance,
No place to settle.
Poverty and hardship,
Only confinement remains.
This hexagram brings misfortune in all matters.

He says: The dwelling has nothing to rely upon,
Thus it is said: *no ground even to plant an awl.*
The sick face extreme distress,
Desires go unfulfilled,
Official matters are hard to resolve,
Long journeys bring encounters with bandits—
All should cultivate blessings.

**Explanation says:**
Dwelling in poverty, enduring hardship—
No means to establish a home.
Coming and going along narrow paths,
One can only sigh.
This divination shows the upper and middle positions isolated,
With no lower position,
Thus forming the image of destitution and homelessness—
All matters are inauspicious.

**Joyous Harmony Divination (Matched Pair Hexagram)**
*One-Two-Zero*
Husband and wife draw close,
No others intrude.
Sitting knee to knee,
Only joy and contentment.

Yan says: Hard and soft in resonance,
An image of harmony.
This hexagram brings harmony in all matters,
Marriage is most auspicious.

He says: The household is at peace,
All desires are fulfilled.
Every matter follows the heart,
Silkworms and fields yield great harvest—
An omen of great fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Husband and wife draw close—
A proper household.
Knee to knee in joy,
A moment of self-delight.
This divination, though lacking a lower position,
Has yang above and yin in the middle,
Achieving its pairing,
With no one to sow discord.
The household is auspicious,
Marriage most auspicious.
All matters proceed smoothly,
Though only in small affairs—
Great undertakings are not favored.

**Fulfillment Divination (Completion Hexagram)**
*One-Three-Zero*
Abiding in one’s proper place,
Matters align with one’s will.
Set the mind at ease,
Fortune and prosperity arrive in due course.
Celebration and joy abound,
All brings lasting benefit.

Yan says: Three yang in the middle,
Achieving its proper order.
This hexagram brings good fortune in all matters,
The sick suffer no pain,
Those seeking office find ever greater success.

He says: All matters follow the heart,
Marriage is harmonious.
Official matters resolve easily,
The household enjoys wealth and nobility,
Those in office ascend to higher ranks—
All matters are greatly auspicious.

**Explanation says:**
The yang path flourishes,
Abiding in its proper place.
No treachery above or below,
Preserving fortune and benefit.
This divination shows yang in its rightful position—
All matters are auspicious.

**Ghostly Omen Divination (Ghostly Relations Hexagram)**
*One-Four-Zero*
Food will not pass the lips,
Breath will not enter the nose,
The heart and belly are knotted with vexation,
Sleep eludes the night.

Yan says: Soft yin resides within,
Not in harmony with the initial yang,
Thus bringing harm.

He says: The sick face misfortune,
Prisoners find no release.
One should reflect on oneself,
Not blame others.
Overland travel brings encounters with bandits,
Voyages meet wind and fire—
All matters are inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
One yang amidst four yin—
The will cannot flow.
Heart and belly knotted with vexation—
The illness lies within.
This divination shows soft yin occupying the human position,
While a solitary yang stands above,
With no companions,
Above and below out of harmony,
Qi and breath obstructed—
An image of worry and illness.
All matters are inauspicious.
Beware of hidden yin threats,
On journeys, fear wind, water, and bandits.

**Delayed Fortune Divination (Ultimate Benefit Hexagram)**
*Two-One-Zero*
Entrusting matters to others,
Day by day, one awaits their intent.

Up to the present, only now does one attain fine joy.
Though matters linger long, in the end one fulfills their will.

**Yan says:**
Affairs must reverse and intertwine,
Only then will aid arrive.
Entrusting matters to others,
In the end one obtains good fortune.
Yet one’s position is solitary and humble,
Unable to advance on their own—
Thus delay brings goodness.
This hexagram responds slowly but auspiciously.

**He says:**
Using affairs to entrust others,
All accord with the heart’s desire,
Only belatedly,
With external joy and celebration.
The sick suffer from heart and belly ailments, recovery is slow;
Travelers wishing to return meet with obstruction.
Every matter proceeds slowly,
Yet attains its good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Entrusting matters to others,
Seeking without immediate success.
Lingering long, one fulfills their will,
In the end there is attainment.
In this divination, yin and yang are paired,
Yet the middle and lower positions are intertwined and disordered.
One’s position is solitary and humble,
Unable to advance swiftly—
Thus only after long duration does it come through.
In all matters, initial worry gives way to joy,
Ultimately fulfilling what is sought.
One should not act with haste.

---

**Anxiety and Separation Divination (Caution and Vigilance Hexagram)**
*Two-Two-Zero*
Though at peace, still perilous;
Though joyful, still sorrowful.
Ever fearing separation,
Unable to remain together.

**Yan says:**
Two yin face each other in residence,
With no yang position at all.
As if good intentions do not pair,
Ever seeming as if parted.
Marriage is difficult to unite,
For it is pure yin.
In all matters, there is no advantage—
Strictly guard against reckless action.

**He says:**
Desiring separation,
Uncertain of good or ill.
What is sought is hard to obtain;
One’s dwelling should be frugal.
Household members may harbor schemes of hidden yin;
Legal matters remain unresolved;
The sick have not recovered;
Travelers have not returned;
Commerce yields no profit;
Military campaigns meet with no victory—
There is calamity, no joy.

**Explanation says:**
Though at peace, still perilous—
The household is empty.
Ever fearing separation—
Intentions do not align.
This hexagram has two yin residing externally,
With no household—
Thus one is at ease yet unaware of danger.
Moreover, intentions do not pair,
With nothing to rely upon.
Those who obtain this divination
Will not fulfill their desires.
The family’s fortunes dwindle,
Ever burdened with worry that cannot be dispelled.

---

**Central Abundance Divination (Great Completion Hexagram)**
*Two-Three-Zero*
Encountering me at the crossroads,
The carriage rumbles along.
What treasure is this?
Yellow gold and white silver.
Ever ensuring abundance,
Seeking without fear of poverty.

**Yan says:**
Though yin resides above,
Yang dwells in the center.
Intentions respond externally,
Supreme prosperity and blessing.
No fear of poverty—
This hexagram is greatly auspicious.
What is hoped for should be distant,
Then there will be joy and celebration,
Great good fortune.

**He says:**
Either through others’ arrival one obtains goods,
Or by seeking others one gains wealth.
Like the flourishing of the myriad things,
One reaps double abundance.
Seeking office brings harmony;
Travelers gain greatly and return at once.
Legal matters disperse;
The sick recover;
All affairs are greatly auspicious—
Especially suitable for seeking wealth.

**Explanation says:**
Encountering me at the crossroads—
The firm and yielding respond.
The carriage rumbles along—
The position is central and correct.
Seeking without fear of poverty—
Great celebration ensues.
In this divination, all affairs are auspicious.
Only with land and position,
Managing property and establishing enterprises,
Is it not advantageous in one’s hometown,
But advantageous abroad.
In all divinations lacking a lower position,
This is generally the case.

---

**Assisting Peril Divination (Upholding Integrity Hexagram)**
*Two-Four-Zero*
The sagely person is refined,
What form do they take?
Worthy and good respond within,
First weeping, then singing.

**Yan says:**
What sets the sagely person apart from others
Is their cultivation of both refinement and substance—
Only then are they esteemed.
This hexagram brings initial sorrow, then joy.
Seeking to meet the ruler for office and emolument,
There is no beginning, but there is an end.
One version says:
Yesterday, setting out on a journey,
I encountered bandits and soldiers.
A stray arrow struck me,
Both eyes now dim and blurred.

**He says:**
Going out or staying in is inauspicious;
One may meet bandits and soldiers,
Struck by a flying arrow in the eye.
Travelers have not arrived;
The sick are gravely afflicted;
Prisoners are difficult to release.

**Explanation says:**
Going out and encountering misfortune—
Yin occupies the center.
A stray arrow strikes the eye—
The upper position is exhausted.
In this divination, both the upper and middle positions are yin,
With no lower position,
Nor proper pairing—
They harm one another.
Those who obtain this divination
Will be oppressed and violated by petty yin forces.
Travelers worry over bandits;
Legal matters are hard to resolve;
Military campaigns suffer defeat;
Marriages are discordant—
In nearly all matters, there is fault.

---

**Flowing Fortune Divination (Attaining Heaven Hexagram)**
*Three-One-Zero*
Continuously meeting misfortune,
Now one joins with good fortune.
Not merely for a time,
Blessing shall accumulate for generations.

**Yan says:**
Three yang above—
Nothing can invade.
This brings fortune and celebration.
In this hexagram, initially there may be worry,
But afterward, no suffering.
Managing the household brings advantage.
Another version says:
Affairs begin as one wishes,
Office and emolument are then obtained.
Travelers return;
The sick recover;
The household is at peace—
All that is sought is greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Affairs begin with worry,
Then fortune arrives.

**Explanation says:**
Continuously meeting misfortune—
First there is worry.
Now one joins with good fortune—
Ultimately attaining what is sought.
In this hexagram, above and below are both yang,
With no obstruction.
Intentions align, the Way converges—
One may bring about fortune and blessing,
An image of attaining Heaven.
In all matters, initial regret gives way to good fortune.

---

**Late Arrival Divination (Awaiting the Time Hexagram)**
*Three-Two-Zero*
Shouldering the plow to till,
In the fourth month, one lifts their feet.
Diligently hastening with the season,
Millet and sorghum flourish.

**Yan says:**
Yang occupies the upper ranks,
Yin is centered in the correct position—
This is the proper principle.
Planting with the season,
There is much advantage.
In the fourth month, the three yang—
Crops and grains begin to thrive,
Fields and silkworms bring great good fortune.

**He says:**
In all matters, as one wishes,
Only slightly delayed.
After long duration, it comes through.

**Explanation says:**
In all matters, initial worry gives way to joy,
Ultimately fulfilling what is sought.
One should not act with haste.

---

**Anxiety and Separation Divination (Caution and Vigilance Hexagram)**
*Two-Two-Zero*
Though at peace, still perilous;
Though joyful, still sorrowful.
Ever fearing separation,
Unable to remain together.

**Yan says:**
Two yin face each other in residence,
With no yang position at all.
As if good intentions do not pair,
Ever seeming as if parted.
Marriage is difficult to unite,
For it is pure yin.
In all matters, there is no advantage—
Strictly guard against reckless action.

**Yan says:**
Desiring separation, yet not discerning good from ill,
What is sought proves difficult to obtain.
Dwelling places should be guarded against famine.
Within the household, there may be schemes of hidden malice.
Official matters remain unresolved,
The sick have not recovered,
Travelers have not returned,
Commerce yields no profit,
Military campaigns meet no victory—
Only misfortune, no joy.

**Explanation says:**
Though at peace, still perilous—
The household is empty.
Ever fearing separation—
Intentions do not align.
In this hexagram, two yin reside externally,
Without a household to call their own.
Thus, though at ease, one knows not the danger.
Moreover, intentions fail to pair,
With nothing to rely upon.
For the one who draws this divination,
Desires go unfulfilled,
The family’s fortunes dwindle,
And constant worry cannot be dispelled.

---

**Abundance Hexagram (Great Success Divination)**
*Two-Three-Zero*
I meet my fields and paths,
Chariot wheels rumbling.
What treasures do I hold?
Yellow gold and white silver.
Ever ensuring abundance,
Seeking without fear of poverty.

**Yan says:**
Though yin resides above,
Yang dwells within.
Intentions respond to the external—
Primal harmony brings fortune and blessing.
No need to fear poverty;
This hexagram is greatly auspicious.
Aspirations should be set far—
Then joy and celebration will come.
Greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Either receiving goods from visitors,
Or journeying to seek others and gaining wealth.
Like the sprouting of all things,
Yielding double abundance.
Seeking office brings harmony,
Travelers return with great gains.
Legal matters disperse,
The sick recover,
All affairs are greatly auspicious—
Especially fitting for seeking wealth.

**Explanation says:**
Meeting my fields and paths—
Hard and soft respond.
Chariot wheels rumbling—
The position is central and upright.
Seeking without fear of poverty—
Great celebration ensues.
This divination bodes well for all matters.
Yet with earthly positions,
Managing property or establishing enterprises
Brings no advantage at home,
But profit lies abroad.
Few are the divinations of lower rank—
Most follow this pattern.

---

**Upholding Danger Hexagram (Guarding Integrity Divination)**
*Two-Four-Zero*
The sage is refined,
What form does he take?
Worthy and good respond within,
First weeping, then singing.

**Yan says:**
What sets the sage apart from others
Is his balanced refinement of culture and substance—
Only then is he esteemed.
This hexagram brings initial sorrow, then joy.
Seeking office from the ruler,
It begins poorly but ends well.
*Another version states:*
Yesterday, while traveling,
Bandits and soldiers confronted me.
A stray arrow struck my eye,
Leaving both sightless and lost.

**He says:**
Going out brings no fortune,
Or encountering bandits,
Struck in the eye by an arrow.
Travelers have not arrived,
The sick are gravely afflicted,
Prisoners remain unresolved.

**Explanation says:**
Traveling meets with misfortune—
Yin occupies the center.
A stray arrow strikes the eye—
The upper position is exhausted.
In this divination, both upper and middle are yin,
Lacking a lower position,
Nor are they a fitting pair—
They harm one another.
For the one who draws this,
They will be oppressed by petty yin forces.
Travelers fear thieves,
Legal matters are hard to escape,
Military campaigns end in defeat,
Marriages fail to harmonize—
Nearly all affairs bring fault.

---

**Flowing Fortune Hexagram (Heaven’s Favor Divination)**
*Three-One-Zero*
Meeting misfortune again and again,
Now it joins with good fortune.
Not just for a time—
Blessings shall span generations.

**Yan says:**
Three yang above—
Nothing can invade,
Thus bringing fortune and celebration.
This hexagram brings initial worry,
But later no suffering.
Favorable for household affairs.
*Another version states:*
Affairs begin as the heart desires,
Then office and rank are attained.
Travelers return,
The sick recover,
The household is at peace—
All seeking is greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Affairs begin with worry,
Then fortune arrives.

**Explanation says:**
Meeting misfortune again and again—
First there is worry.
Now it joins with good fortune—
Ultimately obtaining what is sought.
This hexagram’s upper and lower are both yang,
Without obstruction.
Intentions align with the Dao,
Bringing fortune and blessing—
Taking the image of Heaven.
All matters bring initial regret, then good fortune.

---

**Timely Action Hexagram (Waiting for the Season Divination)**
*Three-Two-Zero*
Shouldering the plow to till,
In the fourth month, lifting one’s feet.
Diligently seizing the season,
Millet and sorghum flourish.

**Yan says:**
Yang occupies the upper ranks,
Yin holds the central position—
This is the proper principle.
Planting at the right time
Brings great advantage.
In the fourth month, the three yang—
Crops begin to thrive,
Fields and silkworms bring great good fortune.

**He says:**
In all matters, as one wishes,
Only slightly delayed.

**Explanation says:**
Yin follows yang—
The upper position is constant.
Tilling at the proper time—
Fulfilling what is hoped for.
This divination’s three yang hold their positions,
While yin follows—
An image of compliance without opposition.
Yet lacking earthly position,
One must labor diligently and act in season
To reap a harvest.

---

**Harmonizing Virtue Hexagram (Equal Power Divination)**
*Three-Three-Zero*
The enlightened lord above,
Below, no treachery.
Court robes in solemn array,
Great brightness dispels darkness.

**Yan says:**
Above, a wise ruler;
Below, worthy ministers—
Thus no treachery,
And all is in orderly harmony.
This hexagram is greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Initial worry, then good fortune.
Approaching office brings even greater benefit.
Prisoners soon released,
This hexagram brings great fortune in all affairs.

**Explanation says:**
The lord is enlightened, the ministers good—
No treachery.
Court robes in solemn array—
Not fitting for frequent changes.

**Hexagram of All Yang in Ruler-Minister Positions**
*Three-Three-Zero*
Here, all yang occupies the positions of ruler and ministers,
With no yin or petty men to intervene.
This attains the utmost goodness—
All affairs are auspicious.
One should uphold the old,
Not seek change.
Only in divining marriage is it auspicious;
For two marshes, the outcome is unfavorable.

**Hexagram of Certain Gain**
*Three-Four-Zero*
The Han hound pursues the hare,
The flying hawk seizes the pheasant.
No venture fails to yield,
And what is gained is fully reliable.

**Yan says:**
Three yang above,
Resonating within and without—
A hexagram of orderly compliance.
With running hounds and flying hawks,
No pursuit fails to capture.
This hexagram is especially suited for the hunt.

**He says:**
All affairs begin without end,
Legal troubles disperse,
Silkworms and fields yield great harvest.
Yet he adds:
Though aspirations start grand,
They end with minor loss.

**Explanation says:**
The Han hound pursues the hare—
Yang rides over yin.
Such is the capture,
A great taking of game.
This divination is most favorable for
Pursuing fugitives, quelling rebels,
Managing property, or seeking office.

---

**Hexagram of Avenge Shame**
*Four-One-Zero*
A wife brings food to the fields,
Yet no plowing father appears.
A thieving crow, shameless,
Pecks at my dried meat.
I draw my bow and shoot,
Striking its left wing.

**Yan says:**
Yang’s position is solitary and weak,
Obscured by heavy yin—
Affairs suffer harm,
Thus the crow steals the meat.
Yet yang’s nature,
From weakness to strength,
Will ultimately prevail,
Avenge its shame.

**He says:**
This stems from disputes with others,
Breeding private grievances.
The hexagram portends worry:
Travelers meet misfortune,
Silkworms and fields yield little,
All pursuits prove unfavorable,
Marriages fail,
Legal matters remain unresolved.

**Explanation says:**
No plowing father appears—
Veiled by obscuring growth.
Small strength bears heavy burdens,
Inviting banditry and harm.
Shooting the wing,
Though victory comes, it is punitive.
Here, heavy yin rules above,
A lone yang within—
Yet treachery and theft will ultimately be defeated.
In warfare, initial defeat yields later victory.

---

**Hexagram of Inviting Bandits**
*Four-Two-Zero*
Drunken quarrels erupt,
Blades and staves rise together.
The host, seized by terror,
Binds himself to halt the chaos.

**Yan says:**
Dwelling in a position without rank,
Beneath a throng of yin—
Guest and host breach propriety,
Drunken rage sparks strife.
Only when the host humbles himself
Does the turmoil cease.
This hexagram bodes ill,
Gatherings with guests grow dire.

**He says:**
First, verbal strife,
But in the end, no worry.

**Explanation says:**
Drunken quarrels—
The peril of petty men.
The host binds himself,
To evade their edge.
This divination is unfit for action;
Self-preservation is best.

---

**Hexagram of Knowing When to Stop**
*Four-Three-Zero*
Ahead, bandits and thieves;
Behind, travelers approach.
Whether to advance or halt,
One may yet preserve oneself.

**Yan says:**
Three yang dwell together,
Yet hold no position below.
A throng of yin above,
Like bandits lying in wait.
Yet as the three yang begin to flourish,
Calmly stepping forward,
They cannot be harmed.
Though no great fortune comes,
One may yet preserve oneself.
This hexagram favors small journeys.
He adds:
This hexagram lacks a lower position,
Thus no travelers follow behind.

**He says:**
First, verbal strife,
A desire to return home—
One should pause for now,
To avoid calamity.
All affairs bear minor fault;
Do not proceed,
But defer to what comes later.

**Explanation says:**
A throng of yin above—
Bandits lie ahead.
Having an upper but no lower position—
No one follows behind.
Knowing peril and halting,
One may avoid fault.

---

**Hexagram of Urgent Entanglement**
*Four-Four-Zero*
Suspended in urgency like a noose,
No rescue arrives in time.
Even the example of Gaozi of Lu
Cannot compare.

**Yan says:**
Yang’s power and virtue both wane,
A throng of yin grows ever stronger—
An omen of ruin and chaos.
As when Duke Min of Lu was slain,
Cheng Ji fled to Ju’s neighbor,
And in that winter, Gaozi of Qi came to盟,
Pacifying Lu’s turmoil.
This hexagram foretells initial defeat,
Then later fortune.
He adds:
All affairs demand haste;
Delay brings discord.

**He says:**
All matters require swift action,
Not procrastination.
As when Duke Min of Lu was slain,
And Duke Xi, son of Jizi, fled to Ju’s neighbor,
That winter Gaozi came to盟—
The *Zuo Zhuan* notes: "Gaozi acted in concert,"
To quell Lu’s chaos, hence his name was not recorded.
All affairs begin with defeat,
Then end in fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Suspended in urgency—
Like reaching the utmost extremity.
No rescue arrives in time—
Calamity presses close.
The absence of a lower position
Forms the image of high suspension.
Here, a throng of yin ascends,
Inevitably inviting ruin.
Yet one hopes for rescue from others—
A dire predicament.
All divined affairs bear ill omens.

---

**Hexagram of Reverent Caution**
*Zero-One-One*
Illuminating virtue, blocking transgression,
Affairs lie in following the moment’s flow.
The worthy are cautious at the outset,
The noble guard against the subtle.

**Yan says:**
Though the upper position is vacant,
The hexagram is wholly yang—
Sufficient to illuminate its great virtue,
And block all wrongdoing.
He adds:
All affairs should move with the season,
While guarding against the subtle.

**He says:**
All affairs should follow the moment’s flow,
Then one’s aspirations may be fulfilled.
As Zang Xi Bo said in the *Zuo Zhuan*:
"Illuminate virtue, block transgression,
To oversee the hundred officials."
This hexagram is greatly auspicious for approaching office.

**Explanation says:**
Illuminating virtue, blocking transgression—
This lies in following the season.
Caution from beginning to end
Requires guarding against the subtle.
This divination favors knowing the moment,
And acting with uprightness.

---

**Hexagram of the Emperor’s Dao**
*Zero-One-Two*
Heaven and earth share their work,
Yin and yang commune.
Endeavors vast and boundless,
From west to east.
Coming and going, moving and dwelling—
Hard to trace their path.

**Yan says:**
Heaven and earth first commune,
Grasses and trees just begin—
No tracks yet appear.
Requests meet no response,
Travelers have not returned.

**He says:**
Aspirations grand yet hard to achieve,
Beyond measure.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven and earth share their work—
Yin and yang attain harmony.
Endeavors vast and boundless—
Progress knows no limit.
Hard to trace their path—
Beyond reckoning.
This divination is greatly auspicious
For establishing merit and undertaking great deeds.

---

**Hexagram of Indecision**
*Zero-One-Three*
Like a fox, hesitant and wavering,
The mind remains unsettled.

**Hexagram of Hesitation**
*Zero-One-Three*
Advance yields no hope;
Retreat must follow right.
**Yan says:**
Though the superior position is vacant,
The host of yang strive in rivalry—
An image of indecision.
Inner and outer lack response,
Thus hesitation lingers.
To act against reason
Is not as good as retreating to uphold right.

**He says:**
Advance and retreat remain uncertain,
Hard to follow the heart.
Nearly all matters are thus.

**Explanation says:**
Hesitant as a fox,
No path to follow.
Advance yields no hope—
The heart wavers.
Retreat must follow right—
Lest one fall into misfortune.
This hexagram depicts a time without a ruler’s position,
While the host of yang lie below,
Without fixed direction—
Hence the fox’s hesitation.
Yang exists without yin,
Inner and outer lack response.
Thus advance yields no hope;
Better to retreat and follow right.
In divination, stillness brings good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Treacherous Deceit**
*Zero-One-Four*
Defying Heaven, betraying the lord,
Disordering human relations.
Indulgent and treacherous,
All gnash their teeth in rage.

**Yan says:**
Above, no heavenly position;
Within, solitary and weak.
The host of yin usurp command—
Thus arise those who defy and betray,
Treacherous schemers who shun the upright,
Whose words target the good.
Holding office brings greater misfortune;
Litigation lacks reason.

**He says:**
Others blame them,
For their own wantonness—
Hence "gnashing teeth,"
Speaking of deep resentment.
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
A lone yang amid the host of yin—
The minister loses his place.
Petty men run rampant,
None can restrain them.
This divination shows no heavenly position above,
A weak and solitary center below,
While the host of yin ally below,
Acting wantonly—
An image of defying Heaven and betraying the lord.
In divination, nothing is not inauspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Reversal**
*Zero-Two-One*
Above and below inverted,
All affairs lose propriety.
East and west diverge,
No longer following one another.

**Yan says:**
Matters proceed,
Yet none align with the heart—
For yin and yang are misplaced.

What is done brings no benefit;
What is sought finds no harmony.

**He says:**
To advance or act in seeking matters,
Relying on others, all may succeed—
But delay brings fortune.
The sick suffer in the heart and belly,
Recovery will be slow.
Travelers wish to return;
In all things, delay brings good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Above and below are overturned—
The soft overcomes the hard.
East and west diverge—
Hopes are dashed.
This hexagram shows no heavenly position above,
While yin and yang are inverted below.
All affairs are perverse and inauspicious.
The diviner must act with caution.

---

**Hexagram of Primal Virtue**
*Zero-Two-Two*
Deep thought and far-reaching reflection,
Dwelling in peace yet wary of danger.
Though no harm exists now,
Ultimately, collapse and loss will come.
Always follow the right Way;
Beware of deceit and fraud.

**Yan says:**
Pure yin without yang
Cannot ensure lasting good fortune—
Thus danger and defeat appear.
This hexagram brings temporary ease,
But later, blame will come.

**He says:**
In all matters, deep thought and far-reaching reflection are fitting.
Though all is peaceful now,
Ultimately, it will not be favorable.

**Explanation says:**
Soft and weak, resting in ease—
Yet in the end, collapse and loss come,
For there is no master.
Always follow the right Way,
Then one does not lose their place.
This divination shows two yin in alignment below,
With no master above—
A fleeting peace,
Yet ultimately unable to stand firm.
The diviner must uphold rightness
To preserve themselves.
If they act recklessly,
Danger and defeat will surely come.

---

**Hexagram of Vigilance**
*Zero-Two-Three*
Virtue dispels misfortune;
Reverence and caution are fitting.
Though now constrained,
Fortune and emolument will come of themselves.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram transforms its lower yin into yang—
Virtue suffices to dispel misfortune,
Ultimately bringing blessed prosperity.
In all matters, initial small worries
Will later yield great good fortune.

**He says:**
Fortune and emolument will surely come,
Though slightly delayed.
Matters will follow one’s will.

**Explanation says:**
Virtue dispels misfortune—
Yang rises below yin.
Fortune and emolument come of themselves—
Ultimately, the heart’s desire is attained.
This hexagram shows yin and yang misaligned,
Yet the three yang are strong and vigorous,
Yin cannot overcome them—
Thus the image of virtue dispelling misfortune.
Though misfortune may arise at first,
Ultimately, great good fortune comes.
Its power is natural,
Not requiring pursuit.
In divination, all matters are auspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Yin Treachery**
*Zero-Two-Four*
Yin treachery plots rebellion,
Unfavorable for descendants.
Though momentarily content,
Later, no peace will come.

**Yan says:**
Transforming yang into yin—
This is the image of treachery.
Yin treachery schemes harm,
Descendants will dwindle—
Thus "unfavorable for descendants."
In this hexagram, all matters and undertakings
Initially bring good fortune,
But later, harm.

**He says:**
Though matters may now align with one’s wishes,
Later, they will not be auspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Yin treachery plots destruction—
Petty men seize their moment.
Yet in the end, no peace comes—
Ultimately, no refuge remains.
This divination brings initial good fortune,
But later misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Auspicious Encounter**
*Zero-Three-One*
Stepping out, one meets good fortune,
Aligning with the good.
A bright pearl shines at night,
So I am not led astray.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram brings good fortune in all things—
Travelers, merchants, farming, and sericulture
All gain good fortune.
For officials, it brings honor and prominence—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

**He says:**
Having met good fortune,
And illuminated by a bright pearl,
All matters are without misfortune;
All undertakings succeed.

**Explanation says:**
Stepping out, one meets good fortune—
Finding one’s kind.
A bright pearl shines at night—
Though dark, it is not blind.
This divination shows yang finding its kind,
Without losing order.
The three’s firm brightness
Suffices to illuminate the dark—
Truly aligning with the good.
In all matters, good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Peace and Prosperity**
*Zero-Three-Two*
Heaven wanes, earth rests;
The worthy hold their posts.
Journeys return, illness fades—
Boundless benefit, no limit.

**Yan says:**
Yin and yang each hold their place;
The noble remain still and guard themselves.
In all matters, returning to the root brings great good fortune.

**He says:**
What is sought cannot be rushed;
All matters follow the heart—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

**Explanation says:**
The worthy hold their posts—
Positions are proper and constant.
Journeys return, illness fades—
Gains without loss.
In this divination, what is sought
Cannot be rushed—
Then all matters follow the heart,
Bringing good fortune.

**Hexagram of Preserving Life**
*Zero-Three-Three*
The phoenix holds a pearl in its beak,
Alighting in the corner of my courtyard.
Fortune comes to me,
Misfortune is driven away.

**Yan says:**
In an age where the high hold no position,
Only one who governs with pure firmness
Sees the omen of good fortune.
Misfortune dissolves, fortune arrives—
The phoenix, most sacred of omens.
The pearl, a treasure of delight:
All that is sought shall be attained.

**He says:**
Fortune and emolument draw near—
A greatly auspicious and beneficial hexagram.

**Explanation says:**
The phoenix alights in the courtyard—
The radiance of worthy virtue.
Fortune arrives, misfortune departs—
All good converges.
In this divination, nothing is inauspicious,
Save for seeking rain, which thwarts desire.

---

**Hexagram of Upholding Worthiness in Decline**
*Zero-Three-Four*
The noble stand firm,
The petty bow low.
A luminous lord governs the age,
Distinguishing purple from crimson.

**Yan says:**
Abiding in the stability of a weighty position,
They emit the illumination of three yang.
As the *Book of Changes* says:
“This is the time when the petty must not be employed.”
Seeking office brings great fortune;
All other matters attain their proper principle.

**He says:**
A wise ruler presides above,
The noble are employed—
All wishes follow the heart.
The petty submit in lowliness,
As reason dictates.

**Explanation says:**
The noble attain their positions—
The petty submit.
Distinguishing crimson from purple,
Each holds their proper post.
In this hexagram, yin and yang each occupy their rightful place:
Firm brightness shines from above,
While yielding yin follows below.
In divination, matters attain their principle;
Both noble and petty know good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of the Ascending Dragon**
*Zero-Four-One*
The hidden dragon prepares to rise,
Dark clouds gather above.
The world receives blessings—
First adversity, then joy.

**Yan says:**
Though the beginning is inauspicious,
The end brings great fortune.
One yang lies below—
As in the *Book of Changes*, the “hidden dragon” of the first nine,
Poised to ascend as clouds arise.
Welcoming it, they soar together,
Riding the empty sky—
An omen of harmony between lord and minister across the land.

**He says:**
This hexagram begins in adversity but ends in prosperity;
All matters bring good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
The hidden dragon meets the clouds—
Ascending to heaven.
First adversity, then joy—
Advance without hindrance.
This hexagram has no heaven above,
Only one yang beneath four yin—
Thus the image of the hidden dragon meeting clouds.
Though the beginning is fraught with difficulty,
The end brings success—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

---

**Hexagram of Overturning and Prosperity**
*Zero-Four-Two*
The celestial dragon rages,
The thunder lord beats his drum.
Clouds gather, rain descends,
Floodwaters surge across the earth.

**Yan says:**
Pure yin occupies a time without response,
Unable to dispel calamity or avert disaster—
Thus the day when thunder and lightning clash,
And floodwaters bring ruin.
This hexagram brings regret in all matters:
Travelers, marriages, and commerce all meet misfortune.

**He says:**
Rain flows, sweeping all clean—
A hexagram of instability in all matters.

**Explanation says:**
The celestial dragon rages—
Yin rises above.
Floodwaters surge across the earth—
Nothing can withstand them.
In this divination, all undertakings are inauspicious,
Save for seeking rain.

---

**Hexagram of Withdrawing from the World**
*Zero-Four-Three*
The petty gain power,
The noble lose the Way.
Abandoning my halls and home,
I enter the deep grasses.

**Yan says:**
Bright yang virtue retreats to a lowly place,
While dark yin usurps the central position—
An image of worthy men suppressed and stagnant.
Thus they forsake their halls,
Dwelling far away in the marshes and grasses,
Cultivating their resolve in seclusion,
Awaiting their time.
This hexagram favors retreat, not advance.

**He says:**
Overpowered by yin,
They lose their rightful place.

**Explanation says:**
The petty gain power—
Yin overcomes yang.
Entering the deep grasses—
Their position is improper.
In this hexagram, yin and yang are misaligned;
All matters favor retreat and shun advance.

---

**Hexagram of Ghostly Activity**
*Zero-Four-Four*
Two ghosts dwell together,
Ever hungry, ever hollow.
They wish to enter the gate,
But fear this talisman.

**Yan says:**
An image of accumulated yin—
Ghosts are about to bring harm.
With no master for sacrifices,
They are said to be hungry and hollow.
The ghosts dare not approach,
Fearing the talisman.
This hexagram favors reciting scriptures and mantras
To expel malevolent spirits;
Sacrifices bring good fortune.

**He says:**
Fortune departs, misfortune arrives—
One should cultivate merit and virtue,
Perform good deeds to dispel evil.
The sick should inscribe talismans
And recite the *Ruan* incantation to recover.
Fields and silkworms yield meager harvests—
A hexagram of constant hardship.

**Explanation says:**
Two ghosts dwell together—
Yin’s malevolence accumulates.
Fearing this sacred talisman,
They are left with nowhere to go.
In this hexagram, two yin lie below,
With no position above—
No ancestral temple or master for sacrifices,
Thus they are homeless ghosts.
Though the celestial position is empty,
Luminous brightness presides above,
Preventing the ghosts from approaching,
As if a talisman barred their entry.
In divination, all matters meet great hardship;
The sick should be treated with talismans and incantations.

---

**Hexagram of Slight Loss**
*One-Zero-One*
Climbing a tree to pluck mulberry leaves,
I fall to the ground, sprawled and prone.
The eastern neighbor has medicine—
I rush to ask for the prescription.
There I meet a skilled physician,
And escape unbroken, unharmed.

**Yan says:**
Seeking something, one incurs this affliction;
Proceeding further to make amends brings good fortune.
Also:
Yin loses its yin position,
The yang line has no response.
Like ascending high only to fall,
Yet with yang present in the center,
No yin disaster befalls.
Seeking a prescription from the eastern neighbor
Averts injury—
For the east is the beginning of yang,
And supplication brings good fortune.

**He says:**
The sick should return to where the illness began
And make amends—this brings good fortune.
Travelers have not returned;
Legal matters are difficult to resolve.

**Explanation says:**
Climbing a tree, falling to the ground—
Ascending high brings peril.
Asking for the prescription, obtaining medicine—
In the end, no loss is suffered.
In this hexagram, above and below are both yang,
With no yin—
Though disaster strikes, it is not severe.
The east is the beginning of yang,
Thus one seeks the prescription from the eastern neighbor
And finds a physician.
The sick are in distress—
They should return to where they incurred the affliction
And make amends; this brings good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Initial Harmony**
*One-Zero-Two*
Like a newlywed bride,
Unaccustomed to her home.
With diligent effort and self-reliance,
She will bear children in time.

**Yan says:**
Though lacking a central position,
Yin and yang are in harmony,
Inner and outer in accord.

**Like Newlyweds, Harmony Comes Later**
First harmony comes after marriage.
In all matters, when responses align,
One may rely on oneself.
Be vigilant day and night, as if facing peril—
Only then will fortune come.
Illness and official matters bring no suffering;
All affairs turn auspicious.

**He says:**
Marriage begins without harmony but ends in accord.
Trade, business, and all undertakings prosper.
Official matters remain difficult to resolve.

**Explanation says:**
The bride is newly wed, unaccustomed to her home—
Their bond is not yet deep.
With diligent effort and self-reliance,
They build their household.
In this hexagram, yang is above and yin below,
Each in its proper place, yet not yet intimate.
Like a new bride, their connection exists but is not yet profound.
Yet the central position is unobstructed;
Though distant at first, they grow close in time.
Thus, with perseverance and effort, harmony is ultimately achieved.
For matters facing obstacles, one must apply force—
Even in military campaigns, resolution comes in the end.

---

**Hexagram of Barren Soil**
*One-Zero-Three*
The earth is high, the stone unyielding;
One looks up and pleads to heaven.
The plow lies idle, the hoe unused—
The fields stand barren, the crops sparse.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, all is yang,
With no yin qi.
Moisture cannot penetrate;
Plowing and sowing are in vain.

**He says:**
All matters require action—
Seek, and you shall attain.
Without seeking, it is like famine from no plowing,
Or drought from no rain.
Ordinary affairs fare as usual;
Silkworms and fields follow the same pattern.

**Explanation says:**
The earth is high, the stone unyielding—
Hardness without harmony.
Looking up to plead to heaven,
There is nothing to be done.
In this hexagram, three yang lines occupy the earthly positions,
With no yang above and no one in the central place—
Isolated, unable to nurture life.
All matters are hollow;
Labor yields no results.

---

**Hexagram of Malevolent Spirits**
*One-Zero-Four*
Evil spirits dwell in the house,
Sitting in pairs, watching.
They wait for transgressions,
Cutting off water and fire.
Heavenly and earthly spirits
Lie in wait for human faults.

**Yan says:**
Yin and yang are unobstructed,
Yet cannot restrain one another.
The human position is empty,
Leaving nothing to govern the household—
Thus, malevolent spirits fill the space.
This hexagram bodes ill for all matters;
For divining residences or illness, it is especially ominous.

**He says:**
One should perform rites to cultivate blessings and avert misfortune,
And take great care with water and fire.

**Explanation says:**
Evil spirits in the house arise from accumulated yin qi.
Yang is solitary and cut off,
With no one in the central position.
Water and fire are severed—
The human path withers.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters.

---

**Hexagram of Emptiness**
*Two-Zero-One*
Felling trees in water,
Fishing on a mountain.
Wasted effort, lost strength—
Empty hands, hollow words.

**Yan says:**
The human position is vacant,
Heaven and earth inverted.
Attempting deeds or creating things—
All come to naught.
Thus it is said:
Felling trees in water,
Fishing on a mountain—
Nothing is gained.
This hexagram portends great misfortune for marriage,
And illness cannot be cured—
For yin and yang are overturned.

**He says:**
Travelers do not return,
The ill grow gravely worse,
Marriages fail to unite,
Official matters are hard to resolve—
Nothing is favorable.

**Explanation says:**
Felling trees in water defies the proper course.
Empty hands, hollow words—
There is nothing to sustain life.
In this hexagram, yin and yang are inverted,
With no human position—
Like fishing on a mountain or felling trees in water.
What is sought cannot be obtained;
All matters are inauspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Two Widows**
*Two-Zero-Two*
Two women without husbands,
Quarreling, living apart.
They go out and return by different paths,
Dwelling in separate chambers.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, all is yin,
Their wills do not align.
Like two women without husbands,
They inevitably contend.
Residences bring misfortune;
Marriages do not succeed.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters—
Two yin lack a master.

*The Book of Changes* says:
"Two women dwelling together,
Their wills do not harmonize."
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**He says:**
It is as if there is an intent to separate,
Like moving yet not fully moving.

**Explanation says:**
Above and below are two yin—
Women without husbands.
Going out and returning by different paths,
The chamber is empty.
In this hexagram, above and below are both yin,
With no master in the center—
Thus the image of two women without husbands,
Their wills unaligned, dwelling apart.
For the diviner, all matters run counter;
What is sought brings misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Repeated Peril**
*Two-Zero-Three*
Two follow one another,
Seeking to avoid danger.
They encounter calamity and fall into a well—
Strength and effort are in vain.

**Yan says:**
Seeking to evade yin’s harm,
They lose their position.
As if falling into a well in peril,
Hands and feet remain, yet strength cannot be applied.
Nothing is accomplished;
Construction and planning often fail.
Traveling afar is most inauspicious.

**He says:**
Desiring action, there is nowhere to apply force.
What is sought is not obtained;
What is done does not succeed.
For divining illness, it is especially ominous.

**Explanation says:**
Seeking to avoid danger,
Their hearts are suspicious.
Encountering calamity and falling into a well—
How lamentable.
In this hexagram, lesser yin is above,
Firm yang below—
Their wills do not align.
Thus, they begin in suspicion and end in mutual ruin.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters.

---

**Hexagram of Yin’s Depletion**
*Two-Zero-Four*
Frost and snow swirl,
Soaking my robes.
The north wind blows upon me—
I cannot return home.

**Yan says:**
Yin qi prevails,
Within and without, no master.
Adrift in wind and snow,
The path home is lost.
This hexagram brings many faults;
For travelers, it is especially inauspicious.
Seeking office or trade—
Nothing goes as desired.

**He says:**
Nothing is accomplished;
There is slander and flattery—
One must be cautious.

**Explanation says:**
Frost and snow swirl—
Yin qi gathers.
Unable to return home,
There is no household.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters—
Keep far from it.

---

**Hexagram of Futile Effort**
*Three-Zero-One*
Journeying east to gather herbs,
One ascends Mount Tai.
No magic mushrooms are found—
Only fragrant orchids.
Orchids are not urgently needed;
One returns empty-handed.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, pure yang—
They do not respond.
Doubled hardness above,
Like towering mountains.
The central position is discordant—
Difficult to achieve merit.
Seeking herbs and finding orchids—
An image of hollow beauty.

**Matters of Hollow Repute**
