**Yan says:**
Desiring separation, yet not discerning good from ill,
What is sought proves difficult to obtain.
Dwelling places should be guarded against famine.
Within the household, there may be schemes of hidden malice.
Official matters remain unresolved,
The sick have not recovered,
Travelers have not returned,
Commerce yields no profit,
Military campaigns meet no victory—
Only misfortune, no joy.

**Explanation says:**
Though at peace, still perilous—
The household is empty.
Ever fearing separation—
Intentions do not align.
In this hexagram, two yin reside externally,
Without a household to call their own.
Thus, though at ease, one knows not the danger.
Moreover, intentions fail to pair,
With nothing to rely upon.
For the one who draws this divination,
Desires go unfulfilled,
The family’s fortunes dwindle,
And constant worry cannot be dispelled.

---

**Abundance Hexagram (Great Success Divination)**
*Two-Three-Zero*
I meet my fields and paths,
Chariot wheels rumbling.
What treasures do I hold?
Yellow gold and white silver.
Ever ensuring abundance,
Seeking without fear of poverty.

**Yan says:**
Though yin resides above,
Yang dwells within.
Intentions respond to the external—
Primal harmony brings fortune and blessing.
No need to fear poverty;
This hexagram is greatly auspicious.
Aspirations should be set far—
Then joy and celebration will come.
Greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Either receiving goods from visitors,
Or journeying to seek others and gaining wealth.
Like the sprouting of all things,
Yielding double abundance.
Seeking office brings harmony,
Travelers return with great gains.
Legal matters disperse,
The sick recover,
All affairs are greatly auspicious—
Especially fitting for seeking wealth.

**Explanation says:**
Meeting my fields and paths—
Hard and soft respond.
Chariot wheels rumbling—
The position is central and upright.
Seeking without fear of poverty—
Great celebration ensues.
This divination bodes well for all matters.
Yet with earthly positions,
Managing property or establishing enterprises
Brings no advantage at home,
But profit lies abroad.
Few are the divinations of lower rank—
Most follow this pattern.

---

**Upholding Danger Hexagram (Guarding Integrity Divination)**
*Two-Four-Zero*
The sage is refined,
What form does he take?
Worthy and good respond within,
First weeping, then singing.

**Yan says:**
What sets the sage apart from others
Is his balanced refinement of culture and substance—
Only then is he esteemed.
This hexagram brings initial sorrow, then joy.
Seeking office from the ruler,
It begins poorly but ends well.
*Another version states:*
Yesterday, while traveling,
Bandits and soldiers confronted me.
A stray arrow struck my eye,
Leaving both sightless and lost.

**He says:**
Going out brings no fortune,
Or encountering bandits,
Struck in the eye by an arrow.
Travelers have not arrived,
The sick are gravely afflicted,
Prisoners remain unresolved.

**Explanation says:**
Traveling meets with misfortune—
Yin occupies the center.
A stray arrow strikes the eye—
The upper position is exhausted.
In this divination, both upper and middle are yin,
Lacking a lower position,
Nor are they a fitting pair—
They harm one another.
For the one who draws this,
They will be oppressed by petty yin forces.
Travelers fear thieves,
Legal matters are hard to escape,
Military campaigns end in defeat,
Marriages fail to harmonize—
Nearly all affairs bring fault.

---

**Flowing Fortune Hexagram (Heaven’s Favor Divination)**
*Three-One-Zero*
Meeting misfortune again and again,
Now it joins with good fortune.
Not just for a time—
Blessings shall span generations.

**Yan says:**
Three yang above—
Nothing can invade,
Thus bringing fortune and celebration.
This hexagram brings initial worry,
But later no suffering.
Favorable for household affairs.
*Another version states:*
Affairs begin as the heart desires,
Then office and rank are attained.
Travelers return,
The sick recover,
The household is at peace—
All seeking is greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Affairs begin with worry,
Then fortune arrives.

**Explanation says:**
Meeting misfortune again and again—
First there is worry.
Now it joins with good fortune—
Ultimately obtaining what is sought.
This hexagram’s upper and lower are both yang,
Without obstruction.
Intentions align with the Dao,
Bringing fortune and blessing—
Taking the image of Heaven.
All matters bring initial regret, then good fortune.

---

**Timely Action Hexagram (Waiting for the Season Divination)**
*Three-Two-Zero*
Shouldering the plow to till,
In the fourth month, lifting one’s feet.
Diligently seizing the season,
Millet and sorghum flourish.

**Yan says:**
Yang occupies the upper ranks,
Yin holds the central position—
This is the proper principle.
Planting at the right time
Brings great advantage.
In the fourth month, the three yang—
Crops begin to thrive,
Fields and silkworms bring great good fortune.

**He says:**
In all matters, as one wishes,
Only slightly delayed.

**Explanation says:**
Yin follows yang—
The upper position is constant.
Tilling at the proper time—
Fulfilling what is hoped for.
This divination’s three yang hold their positions,
While yin follows—
An image of compliance without opposition.
Yet lacking earthly position,
One must labor diligently and act in season
To reap a harvest.

---

**Harmonizing Virtue Hexagram (Equal Power Divination)**
*Three-Three-Zero*
The enlightened lord above,
Below, no treachery.
Court robes in solemn array,
Great brightness dispels darkness.

**Yan says:**
Above, a wise ruler;
Below, worthy ministers—
Thus no treachery,
And all is in orderly harmony.
This hexagram is greatly auspicious.

**He says:**
Initial worry, then good fortune.
Approaching office brings even greater benefit.
Prisoners soon released,
This hexagram brings great fortune in all affairs.

**Explanation says:**
The lord is enlightened, the ministers good—
No treachery.
Court robes in solemn array—
Not fitting for frequent changes.

chunks.original_text: 此课群阳居君臣之位，无阴小人间也。 得其至善矣，几事皆吉。 宜守旧，不宜更改。 惟占婚姻吉，两泽则不如意。 必得课攸利卦　　三四○ 韩卢逐兔，飞鹰搏雉。 无往不得，所获足恃。 颜云：三阳在上，内外相应，顺序之卦也。 走犬飞鹰，无往不获，此卦尤宜畋猎。 何云：万事无始有终，官事散，田蚕大收。 又曰：志虽初大，终后小失。 解曰：韩卢逐兔，阳乘阴也。 其获如此，大得禽也。 此课大宜捕亡、讨贼、治产、求官。 雪耻课负乘卦　　四一○ 妇饷入田，不见耕父，盗乌无状，啄我乾脯。 挽弓射之，中其左羽。 颜云：阳位孤微，重阴所蔽，事有伤害，故曰盗乌啄脯。 然阳之为体，自微至着，终当克捷，以雪其耻。 何云：因与人物，以致私憾。 此卦有忧，远行人凶，田蚕微收，所求不利，婚姻不成，官事未解。 解曰：不见耕父，蒙荟翳也。 力小任重，致寇害也。 射之中羽，虽克亦惩也。 此课重阴居上，孤阳中，奸盗终必败获。 出师先败后胜也。 致寇课通遏卦　　四二○ 醉酒喧争，刀仗并起。 主人惶怖，自缚乃止。 颜云：处无位之地，群阴之下，宾主失礼，醉怒喧争，主人自卑，然后得止。 此卦多咎，会客弥凶。 何云：初有口舌，后终无忧也。 解曰：醉酒喧争，小人之凶。 主人自缚，避其锋也。 此课不宜行事，自保可也。 戒违课知止卦　　四三○ 前者寇盗，后有行人。 安行止住，可得全身。 颜云：三阳共居，下无其位。 群阴在上，如寇贼之在前。 然三阳始盛，安步直往，终不能害。 虽无吉庆，庶可全身。 此卦游行小吉。 又云：此卦无下位，故日后无行人。 何云：初有口舌，欲还乡里，宜且暂停，乃得免患。 百事小咎，不宜行往，几事宜向后。 解曰：群阴在上，前有寇也。 有上无下，无人在后也。 知难而止，可无咎也。 被绞课宜速卦　　四四○ 悬急如绞，救不来至。 鲁望高子，不足为比。 颜云：阳德俱消，群阴浸盛，败乱之象。 若鲁闵公遇弒，成季以莒适邻，其年冬齐高子来盟，遂平鲁乱，此卦先败而后吉。 又云：几事宜速，悠悠即不谐合。 何云：几事皆宜速救，不宜迟晚。 如鲁闵公遇弒，季子僖公以莒适邻，其年冬高子来盟，注云高子俱也，平鲁乱之故，不书名。 几事先败后吉。 解曰：悬急，如穷之极也。 救不来至，祸之亟也。 无下位救为高悬之象。 此课群阴上行，必致败乱，而望救於他人，困之甚也。 占事皆凶象。 敬慎课昭得卦　　○一一 昭德塞违，事在顺机。 贤者谨始，君子防微。 颜云：其上虽无，而卦皆阳，足以昭其盛德、塞彼非违。 又曰：几事宜顺时而动，兼须防微。 何云：几事宜顺机，而后得志。 《左传》臧僖伯云：昭德塞违，以照临百官。 此卦临官大吉。 解曰：昭德塞违，在顺时也。 慎终于始，必防微也。 此课宜知机识时，以行公正之事。 帝道课德至卦　　○一二 天地同功，阴阳相通。 事业广大，从西至东。 行来去处，难可蹈踪。 颜云：天地初通，草木方始，未示踪也。 所求难应，行人未回。 何云：志大难成，不可量也。 解曰：天地同功，阴阳得也。 事业广大，进未极也。 难蹈其踪，不可测也。 此课立功立事大吉。 不定课狐疑卦　　○一三 狐疑犹豫，意中不定。

**Hexagram of All Yang in Ruler-Minister Positions**
*Three-Three-Zero*
Here, all yang occupies the positions of ruler and ministers,
With no yin or petty men to intervene.
This attains the utmost goodness—
All affairs are auspicious.
One should uphold the old,
Not seek change.
Only in divining marriage is it auspicious;
For two marshes, the outcome is unfavorable.

**Hexagram of Certain Gain**
*Three-Four-Zero*
The Han hound pursues the hare,
The flying hawk seizes the pheasant.
No venture fails to yield,
And what is gained is fully reliable.

**Yan says:**
Three yang above,
Resonating within and without—
A hexagram of orderly compliance.
With running hounds and flying hawks,
No pursuit fails to capture.
This hexagram is especially suited for the hunt.

**He says:**
All affairs begin without end,
Legal troubles disperse,
Silkworms and fields yield great harvest.
Yet he adds:
Though aspirations start grand,
They end with minor loss.

**Explanation says:**
The Han hound pursues the hare—
Yang rides over yin.
Such is the capture,
A great taking of game.
This divination is most favorable for
Pursuing fugitives, quelling rebels,
Managing property, or seeking office.

---

**Hexagram of Avenge Shame**
*Four-One-Zero*
A wife brings food to the fields,
Yet no plowing father appears.
A thieving crow, shameless,
Pecks at my dried meat.
I draw my bow and shoot,
Striking its left wing.

**Yan says:**
Yang’s position is solitary and weak,
Obscured by heavy yin—
Affairs suffer harm,
Thus the crow steals the meat.
Yet yang’s nature,
From weakness to strength,
Will ultimately prevail,
Avenge its shame.

**He says:**
This stems from disputes with others,
Breeding private grievances.
The hexagram portends worry:
Travelers meet misfortune,
Silkworms and fields yield little,
All pursuits prove unfavorable,
Marriages fail,
Legal matters remain unresolved.

**Explanation says:**
No plowing father appears—
Veiled by obscuring growth.
Small strength bears heavy burdens,
Inviting banditry and harm.
Shooting the wing,
Though victory comes, it is punitive.
Here, heavy yin rules above,
A lone yang within—
Yet treachery and theft will ultimately be defeated.
In warfare, initial defeat yields later victory.

---

**Hexagram of Inviting Bandits**
*Four-Two-Zero*
Drunken quarrels erupt,
Blades and staves rise together.
The host, seized by terror,
Binds himself to halt the chaos.

**Yan says:**
Dwelling in a position without rank,
Beneath a throng of yin—
Guest and host breach propriety,
Drunken rage sparks strife.
Only when the host humbles himself
Does the turmoil cease.
This hexagram bodes ill,
Gatherings with guests grow dire.

**He says:**
First, verbal strife,
But in the end, no worry.

**Explanation says:**
Drunken quarrels—
The peril of petty men.
The host binds himself,
To evade their edge.
This divination is unfit for action;
Self-preservation is best.

---

**Hexagram of Knowing When to Stop**
*Four-Three-Zero*
Ahead, bandits and thieves;
Behind, travelers approach.
Whether to advance or halt,
One may yet preserve oneself.

**Yan says:**
Three yang dwell together,
Yet hold no position below.
A throng of yin above,
Like bandits lying in wait.
Yet as the three yang begin to flourish,
Calmly stepping forward,
They cannot be harmed.
Though no great fortune comes,
One may yet preserve oneself.
This hexagram favors small journeys.
He adds:
This hexagram lacks a lower position,
Thus no travelers follow behind.

**He says:**
First, verbal strife,
A desire to return home—
One should pause for now,
To avoid calamity.
All affairs bear minor fault;
Do not proceed,
But defer to what comes later.

**Explanation says:**
A throng of yin above—
Bandits lie ahead.
Having an upper but no lower position—
No one follows behind.
Knowing peril and halting,
One may avoid fault.

---

**Hexagram of Urgent Entanglement**
*Four-Four-Zero*
Suspended in urgency like a noose,
No rescue arrives in time.
Even the example of Gaozi of Lu
Cannot compare.

**Yan says:**
Yang’s power and virtue both wane,
A throng of yin grows ever stronger—
An omen of ruin and chaos.
As when Duke Min of Lu was slain,
Cheng Ji fled to Ju’s neighbor,
And in that winter, Gaozi of Qi came to盟,
Pacifying Lu’s turmoil.
This hexagram foretells initial defeat,
Then later fortune.
He adds:
All affairs demand haste;
Delay brings discord.

**He says:**
All matters require swift action,
Not procrastination.
As when Duke Min of Lu was slain,
And Duke Xi, son of Jizi, fled to Ju’s neighbor,
That winter Gaozi came to盟—
The *Zuo Zhuan* notes: "Gaozi acted in concert,"
To quell Lu’s chaos, hence his name was not recorded.
All affairs begin with defeat,
Then end in fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Suspended in urgency—
Like reaching the utmost extremity.
No rescue arrives in time—
Calamity presses close.
The absence of a lower position
Forms the image of high suspension.
Here, a throng of yin ascends,
Inevitably inviting ruin.
Yet one hopes for rescue from others—
A dire predicament.
All divined affairs bear ill omens.

---

**Hexagram of Reverent Caution**
*Zero-One-One*
Illuminating virtue, blocking transgression,
Affairs lie in following the moment’s flow.
The worthy are cautious at the outset,
The noble guard against the subtle.

**Yan says:**
Though the upper position is vacant,
The hexagram is wholly yang—
Sufficient to illuminate its great virtue,
And block all wrongdoing.
He adds:
All affairs should move with the season,
While guarding against the subtle.

**He says:**
All affairs should follow the moment’s flow,
Then one’s aspirations may be fulfilled.
As Zang Xi Bo said in the *Zuo Zhuan*:
"Illuminate virtue, block transgression,
To oversee the hundred officials."
This hexagram is greatly auspicious for approaching office.

**Explanation says:**
Illuminating virtue, blocking transgression—
This lies in following the season.
Caution from beginning to end
Requires guarding against the subtle.
This divination favors knowing the moment,
And acting with uprightness.

---

**Hexagram of the Emperor’s Dao**
*Zero-One-Two*
Heaven and earth share their work,
Yin and yang commune.
Endeavors vast and boundless,
From west to east.
Coming and going, moving and dwelling—
Hard to trace their path.

**Yan says:**
Heaven and earth first commune,
Grasses and trees just begin—
No tracks yet appear.
Requests meet no response,
Travelers have not returned.

**He says:**
Aspirations grand yet hard to achieve,
Beyond measure.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven and earth share their work—
Yin and yang attain harmony.
Endeavors vast and boundless—
Progress knows no limit.
Hard to trace their path—
Beyond reckoning.
This divination is greatly auspicious
For establishing merit and undertaking great deeds.

---

**Hexagram of Indecision**
*Zero-One-Three*
Like a fox, hesitant and wavering,
The mind remains unsettled.

No treachery.

Not fitting for frequent changes.

chunks.original_text: 进不可希，退宜从正。 颜云：其上虽无，众阳趁兢，未定之象，内外无应，故犹豫也。 昧理而行，不如退而守正。 何云：进退不定，难得从心，几事皆如此。 解曰：狐疑犹豫，莫适从也。 进不可希，心憧憧也。 退宜从正，无入干凶也。 此卦当无君位之时，而众阳在下，无所定向，故为狐疑犹豫。 有阳无阴，内外无应，故进不可希，不如退而从正也。 占事守静则吉。 邪佞课阴疑卦　　○一四 违天背君，不顺伦理。 放恣邪佞，人皆切齿。 颜云：上无天位，中又孤弱，群阴擅命，故有违背邪佞之徒，亚弯直忌正，言及善人。 临官弥凶，词讼无理。 何云：人又责之，由身放恣，故曰切齿，言怨恨深也。 此卦大凶。 解曰：孤阳群阴，臣失所也。 小人放恣，莫能御也。 此课上无天位，中有寡弱，而群阴下比，恣意而行，违天背君之象，占事无所不凶。 慎悔课有违卦　　○二一 上下倒反，事皆失宜。 东西乖角，不相追随。 颜云：事有攸往，铃不从心，阴阳错位故也。 所为无益，所求不谐。 何云：进用求事，托人皆得，少迟有庆。 病者在腹心，瘥缓。 行人欲回，每事迟则吉。 解曰：上下反侧，柔尚刚也。 东西乖角，失所望也。 此课上无天位，而阴阳又颠倒于下，诸事皆反逆凶，占者慎保。 初德课临坎卦　　○二二 深思远念，居安虑危。 今虽无患，终必倾亏。 常为正道，慎勿诈欺。 颜云：纯阴无阳，不能保其终吉，故叉见危败。 此卦初偷安，后必见咎。 何云：几事并宜深思远虑，今虽平善，后终不利也。 解曰：柔懦而安处也，终铃倾亏，无主也。 常行正道，则不失所也。 此课二阴相比于下，而上无主，苟安目下，而终不能自立。 占者守正，可以保己。 若有妄动，必至危败。 福会课兢谨卦　　○二三 德禳不祥，敬慎宜尊。 今虽隐约，福禄自臻。 颜云：此卦变其下阴成阳，德足以禳去不祥，终至福祚也。 几事皆先小忧，后获大吉。 何云：福禄必至，但少迟耳，事得从必。 解曰：德禳不祥，阳下阴也。 福禄自臻，终获其心也。 此课阴阳虽失位，而三阳刚盛，阴不能胜，故为德禳不祥之象。 始虽有凶，终获大吉。 其势自然，不待求也。 占事皆吉。 阴贼课盛阴卦　　○二四 阴贼逆谋，不利后代。 虽暂适意，后亦不泰。 颜云：变阳为阴，乃贼之象也。 阴贼谋害，后嗣将微，故日不利后代也。 此卦几事及经营，初获吉，后有害。 何云：几事纵今如意，后亦不吉。 解曰：阴贼谋戕，小人得时也。 终亦不泰，卒无所归也。 此课谋事初吉，后凶。 利禄课元亨卦　　○三一 出门逢福，与善相得。 明珠夜照，使我不惑。 颜云：此卦事事皆吉，行人、市贾、田蚕，并获吉利。 仕宦荣显，大吉之卦。 何云：既与福会，又为明珠所照，百事无不吉利，所作皆通。 解曰：出门逢福，得其与也。 明珠夜照，虽幽不瞽也。 此课阳得其类，而不失序。 三之刚明，足以照烛幽暗，可谓与善相得者矣。 几事皆吉。 福祥课安泰卦　　○三二 天消地息，贤人安职。 行返病除，有利无极。 颜云：阴阳各安其位，君子静而自守，几事归本大吉。 何云：所求不可速，万事从心，大吉之卦。 解曰：贤人安职，位正常也。 行反病除，有得无丧也。 此课所求，不可速，则万事从心，吉。

**Hexagram of Hesitation**
*Zero-One-Three*
Advance yields no hope;
Retreat must follow right.
**Yan says:**
Though the superior position is vacant,
The host of yang strive in rivalry—
An image of indecision.
Inner and outer lack response,
Thus hesitation lingers.
To act against reason
Is not as good as retreating to uphold right.

**He says:**
Advance and retreat remain uncertain,
Hard to follow the heart.
Nearly all matters are thus.

**Explanation says:**
Hesitant as a fox,
No path to follow.
Advance yields no hope—
The heart wavers.
Retreat must follow right—
Lest one fall into misfortune.
This hexagram depicts a time without a ruler’s position,
While the host of yang lie below,
Without fixed direction—
Hence the fox’s hesitation.
Yang exists without yin,
Inner and outer lack response.
Thus advance yields no hope;
Better to retreat and follow right.
In divination, stillness brings good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Treacherous Deceit**
*Zero-One-Four*
Defying Heaven, betraying the lord,
Disordering human relations.
Indulgent and treacherous,
All gnash their teeth in rage.

**Yan says:**
Above, no heavenly position;
Within, solitary and weak.
The host of yin usurp command—
Thus arise those who defy and betray,
Treacherous schemers who shun the upright,
Whose words target the good.
Holding office brings greater misfortune;
Litigation lacks reason.

**He says:**
Others blame them,
For their own wantonness—
Hence "gnashing teeth,"
Speaking of deep resentment.
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
A lone yang amid the host of yin—
The minister loses his place.
Petty men run rampant,
None can restrain them.
This divination shows no heavenly position above,
A weak and solitary center below,
While the host of yin ally below,
Acting wantonly—
An image of defying Heaven and betraying the lord.
In divination, nothing is not inauspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Reversal**
*Zero-Two-One*
Above and below inverted,
All affairs lose propriety.
East and west diverge,
No longer following one another.

**Yan says:**
Matters proceed,
Yet none align with the heart—
For yin and yang are misplaced.

What is done brings no benefit;
What is sought finds no harmony.

**He says:**
To advance or act in seeking matters,
Relying on others, all may succeed—
But delay brings fortune.
The sick suffer in the heart and belly,
Recovery will be slow.
Travelers wish to return;
In all things, delay brings good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Above and below are overturned—
The soft overcomes the hard.
East and west diverge—
Hopes are dashed.
This hexagram shows no heavenly position above,
While yin and yang are inverted below.
All affairs are perverse and inauspicious.
The diviner must act with caution.

---

**Hexagram of Primal Virtue**
*Zero-Two-Two*
Deep thought and far-reaching reflection,
Dwelling in peace yet wary of danger.
Though no harm exists now,
Ultimately, collapse and loss will come.
Always follow the right Way;
Beware of deceit and fraud.

**Yan says:**
Pure yin without yang
Cannot ensure lasting good fortune—
Thus danger and defeat appear.
This hexagram brings temporary ease,
But later, blame will come.

**He says:**
In all matters, deep thought and far-reaching reflection are fitting.
Though all is peaceful now,
Ultimately, it will not be favorable.

**Explanation says:**
Soft and weak, resting in ease—
Yet in the end, collapse and loss come,
For there is no master.
Always follow the right Way,
Then one does not lose their place.
This divination shows two yin in alignment below,
With no master above—
A fleeting peace,
Yet ultimately unable to stand firm.
The diviner must uphold rightness
To preserve themselves.
If they act recklessly,
Danger and defeat will surely come.

---

**Hexagram of Vigilance**
*Zero-Two-Three*
Virtue dispels misfortune;
Reverence and caution are fitting.
Though now constrained,
Fortune and emolument will come of themselves.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram transforms its lower yin into yang—
Virtue suffices to dispel misfortune,
Ultimately bringing blessed prosperity.
In all matters, initial small worries
Will later yield great good fortune.

**He says:**
Fortune and emolument will surely come,
Though slightly delayed.
Matters will follow one’s will.

**Explanation says:**
Virtue dispels misfortune—
Yang rises below yin.
Fortune and emolument come of themselves—
Ultimately, the heart’s desire is attained.
This hexagram shows yin and yang misaligned,
Yet the three yang are strong and vigorous,
Yin cannot overcome them—
Thus the image of virtue dispelling misfortune.
Though misfortune may arise at first,
Ultimately, great good fortune comes.
Its power is natural,
Not requiring pursuit.
In divination, all matters are auspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Yin Treachery**
*Zero-Two-Four*
Yin treachery plots rebellion,
Unfavorable for descendants.
Though momentarily content,
Later, no peace will come.

**Yan says:**
Transforming yang into yin—
This is the image of treachery.
Yin treachery schemes harm,
Descendants will dwindle—
Thus "unfavorable for descendants."
In this hexagram, all matters and undertakings
Initially bring good fortune,
But later, harm.

**He says:**
Though matters may now align with one’s wishes,
Later, they will not be auspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Yin treachery plots destruction—
Petty men seize their moment.
Yet in the end, no peace comes—
Ultimately, no refuge remains.
This divination brings initial good fortune,
But later misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Auspicious Encounter**
*Zero-Three-One*
Stepping out, one meets good fortune,
Aligning with the good.
A bright pearl shines at night,
So I am not led astray.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram brings good fortune in all things—
Travelers, merchants, farming, and sericulture
All gain good fortune.
For officials, it brings honor and prominence—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

**He says:**
Having met good fortune,
And illuminated by a bright pearl,
All matters are without misfortune;
All undertakings succeed.

**Explanation says:**
Stepping out, one meets good fortune—
Finding one’s kind.
A bright pearl shines at night—
Though dark, it is not blind.
This divination shows yang finding its kind,
Without losing order.
The three’s firm brightness
Suffices to illuminate the dark—
Truly aligning with the good.
In all matters, good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Peace and Prosperity**
*Zero-Three-Two*
Heaven wanes, earth rests;
The worthy hold their posts.
Journeys return, illness fades—
Boundless benefit, no limit.

**Yan says:**
Yin and yang each hold their place;
The noble remain still and guard themselves.
In all matters, returning to the root brings great good fortune.

**He says:**
What is sought cannot be rushed;
All matters follow the heart—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

**Explanation says:**
The worthy hold their posts—
Positions are proper and constant.
Journeys return, illness fades—
Gains without loss.
In this divination, what is sought
Cannot be rushed—
Then all matters follow the heart,
Bringing good fortune.

**Explanation says:**

chunks.original_text: 攸叔课保命卦　　○三三 凤凰衔珠，集我庭隅。 福为我至，祸为我除。 颜云：上当无位之世，独能以纯刚御之，吉祥之兆也。 祸消福至，凤凰至灵之瑞。 珠者，宝玩之物也，所求皆得。 何云：福禄方至，大吉利也。 解曰：凤凰集庭，贤德辉也。 福至祸除，众善归也。 此课占者无所不利，惟求雨而违所欲矣。 否倾课用贤卦　　○三四 君子抗衡，小人低躯。 明君治世，分别紫朱。 颜云：处重地之安，吐三阳之照。 《易》曰：小人勿用之时。 求官大吉，余事皆得其理也。 何云：明主在上，君子得用，所愿从心，小人低伏，理宜然也。 解曰：君子得位，小人服也。 分别朱紫，各安职也。 此课阴阳各安其位，刚明上照，而柔阴下从。 占事得理，君子小人皆吉。 未刑课龙升卦　　○四一 潜龙将升，玄云上起。 天下蒙祉，先否后喜。 颜云：初虽不佳，后乃大吉。 一阳在下，《易》初九潜龙，将升而云起。 迎之共飞，虚空以御，天下君臣相得之兆也。 何云：此卦初否后泰，几事皆吉。 解曰：潜龙得云，以上天也。 先否后喜，往无前也。 此课上无天而一阳，四阴接之，故为潜龙得云之象。 初虽艰难，后乃克济，大吉之课也。 荡覆课泰过卦　　○四二 天龙暴怒，雷公击鼓。 兴云致雨，流潦下土。 颜云：以纯阴而居无应之时，不能消灾却患，故日雷电相击、水潦为灾。 此卦百事悔吝，行人、婚姻、市贾，皆不利。 何云：雨流荡涤，几事不定之卦。 解曰：天龙暴怒，阴上兴也。 流潦下土，物莫能胜也。 此课古事皆凶，惟宜求雨。 避世课不吉卦　　○四三 小人得志，君子失道。 弃我室庐，入彼深草。 颜云：以明阳之德，退居卑下，而阴暗之徒，反居中位，贤良屈滞之象。 故弃其栋宇，远居草泽，幽居养志，以待其时。 此卦宜退，不宜进。 何云：为阴所凌，失其正位。 解曰：小人得志，阴乘阳也。 入彼深草，位不当也。 此卦阴阳失位，几事退吉进凶。 鬼动课用卫卦　　○四四 两鬼共居，常若饥饥虚。 欲入门户，畏此神符。 颜云：积阴之象，鬼将为害。 祭祀 无主，故曰饥虚。 鬼不敢来，畏有神符。 此卦宜书诵呢，以除邪鬼，祭祀获吉。 何云：福去祸来，宜修功德，作善除邪。 病者宜书符，诵阮治之即瘥。 田蚕薄收，王常之卦。 解曰：两鬼共居，积阴慝也。 畏此灵符，穷无适也。 此卦二阴居下，而无上位，无宗庙祭祀之主，是为无依之鬼。 天位虽虚，而高明在上，鬼不能往，犹有灵符禁之，不得入门户也。 占事大困，病者宜以符呢治之。 微损课求安卦　　一○一 登树探桑，堕地仆僵。 东邻有药，走往问方。 因遇良医，得不折伤。 颜云：所向取物，固此得病，更往前处，谢之吉。 又云：阴失阴位，阳爻无应。 如升高堕地，然已有阳在中，无阴灾。 求方於东邻，得免损伤。 盖东者，阳之始，请之吉。 何云：病者宜往得病处，谢之吉。 行人未回，官事难解。 解曰：登木仆地，升高而危也。 ，问方得药，终不亏也。 此课上下皆阳，而无阴，虽灾不重。 东者，阳始也。 故求方於东邻，而得医也。 病者困，所向取物而得，更前处谢之，吉。 初谐课始安卦　　一○二 如新娶妇，居家未熟。 眼勉自力，方有子息。 颜云：虽无中位，阴阳相得，内外相应。

**Hexagram of Preserving Life**
*Zero-Three-Three*
The phoenix holds a pearl in its beak,
Alighting in the corner of my courtyard.
Fortune comes to me,
Misfortune is driven away.

**Yan says:**
In an age where the high hold no position,
Only one who governs with pure firmness
Sees the omen of good fortune.
Misfortune dissolves, fortune arrives—
The phoenix, most sacred of omens.
The pearl, a treasure of delight:
All that is sought shall be attained.

**He says:**
Fortune and emolument draw near—
A greatly auspicious and beneficial hexagram.

**Explanation says:**
The phoenix alights in the courtyard—
The radiance of worthy virtue.
Fortune arrives, misfortune departs—
All good converges.
In this divination, nothing is inauspicious,
Save for seeking rain, which thwarts desire.

---

**Hexagram of Upholding Worthiness in Decline**
*Zero-Three-Four*
The noble stand firm,
The petty bow low.
A luminous lord governs the age,
Distinguishing purple from crimson.

**Yan says:**
Abiding in the stability of a weighty position,
They emit the illumination of three yang.
As the *Book of Changes* says:
“This is the time when the petty must not be employed.”
Seeking office brings great fortune;
All other matters attain their proper principle.

**He says:**
A wise ruler presides above,
The noble are employed—
All wishes follow the heart.
The petty submit in lowliness,
As reason dictates.

**Explanation says:**
The noble attain their positions—
The petty submit.
Distinguishing crimson from purple,
Each holds their proper post.
In this hexagram, yin and yang each occupy their rightful place:
Firm brightness shines from above,
While yielding yin follows below.
In divination, matters attain their principle;
Both noble and petty know good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of the Ascending Dragon**
*Zero-Four-One*
The hidden dragon prepares to rise,
Dark clouds gather above.
The world receives blessings—
First adversity, then joy.

**Yan says:**
Though the beginning is inauspicious,
The end brings great fortune.
One yang lies below—
As in the *Book of Changes*, the “hidden dragon” of the first nine,
Poised to ascend as clouds arise.
Welcoming it, they soar together,
Riding the empty sky—
An omen of harmony between lord and minister across the land.

**He says:**
This hexagram begins in adversity but ends in prosperity;
All matters bring good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
The hidden dragon meets the clouds—
Ascending to heaven.
First adversity, then joy—
Advance without hindrance.
This hexagram has no heaven above,
Only one yang beneath four yin—
Thus the image of the hidden dragon meeting clouds.
Though the beginning is fraught with difficulty,
The end brings success—
A greatly auspicious hexagram.

---

**Hexagram of Overturning and Prosperity**
*Zero-Four-Two*
The celestial dragon rages,
The thunder lord beats his drum.
Clouds gather, rain descends,
Floodwaters surge across the earth.

**Yan says:**
Pure yin occupies a time without response,
Unable to dispel calamity or avert disaster—
Thus the day when thunder and lightning clash,
And floodwaters bring ruin.
This hexagram brings regret in all matters:
Travelers, marriages, and commerce all meet misfortune.

**He says:**
Rain flows, sweeping all clean—
A hexagram of instability in all matters.

**Explanation says:**
The celestial dragon rages—
Yin rises above.
Floodwaters surge across the earth—
Nothing can withstand them.
In this divination, all undertakings are inauspicious,
Save for seeking rain.

---

**Hexagram of Withdrawing from the World**
*Zero-Four-Three*
The petty gain power,
The noble lose the Way.
Abandoning my halls and home,
I enter the deep grasses.

**Yan says:**
Bright yang virtue retreats to a lowly place,
While dark yin usurps the central position—
An image of worthy men suppressed and stagnant.
Thus they forsake their halls,
Dwelling far away in the marshes and grasses,
Cultivating their resolve in seclusion,
Awaiting their time.
This hexagram favors retreat, not advance.

**He says:**
Overpowered by yin,
They lose their rightful place.

**Explanation says:**
The petty gain power—
Yin overcomes yang.
Entering the deep grasses—
Their position is improper.
In this hexagram, yin and yang are misaligned;
All matters favor retreat and shun advance.

---

**Hexagram of Ghostly Activity**
*Zero-Four-Four*
Two ghosts dwell together,
Ever hungry, ever hollow.
They wish to enter the gate,
But fear this talisman.

**Yan says:**
An image of accumulated yin—
Ghosts are about to bring harm.
With no master for sacrifices,
They are said to be hungry and hollow.
The ghosts dare not approach,
Fearing the talisman.
This hexagram favors reciting scriptures and mantras
To expel malevolent spirits;
Sacrifices bring good fortune.

**He says:**
Fortune departs, misfortune arrives—
One should cultivate merit and virtue,
Perform good deeds to dispel evil.
The sick should inscribe talismans
And recite the *Ruan* incantation to recover.
Fields and silkworms yield meager harvests—
A hexagram of constant hardship.

**Explanation says:**
Two ghosts dwell together—
Yin’s malevolence accumulates.
Fearing this sacred talisman,
They are left with nowhere to go.
In this hexagram, two yin lie below,
With no position above—
No ancestral temple or master for sacrifices,
Thus they are homeless ghosts.
Though the celestial position is empty,
Luminous brightness presides above,
Preventing the ghosts from approaching,
As if a talisman barred their entry.
In divination, all matters meet great hardship;
The sick should be treated with talismans and incantations.

---

**Hexagram of Slight Loss**
*One-Zero-One*
Climbing a tree to pluck mulberry leaves,
I fall to the ground, sprawled and prone.
The eastern neighbor has medicine—
I rush to ask for the prescription.
There I meet a skilled physician,
And escape unbroken, unharmed.

**Yan says:**
Seeking something, one incurs this affliction;
Proceeding further to make amends brings good fortune.
Also:
Yin loses its yin position,
The yang line has no response.
Like ascending high only to fall,
Yet with yang present in the center,
No yin disaster befalls.
Seeking a prescription from the eastern neighbor
Averts injury—
For the east is the beginning of yang,
And supplication brings good fortune.

**He says:**
The sick should return to where the illness began
And make amends—this brings good fortune.
Travelers have not returned;
Legal matters are difficult to resolve.

**Explanation says:**
Climbing a tree, falling to the ground—
Ascending high brings peril.
Asking for the prescription, obtaining medicine—
In the end, no loss is suffered.
In this hexagram, above and below are both yang,
With no yin—
Though disaster strikes, it is not severe.
The east is the beginning of yang,
Thus one seeks the prescription from the eastern neighbor
And finds a physician.
The sick are in distress—
They should return to where they incurred the affliction
And make amends; this brings good fortune.

---

**Hexagram of Initial Harmony**
*One-Zero-Two*
Like a newlywed bride,
Unaccustomed to her home.
With diligent effort and self-reliance,
She will bear children in time.

**Yan says:**
Though lacking a central position,
Yin and yang are in harmony,
Inner and outer in accord.

chunks.original_text: 如人新婚，后始和谐。 几事相应，即可自力。 乾乾夕惕，若厉方吉。 病及官事无苦，几事皆吉。 何云：婚姻无始有终，市贾、经营，百事皆吉。 官事难成。 解曰：娶妇未熟，情未洽也。 电勉自力，成家业也。 此课阳上阴下，各得其位，而不相亲。 如娶妇然，情虽相通而未浃洽也。 然而其中位无阻，虽远终近，故电勉自力，卒能谐和。 占事弥阻，须用力，出军终以解和。 不耕课中虚卦　　一○三 土高石坚，仰面诉天。 未耜不举，禾稼缺然。 颜云：内外皆阳，中无阴气。 润泽不通，耕褥绝理。 何云：凡事要当，求之即遂。 若不求，则犹类不耕则饥，不雨则旱。 几事平常，田蚕亦尔。 解曰：土高石坚，刚而不和也。 仰面诉天，无如之何也。 此课三阳居地位，而无一阳在上，而中位无人，隔绝不能生物。 占事皆虚，劳而无成也。 鬼灾课虚耗卦　　一○四 家有恶鬼，两两对坐。 伺候过失，断水绝火。 天神地只，专候人过。 颜云：阴阳无隔，不相制御，人位既空，无以主家，故使厉鬼实烦也。 此卦百事不吉，卜宅占病尤凶。 何云：宜修福禳祸，兼宜慎诸水火。 解曰：家有恶鬼，积阴气也。 高阳孤绝，无中位也。 水火断绝，人道瘁也。 此课百事不吉。 空亡课失望卦　　二○一 入水伐木，登山捕鱼。 损工失力，手空口虚。 颜云：人位既阕，天地反覆。 立功造事，皆不成。 遂故曰，入水伐木，登山捕鱼，终不获也。 此卦婚姻大凶，病者不救，阴阳颠倒故也。 何云：行人不至，病者至重，婚姻不合，官事难散，百事未宜。 解曰：入水伐木，违所行也。 手空口虚，无以为生也。 此课阴阳反覆，而无人位，有登山捕鱼入水伐木之象。 言其铃不可得，诸事皆凶。 不谐课两寡卦　　二○二 两女无夫，斗争别居。 出入异路，分处室庐。 颜云：内外俱阴，志不相合。 犹二女无夫，理致争斗。 居宅弥凶，婚姻不成。 此卦百事不吉，二阴无主故也。 《易》曰：二女同居，志不相得。 此卦大凶。 何云：如有分别之意，状如移住，而不尽移故也。 解曰：上下二阴，有女无夫也。 出入异路，室中虚也。 此课上下俱阴，而中无主，故取两女无夫，志不相合，而分别居室之象。 占者百事皆违，所求凶。 习坎课虚劳卦　　二○三 二人相随，欲行避危。 逢难落井，筋力无施。 颜云：欲避阴害，致失其位。 若遭难落井，手足空存，筋力靡运。 几事不成，修营多不称意，远行最凶。 何云：欲有所为，无处施力。 所求不得，所作不成，占病弥凶。 解曰：欲行避危，心相疑也。 逢难落井，亦可悲也。 此课少阴在上，刚阳居下，志不相得，故始相疑而卒俱陷。 此课百事皆凶。 来革课阴耗卦　　二○四 霜雪霏霏，沾我裳衣。 北风吹我，不得旅归。 颜云：阴气弥盛，内外无主。 风雪飘泊，归路杳然。 此卦多咎，行人尤凶。 求官、市易，皆不称心。 何云：几事不遂，有口舌谗谀，切宜慎之。 解曰：霜雪霏霏，阴气集也。 不得旅归，无家室也。 此课百事皆凶，远而恶之。 无功课力卦　　三○一 东行采药，乃上泰山。 不得芝草，但见芳兰。 兰非急用，空手而还。 颜云：内外纯阳，不相应也。 重刚在上，山岳之象。 中位不协，难以立功。 探药得兰，虚美之象。
chunks.translated_text:
**Like Newlyweds, Harmony Comes Later**
First harmony comes after marriage.
In all matters, when responses align,
One may rely on oneself.
Be vigilant day and night, as if facing peril—
Only then will fortune come.
Illness and official matters bring no suffering;
All affairs turn auspicious.

**He says:**
Marriage begins without harmony but ends in accord.
Trade, business, and all undertakings prosper.
Official matters remain difficult to resolve.

**Explanation says:**
The bride is newly wed, unaccustomed to her home—
Their bond is not yet deep.
With diligent effort and self-reliance,
They build their household.
In this hexagram, yang is above and yin below,
Each in its proper place, yet not yet intimate.
Like a new bride, their connection exists but is not yet profound.
Yet the central position is unobstructed;
Though distant at first, they grow close in time.
Thus, with perseverance and effort, harmony is ultimately achieved.
For matters facing obstacles, one must apply force—
Even in military campaigns, resolution comes in the end.

---

**Hexagram of Barren Soil**
*One-Zero-Three*
The earth is high, the stone unyielding;
One looks up and pleads to heaven.
The plow lies idle, the hoe unused—
The fields stand barren, the crops sparse.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, all is yang,
With no yin qi.
Moisture cannot penetrate;
Plowing and sowing are in vain.

**He says:**
All matters require action—
Seek, and you shall attain.
Without seeking, it is like famine from no plowing,
Or drought from no rain.
Ordinary affairs fare as usual;
Silkworms and fields follow the same pattern.

**Explanation says:**
The earth is high, the stone unyielding—
Hardness without harmony.
Looking up to plead to heaven,
There is nothing to be done.
In this hexagram, three yang lines occupy the earthly positions,
With no yang above and no one in the central place—
Isolated, unable to nurture life.
All matters are hollow;
Labor yields no results.

---

**Hexagram of Malevolent Spirits**
*One-Zero-Four*
Evil spirits dwell in the house,
Sitting in pairs, watching.
They wait for transgressions,
Cutting off water and fire.
Heavenly and earthly spirits
Lie in wait for human faults.

**Yan says:**
Yin and yang are unobstructed,
Yet cannot restrain one another.
The human position is empty,
Leaving nothing to govern the household—
Thus, malevolent spirits fill the space.
This hexagram bodes ill for all matters;
For divining residences or illness, it is especially ominous.

**He says:**
One should perform rites to cultivate blessings and avert misfortune,
And take great care with water and fire.

**Explanation says:**
Evil spirits in the house arise from accumulated yin qi.
Yang is solitary and cut off,
With no one in the central position.
Water and fire are severed—
The human path withers.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters.

---

**Hexagram of Emptiness**
*Two-Zero-One*
Felling trees in water,
Fishing on a mountain.
Wasted effort, lost strength—
Empty hands, hollow words.

**Yan says:**
The human position is vacant,
Heaven and earth inverted.
Attempting deeds or creating things—
All come to naught.
Thus it is said:
Felling trees in water,
Fishing on a mountain—
Nothing is gained.
This hexagram portends great misfortune for marriage,
And illness cannot be cured—
For yin and yang are overturned.

**He says:**
Travelers do not return,
The ill grow gravely worse,
Marriages fail to unite,
Official matters are hard to resolve—
Nothing is favorable.

**Explanation says:**
Felling trees in water defies the proper course.
Empty hands, hollow words—
There is nothing to sustain life.
In this hexagram, yin and yang are inverted,
With no human position—
Like fishing on a mountain or felling trees in water.
What is sought cannot be obtained;
All matters are inauspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Two Widows**
*Two-Zero-Two*
Two women without husbands,
Quarreling, living apart.
They go out and return by different paths,
Dwelling in separate chambers.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, all is yin,
Their wills do not align.
Like two women without husbands,
They inevitably contend.
Residences bring misfortune;
Marriages do not succeed.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters—
Two yin lack a master.

*The Book of Changes* says:
"Two women dwelling together,
Their wills do not harmonize."
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**He says:**
It is as if there is an intent to separate,
Like moving yet not fully moving.

**Explanation says:**
Above and below are two yin—
Women without husbands.
Going out and returning by different paths,
The chamber is empty.
In this hexagram, above and below are both yin,
With no master in the center—
Thus the image of two women without husbands,
Their wills unaligned, dwelling apart.
For the diviner, all matters run counter;
What is sought brings misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Repeated Peril**
*Two-Zero-Three*
Two follow one another,
Seeking to avoid danger.
They encounter calamity and fall into a well—
Strength and effort are in vain.

**Yan says:**
Seeking to evade yin’s harm,
They lose their position.
As if falling into a well in peril,
Hands and feet remain, yet strength cannot be applied.
Nothing is accomplished;
Construction and planning often fail.
Traveling afar is most inauspicious.

**He says:**
Desiring action, there is nowhere to apply force.
What is sought is not obtained;
What is done does not succeed.
For divining illness, it is especially ominous.

**Explanation says:**
Seeking to avoid danger,
Their hearts are suspicious.
Encountering calamity and falling into a well—
How lamentable.
In this hexagram, lesser yin is above,
Firm yang below—
Their wills do not align.
Thus, they begin in suspicion and end in mutual ruin.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters.

---

**Hexagram of Yin’s Depletion**
*Two-Zero-Four*
Frost and snow swirl,
Soaking my robes.
The north wind blows upon me—
I cannot return home.

**Yan says:**
Yin qi prevails,
Within and without, no master.
Adrift in wind and snow,
The path home is lost.
This hexagram brings many faults;
For travelers, it is especially inauspicious.
Seeking office or trade—
Nothing goes as desired.

**He says:**
Nothing is accomplished;
There is slander and flattery—
One must be cautious.

**Explanation says:**
Frost and snow swirl—
Yin qi gathers.
Unable to return home,
There is no household.
This hexagram is inauspicious for all matters—
Keep far from it.

---

**Hexagram of Futile Effort**
*Three-Zero-One*
Journeying east to gather herbs,
One ascends Mount Tai.
No magic mushrooms are found—
Only fragrant orchids.
Orchids are not urgently needed;
One returns empty-handed.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, pure yang—
They do not respond.
Doubled hardness above,
Like towering mountains.
The central position is discordant—
Difficult to achieve merit.
Seeking herbs and finding orchids—
An image of hollow beauty.

chunks.translated_text:
**Matters of Hollow Repute**
*Three-Zero-One*
All affairs bear names without substance—
Hearing joy, one feels no joy;
Hearing sorrow, one feels no sorrow.

**He says:**
Marching troops meet no fortune;
All pursuits fall short of desire.

**Explanation says:**
Seeking herbs and finding orchids—
Beauty without substance.
Returning empty-handed—
A cause for shame.
This hexagram has three yang above,
An image of towering mountains.
Within and without, pure yang—
Yet the center holds no position, no resonance.
Thus, hollow beauty yields no effect.
Merit is difficult to establish;
One must not act.

---

**Hexagram of Rain Disaster and Hardship**
*Three-Zero-Two*
Ceaseless downpours,
Floodwaters surge to the heavens.
People dwell in nests,
Without fire or kinship.

**Yan says:**
Within and without, the lines are correct,
But the central position is empty.
Yin and yang clash—
Thus, rain falls without end.
Above, three lines—
An image of nest-dwelling.
This hexagram brings manifold faults;
All undertakings grow more ominous.

**He says:**
An image of impending chaos—
Nothing goes as it should.

**Explanation says:**
Floodwaters surge to the heavens—
Yin qi grows long.
Dwelling in nests without kinship—
Strife stirs above.
This hexagram has three yang above,
While lesser yin lengthens below.
The center lacks a master—
Thus, desire manifests as rain and flood.
Yang rules above,
Yet cannot make a home—
An image of nest-dwelling without fire.
To the diviner, this portends misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Rain Disaster and Exhaustion**
*Three-Zero-Three*
Scorching drought brings calamity—
Heaven and earth parched.
One pleads to the dragon above,
Seeks springs below.
Anxious and fearful,
All are unsettled.

**Yan says:**
Heaven and earth are both yang—
An image of extreme yang.
Pleading to the dragon, seeking springs—
Yet nothing stirs.
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious;
Fields and silkworms yield no profit.

**He says:**
Drought and scorching bring disaster—
Above, no benevolent moisture;
Below, resentment festers.
Nothing comes to fruition.
Marriage, wealth-seeking, construction—
All are unfavorable.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven and earth are both yang,
Without a human position.
Solitary yang cannot generate—
Thus, disaster and drought arise.
In divination, nothing succeeds.

---

**Hexagram of Distant Pursuit and Flight**
*Three-Zero-Four*
Chasing fugitive bandits,
One reaches Lelang.

chunks.original_text: 故我宝玉，牵我牛羊。 颜云：天地相应，阴阳有位。 故远赴海表，明扬九代。 但中路无主，宝玉牛羊，未免归於贼。 此卦小吉。 几征伐有克，乐浪在东海。 何云：或取人物，以致不利，急解谢即吉。 或室中物，不应取而取之，亦不吉也。 解曰：追寇捕亡，往成伐也。 乃至乐浪，劳远出也。 牵我牛羊，得故物也。 此课阴阳有位而相应，然无中位，故为被寇，有所亡失之象，必勤远伐而后待之。 占者劳力，而后有成，用兵先难而后胜。 盗劫课牵系卦　　四○一 盗人珍宝，欲为己有。 人斜其奸，鬼缚其肘。 颜云：阴据天位，阳反在下。 犹小人而乘君子之器，而人鬼交责也。 何云：病者由取人物，致有有今祸，急求与之。 兼慎口舌，此卦大凶。 解曰：盗人珍宝，鬼缚，莫能有也。 亦可丑也。 人纠此课以不一阴居天位，非所当居之，盗也。 阳虽孤弱，非我所能奄而有也。 故至人鬼交伐，而无所逃。 占事皆凶，惟捕盗则必获。 失律课败咎卦　　四○二 违道逆理，阴阳相伤。 皇天不佑，反受其殃。 颜云：阴窃阳位，故曰违逆。 几事顺理则吉，逆理则凶。 何云：占病难治，官事不散，闻讼者伤，军行失律，市贾不利。 解曰：违道逆理，位不当也。 阴阳相伤，不久长也。 此课以至阴居上位，违道也。 而中位无人，下位非应，虽一时窃据，而中有殃祸也。 占事皆凶。 奸党课抑贤卦　　四○三 进枉退直，不得其职。 贤人伏藏，君子叹息。 颜云：阴进阳退，故曰失职。 贤人君子，不得任用，故曰伏藏而叹息也。 语云：举直措诸枉，则民服。 举枉措诸直，则民不服。 何云：百事不遂，宜退身行正。 公言不从，则随时为吉也。 君子凶，小人吉。 解曰：进枉退直，倒置也。 小人得时，君子避也。 此课群阴窃据，而阳处于下，远不相亲，故为进枉退直、贤人伏藏之象。 几事宜退，守正则吉。 口舌课耗吉卦　　四○四 东家娶妇，西邻会客。 缚堵啾啾，打犬咋咋。 谨戒祸患，免成外厄。 颜云：事起於会一，集其堂中勿预之，吉。 或有娶妇之礼则吉，聚会同好故也。 何云：内外位敌，东家虽有聚妇之美，西邻向能会客。 二家烹犬打褚，用相夸竞，徒营计较，并有口舌。 又云：此卦斗争及官事婚姻，并输物乃吉。 病者宜修福，此卦平平。 解曰：娶妇会客，内外敌也。 竟而不禳，必有厄也。 此课上下俱至阴，其体相敌，彼娶妇而此会客，竟为欢宴，自恣而无禁也。 小人之情，乐极必淫，而忧生也。 故能戒馑则可免祸，不然必争斗横逆之事，占者慎之。 未明课天元卦　　一○○ 元气初生，万物未形。 光明未融，出入冥冥。 始欲运立，百事不成。 颜云：一者，万物之初也，阳气初生，未能光明。 肇於一爻，以求众象。 几事迟留，未能称遂。 何云：作事不成，病者自瘥，万事皆平，所求未能成也。 解曰：元气初生，未有与也。 出入冥冥，幽不可堵也。 此卦求事不成，凡百平平。 迁流课至微卦　　二○○ 自天立象、气尚浮游。 未能审定，东西迁流。 颜云：自一至二，步数方滋，然基迹始兴。 人道未立，故使迁流，未能有定，悠悠漫漫之象也。 未能遂意。 何云：人事未定，不成之兆也。 解曰：自天立象，其道微也。 东迁西流，未成基也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Hexagram of Reclaiming Lost Treasures**
*Three-Zero-Five*
Thus, my treasured jade is reclaimed,
My cattle and sheep are led back.

**Yan says:**
Heaven and earth correspond,
Yin and yang hold their positions.
Thus, one journeys far to the seas,
Illuminating and exalting nine generations.
Yet on the road, there is no master—
The treasured jade, cattle, and sheep
Inevitably fall to bandits.
This hexagram is slightly auspicious.
For military campaigns, there is victory;
Lelang lies in the Eastern Sea.

**He says:**
If one seizes others’ possessions,
It will bring misfortune.
Hasten to return them, and it will be auspicious.
Or if household items are taken when they should not be,
This, too, is inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Pursuing bandits and capturing fugitives
Is a journey to achieve conquest.
Reaching Lelang
Is the toil of a distant expedition.
Leading back my cattle and sheep
Is reclaiming what was lost.
This divination shows yin and yang in their proper positions, responding to one another,
Yet lacking a central position—
Thus, it bears the image of being robbed,
Of suffering loss.
One must exert effort in a distant campaign before awaiting success.
The diviner labors first, then achieves;
In warfare, there is initial hardship, then victory.

---

**Hexagram of Thieves and Bonds**
*Four-Zero-One*
Thieves seize precious treasures,
Desiring to make them their own.
People expose their deceit,
Ghosts bind their arms.

**Yan says:**
Yin occupies heaven’s position,
While yang is cast below—
Like petty men usurping the vessels of gentlemen,
Drawing the censure of both men and spirits.

**He says:**
If illness arises from seizing others’ possessions,
Hasten to return them.
Guard against gossip;
This hexagram is greatly inauspicious.

**Explanation says:**
Thieves seize precious treasures,
But ghosts bind them—
They cannot possess them.
This, too, is shameful.
This divination arises from a single yin residing in heaven’s position,
Where it does not belong—
This is theft.
Though yang is solitary and weak,
It is not something we can suddenly claim.
Thus, men and spirits both strike,
And there is no escape.
All divined matters are inauspicious,
Except for capturing thieves, which will surely succeed.

---

**Hexagram of Military Defeat and Calamity**
*Four-Zero-Two*
Defying the Dao, violating principle,
Yin and yang wound one another.
August Heaven offers no protection—
Instead, one reaps disaster.

**Yan says:**
Yin usurps yang’s position,
Thus, it is called defiance and rebellion.
In all matters, following principle brings auspiciousness;
Violating principle brings misfortune.

**He says:**
Illness is difficult to cure,
Legal matters do not resolve,
Those who hear lawsuits are harmed,
Military campaigns lose discipline,
Merchants profit little.

**Explanation says:**
Defying the Dao, violating principle—
Positions are improper.
Yin and yang wound one another—
This cannot endure.
This divination arises from extreme yin occupying the upper position,
Defying the Dao.
With no human position in the center
And no correspondence below,
Though it may usurp for a time,
Disaster lurks within.
All divined matters are inauspicious.

---

**Hexagram of Cliques and the Suppression of Worthies**
*Four-Zero-Three*
The crooked advance, the upright retreat,
Failing to hold their rightful posts.
Worthy men hide in seclusion,
Gentlemen sigh in despair.

**Yan says:**
Yin advances, yang retreats—
Thus, it is called loss of office.
Worthy men and gentlemen
Cannot be employed,
So they hide in seclusion and sigh.
As the saying goes:
“Promote the upright, set them above the crooked,
And the people will submit.
Promote the crooked, set them above the upright,
And the people will not submit.”

**He says:**
Nothing succeeds;
It is best to withdraw and act with integrity.
If public words go unheeded,
Adapting to the times brings auspiciousness.
Gentlemen meet misfortune,
Petty men meet good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
The crooked advance, the upright retreat—
This is inversion.
Petty men seize the moment,
Gentlemen withdraw.
This divination shows a host of yin usurping power,
While yang is relegated below,
Far from intimacy—
Thus, it bears the image of the crooked advancing, the upright retreating,
Worthy men hiding in seclusion.
In all matters, it is best to retreat;
Holding to integrity brings auspiciousness.

---

**Hexagram of Verbal Strife and Auspicious Expenditure**
*Four-Zero-Four*
The eastern household takes a bride,
The western neighbor hosts a feast.
With clamor and clatter, they bind the swine,
With yelps and barks, they beat the dogs.
Be vigilant against misfortune,
To avoid external calamity.

**Yan says:**
Matters arise from a single gathering;
Do not partake in their hall—
This is auspicious.
Or if there is a wedding rite, it is auspicious,
For it is a gathering of like-minded friends.

**He says:**
Inner and outer positions are evenly matched:
Though the eastern household has the joy of a bride,
The western neighbor can still host a feast.
The two families slaughter dogs and beat swine,
Vying in extravagance,
Futilely scheming and comparing—
Both will face verbal strife.
It is also said:
This hexagram brings disputes, legal matters, and marriages—
Only by yielding possessions will it be auspicious.
For the ill, performing good deeds is advised.
This hexagram is middling.

**Explanation says:**
Taking a bride, hosting a feast—
Inner and outer are evenly matched.
If they compete without expiation,
Calamity will surely follow.
This divination shows both upper and lower as extreme yin,
Their forms evenly matched.
One household takes a bride, the other hosts a feast,
Competing in revelry,
Indulging without restraint—
This is the nature of petty men:
Joy reaches its peak, then turns to excess,
And sorrow arises.
Thus, if one can exercise restraint, misfortune may be avoided;
Otherwise, disputes and violent conflicts will ensue.
The diviner must be cautious.

---

**Hexagram of the Unmanifest**
*One-Zero-Zero*
Primordial qi first stirs,
The myriad things are yet unformed.
Light has not yet merged,
Entrance and exit are shrouded in darkness.
Just as it begins to move and take shape,
Nothing comes to fruition.

**Yan says:**
One is the beginning of the myriad things,
Yang qi first stirs,
Yet light has not yet emerged.
It originates from a single line,
Seeking the multitude of forms.
In all matters, there is delay;
Nothing can be swiftly accomplished.

**He says:**
Affairs do not succeed,
The ill recover on their own,
All matters are middling,
Desires remain unfulfilled.

**Explanation says:**
Primordial qi first stirs,
Yet nothing accompanies it.
Entrance and exit are shrouded in darkness—
Profound and unfathomable.
This hexagram shows that affairs do not succeed;
All matters are middling.

---

**Hexagram of Transience and Subtlety**
*Two-Zero-Zero*
From heaven, images are established,
Qi still drifts and wanders.
Unable to settle,
It flows east and west.

**Yan says:**
From one to two, the steps begin to multiply,
Yet the foundation’s traces have just emerged.
The human path is not yet established—
Thus, it drifts and flows,
Unable to find stability,
An image of aimless wandering.
Desires cannot be fulfilled.

**He says:**
Human affairs are unsettled—
An omen of incompletion.

**Explanation says:**
From heaven, images are established—
Its Dao is subtle.
Flowing east and west—
No foundation is laid.
chunks.overlap_context:
no profit.

**He says:**
Drought and scorching bring disaster—
Above, no benevolent moisture;
Below, resentment festers.
Nothing comes to fruition.
Marriage, wealth-seeking, construction—
All are unfavorable.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven and earth are both yang,
Without a human position.
Solitary yang cannot generate—
Thus, disaster and drought arise.
In divination, nothing succeeds.

---

**Hexagram of Distant Pursuit and Flight**
*Three-Zero-Four*
Chasing fugitive bandits,
One reaches Lelang.

chunks.original_text: 此课人事未定，求事不成。 未宁课有象卦　　三○○ 天地立形，人乃化生。 随气上下，不能自宁。 颜云：君臣混杂，未有定所。 任其去留，无相拘制。 此卦虽无大咎，凡事不谐。 何云：凡事必有所困，未能从心耳。 解曰：天地立形、生物初也。 随气上下，未定居也。 此课稍有所向，未可强为也。 死象课无气卦　　四○○ 人生有死，鬼气乃兴。 四时俱备，寒暑相承。 沉蔽不显，其体阴凝。 颜云：上有重阴，下无阳位，此为死象。 夫死者与造化隔绝，阴阳乖殊，四时易变。 病者益忧，其体幽阴，鬼也象也。 何云：暮年将老，众鬼复来，凶之兆也。 解曰：重阴冥冥，在上穷也。 阳气微塞，人道终也。 沉蔽不显，何其凶也。 此课占病必死，几事皆凶。 发阳课天光卦　　○一○ 天光覆下，日月发明。 万物云为，有足皆行。 颜云：一阳独明，故曰天光。 万物所生，必资日月。 此卦几事虽小难，终亦有望。 何云：几事宜自筹量，不可全信他人乃吉。 解曰：天光覆下，人道亨也。 有足皆行，无幽明也。 此课一阳居中，日月光明之象，人物之所资。 以求事，可望而迟。 岁登课二阳卦　　○二○ 天地开通，万物皆隆。 事方决定，岁中大丰。 颜云：此卦亦犹上卦，天地播植之功，大致丰盛。 此卦小吉。 何云：几事迟吉，不宜速得，而自为正，百自皆然。 解曰：人道将泰也。 此课一至二，渐多去之象，求事以渐可也。 人事课三阳卦　　○三○ 人事方起，吉无不利。 居者得福，行者必至。 颜云：三阳居中，人道始兴。 虽无应援，终致大吉。 何云：几事所来，皆得通达，行者必依期而还。 解曰：人事方起，阳正中也。 吉无不利，大有终也。 此课三阳出地，建寅之月，人事方起之时。 天地交泰，吉无不利也。 保身课盛阴卦　　○四○ 鬼气未成，厉毒未形。 保慎性命，门户安宁。 颜云：中位人象，故曰鬼气未成。 然处阴弱之位，又无交接。 宜慎保退，密不可为。 鬼厉所侵，有为即败，不能吉也。 何云：宜自保身，安静可也。 解曰：鬼气未成，无相与也。 保慎性命，宜安处也。 此课阴处阳位，而无据凭也。 占者馑慎，退密以保身则无咎。 化育课保有卦　　○○一 明明上天，照临下土。 化育群生，开发门户。 事皆豁然，更相瞻睹。 颜云：地得配天，必有光泽，下润群萌，以致长大者也。 何云：凡事从心而稽缓，此卦无咎。 解曰：上天照临，以发生也。 更相瞻暗，物莫不荣也。 此课阳来居於地位，是为上天照临之象。 占事始达而未大，无咎也。 地利课安厚卦　　○○二 本立事定，人物齐正。 饮清食甘，各保性命。 颜云：天一地二，故本既立矣。 人物因之，各正性命，几事小吉。 何云：得之小迟，彼未长也，万事咸吉之象。 解曰：本立事定，地道成也。 饮清食甘，各保性命也。 此课求事，有始终吉。 建候课坤成卦　　○○三 事兴功起，英雄基趾。 圣贤救世，法令得理。 颜云：三阳处下位，兴功立事之象。 创造基趾，非英雄无以克成，故能明法救世。 此卦百事皆成，行人亦吉。 何云：几事有人言，助其断割也。 解曰：事兴功起，阳道立也。 圣贤救世，进以成业也。 此课三阳在地位，建基立业，刚健足以有为，而无沮挠之者。

**Hexagram of Unsettled Affairs**
*Three-Zero-Zero*
Heaven and earth establish forms,
And humans are transformed into life.
Following qi’s ascent and descent,
They cannot find peace.

**Yan says:**
Rulers and ministers are intermingled,
With no fixed abode.
Left to come and go freely,
No restraint binds them.
Though this hexagram bears no great fault,
All matters remain discordant.

**He says:**
In all affairs, there must be obstruction—
Desires cannot be fulfilled.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven and earth establish forms—
This is the inception of life.
Following qi’s ascent and descent—
No settled dwelling is found.
This hexagram suggests some direction,
But one must not force action.

---

**Hexagram of Death’s Image**
*Four-Zero-Zero*
Humans are born to die,
And ghostly qi then arises.
The four seasons are complete,
Cold and heat succeed one another.
Sunken and obscured, unseen—
Its body congeals in yin.

**Yan says:**
Above lies layered yin,
Below, no yang position—
This is the image of death.
The dead are cut off from creation,
Yin and yang part ways,
The four seasons shift.
For the ill, worry deepens;
Its body is dark yin—
The image of ghosts.
**He says:**
In old age, as one nears the end,
Hosts of ghosts return—
An omen of misfortune.

**Explanation says:**
Layered yin, profound and dark—
It reaches its utmost above.
Yang qi is faint and obstructed—
The human Dao comes to an end.
Sunken and obscured, unseen—
How dire it is!
This hexagram foretells death in illness,
And misfortune in all matters.

---

**Hexagram of Radiant Yang**
*Zero-One-Zero*
Heaven’s light descends,
Sun and moon shine forth.
All things act as clouds,
And all that have feet walk.

**Yan says:**
A single yang shines alone—
Thus, it is called "Heaven’s Light."
All things that live
Must rely on sun and moon.
Though this hexagram brings minor difficulties,
There is hope in the end.

**He says:**
In all matters, one should deliberate carefully—
Do not rely entirely on others for good fortune.

**Explanation says:**
Heaven’s light descends—
The human Dao prospers.
All that have feet walk—
No darkness remains.
This hexagram, with one yang at its center,
Is the image of sun and moon’s radiance,
On which all beings depend.
In seeking affairs, success may be hoped for, though delayed.

---

**Hexagram of Year’s Abundance**
*Zero-Two-Zero*
Heaven and earth open and connect,
All things flourish.
Affairs are now decided—
A great harvest in the year.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram resembles the one above,
With heaven and earth’s power of sowing and planting,
Leading to great abundance.
It portends minor good fortune.

**He says:**
In all matters, good fortune comes late—
Do not seek swift results.
Act with rectitude,
And all will follow suit.

**Explanation says:**
The human Dao approaches prosperity.
This hexagram, from one to two,
Shows gradual increase—
In seeking affairs, progress comes step by step.

---

**Hexagram of Human Affairs**
*Zero-Three-Zero*
Human affairs arise—
Auspicious, with no misfortune.
Those who stay gain fortune,
Those who travel will arrive.

**Yan says:**
Three yangs reside in the center—
The human Dao begins to flourish.
Though lacking support,
Great good fortune will ultimately come.

**He says:**
In all matters that arise,
All will be unimpeded.
Travelers will return as scheduled.

**Explanation says:**
Human affairs arise—
Yang stands at the center.
Auspicious, with no misfortune—
Great success in the end.
This hexagram, with three yangs emerging from earth,
Is the time of the *jianyin* month,
When human affairs begin.
Heaven and earth unite in harmony—
Auspicious, with no misfortune.

---

**Hexagram of Preserving the Self**
*Zero-Four-Zero*
Ghostly qi is not yet formed,
Perilous toxins have no shape.
Guard and tend to life,
And the household will be at peace.

**Yan says:**
The central position holds the human image—
Thus, ghostly qi is not yet formed.
Yet it occupies a weak yin position,
With no interaction.
One should guard and withdraw cautiously,
Acting in secret, not openly.
If assailed by ghostly perils,
Any action will fail—
No good fortune comes.

**He says:**
One should preserve the self
And remain tranquil.

**Explanation says:**
Ghostly qi is not yet formed—
There is no support.
Guard and tend to life—
Peaceful dwelling is fitting.
This hexagram, with yin in a yang position,
Has no firm foundation.
The diviner should be prudent,
Withdrawing and guarding the self in secret—
Then no fault will arise.

---

**Hexagram of Transformation and Nurturance**
*Zero-Zero-One*
Bright, bright is the high heaven,
Shining upon the earth below.
Transforming and nurturing all life,
Opening and unfolding doors.
All affairs become clear,
Mutually gazing upon one another.

**Yan says:**
Earth, paired with heaven,
Must receive its radiance,
Moistening all sprouts below,
Enabling them to grow.
**He says:**
In all matters, follow the heart’s intent,
Though progress may be slow—
This hexagram bears no fault.

**Explanation says:**
High heaven shines upon the earth—
To bring forth life.
Mutually gazing in darkness—
No thing fails to flourish.
This hexagram, with yang coming to dwell in earth’s position,
Is the image of high heaven’s illumination.
In affairs, there is initial success but no great achievement—
Yet no fault arises.

---

**Hexagram of Earth’s Benefit**
*Zero-Zero-Two*
Foundations are established, affairs settled,
Humans and things align in rectitude.
Drinking pure, eating sweet,
Each preserves its nature.

**Yan says:**
Heaven as one, earth as two—
Thus, the foundation is already laid.
Humans and things, following this,
Each rectify their natures—
Minor good fortune in all matters.

**He says:**
Success comes slightly late,
For the other has not yet grown—
An image of good fortune in all things.

**Explanation says:**
Foundations are established, affairs settled—
The Dao of earth is complete.
Drinking pure, eating sweet—
Each preserves its nature.
In seeking affairs with this hexagram,
There is good fortune from beginning to end.

---

**Hexagram of Establishing the Season**
*Zero-Zero-Three*
Affairs flourish, works arise,
Heroes lay foundations.
Sages and worthies save the world,
Laws and decrees attain principle.

**Yan says:**
Three yangs occupy the lower position—
The image of flourishing works and arising affairs.
To create foundations,
None but heroes can achieve success.
Thus, they clarify laws to save the world.

**He says:**
In all matters, there will be words from others
To assist in decision and action.

**Explanation says:**
Affairs flourish, works arise—
The Dao of yang is established.
Sages and worthies save the world—
Advancing to accomplish great deeds.
This hexagram, with three yangs in earth’s position,
Lays foundations and establishes enterprises.
Its vigor and strength suffice for action,
With none to obstruct it.

chunks.original_text: 占者大宜有为，百事俱吉。 送终课全阴卦　　○○四 养生送死，祭杞洁丰。 孝子策杖，衣服粗凶。 颜云：此卦阴数，万物之极也。 夫受气於天，生而为人，死而归土，故曰养生送死。 以有祭祀，明孝子之事，亲终也。 何云：此卦孝子之有亲，必当至孝，恐有丧也。 卜病弥凶，百事不利。 解曰：养生送死，人道尽矣。 体魄归地，就泯泯也。 此课困极之象，占事无所为而不凶。 阴漫课无象卦　　○○○ 阴漫无象，兆状未形。 动而有悔，退保其贞。 颜云：十二棋子皆覆，无字者阴漫之卦。 本自有形，而归无形，天地阴阳之理极矣。 是以灵棋起於一爻之文，而终於无象棋体。 既无文象，以成爻卦，故不在於一百二十四卦之内。 此卦未可兴作，故退保幽贞，以消大咎。 久病者不死，卒病者凶。 何云：不利所求，宜居家守志。 百事无忧，宜正官事。 无罪则立散，有事则难解。 战阵不利，所求不得。 此卦居宅平安，无得失之卦也。 解曰：太极未分，杳冥也。 阴阳混合，莫暗其形也。 退静处默，以保其贞也。 此课吉凶未分，不可作为，静默自守，则吉无咎矣。 占者得之，闻忧不忧，闻喜不喜，守怛无得失之卦也。 灵棋本章正经卷下竟 仆知命之后，从宦幽燕，值唐祚湮微。

**For the Querent: Greatly Fitting to Act**
All affairs are wholly auspicious.

**Funeral Hexagram: All Yin**
*Zero-Zero-Four*
Nurturing life, sending off the dead,
Sacrifices pure and abundant.
The filial son leans on his staff,
Clothing coarse, the omen dire.

**Yan says:**
This hexagram is of yin numbers—
The extreme of the ten thousand things.
Receiving qi from Heaven,
Born to become human, dying to return to earth,
Thus it is called nurturing life and sending off the dead.
Through sacrificial rites,
The affairs of the filial son are made clear—
The passing of kin.

**He says:**
This hexagram concerns the filial son with living parents,
Who must be utmost in devotion,
For there may be mourning ahead.
In divining illness, it is exceedingly inauspicious;
All affairs are unfavorable.

**Explanation says:**
Nurturing life, sending off the dead—
The human Dao is exhausted.
The bodily form returns to earth,
To merge with the indistinct.
This hexagram is the image of utter distress;
In divination, there is nothing it does not portend as dire.

**Formless Yin Hexagram**
*Zero-Zero-Zero*
Yin spreads formless,
The omen’s shape not yet formed.
Act and there will be regret;
Retreat to preserve integrity.

**Yan says:**
All twelve pieces are overturned—
The characterless hexagram of formless yin.
Originally possessing form,
Yet reverting to formlessness,
The principle of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, is exhausted.
Thus, the *Lingqi* begins with the lines of the first hexagram
And ends with the formless body of the pieces.
Since it lacks written lines or images
To constitute a hexagram,
It does not fall within the one hundred twenty-four hexagrams.
This hexagram is not fit for action;
Thus, retreat to preserve hidden integrity,
To dispel great misfortune.
For chronic illness, the patient will not die;
For sudden illness, the omen is dire.

**He says:**
Unfavorable for seeking;
Fitting to stay home and guard one’s resolve.
All affairs are without worry;
Fitting for official matters.
If innocent, the case will be swiftly dismissed;
If guilty, the matter will be difficult to resolve.
Unfavorable for battle;
Unattainable in seeking.
This hexagram brings peace to the household,
A sign without gain or loss.

**Explanation says:**
Before the Great Ultimate divided,
There was profound obscurity.
Yin and yang blended,
Their forms indistinct.
Retreat in stillness, abide in silence,
To preserve integrity.
This hexagram’s fortune is undetermined;
No action should be taken.
Abide in quietude and self-restraint,
Then good fortune will come without misfortune.
For the querent who obtains this,
Hearing sorrow, do not grieve;
Hearing joy, do not rejoice—
Guard steadfastness, a hexagram without gain or loss.

The *Lingqi Jing*

Sages and worthies save the world—

With none to obstruct it.

chunks.original_text: 时岁在辛丑三月中旬，契丹大下，围绕燕城。 原野之中，略无虚地，尽白壤而已。 士庶惊骇，寮属惶惑。 弱子幼妇，晨夕不保。 自是无所控告，遂焚香以灵棋。 经筮得三上二中二下卦，辞云：土地平安，无有艰难。 大宜种作，利用往还。 翌日，勾院博陵公郎中召饮，因议兹事。 博陵曰：某昨日亦得斯兆。 是时，契丹攻围转逼。 有僧同族，始以当家，因相慰问。 又虔祝而筮之，前卦复显。 至五月，救兵不至。 仆与同辈，在昌平繇令周居隐。 怀来繇令昊湘，都押衙赵宗古，同宿于守备之所，忧援兵来缓，因言是经。 遂众请虔祷而筮之，得二上一中，见卦体不全，合坐愕然贻叹，览其辞曰：以事托人，日望其意。 乃至于今，方获嘉喜。 事须淹留，终保其志。 颜曰：以其位孤微，不能自立，吉则终吉，但应迟尔。 至六月，危困愈甚。 仆又请筮之，众曰：休，休。 若得好卦，犹不敢伏。 如更凶恶，转加愁思。 畲自心口相谓曰：但自掷之，好即扬，凶则自谋脱命之计。 由是掷之，依前得土地平安无有艰难之卦。 至七月九日，门徒医术士郭彤云来相省慰，仆不在家，与诸子共话灵棋经之事，复恳祝之，掷而成卦，亦得土地平安之卦。 仆因启愿若兔斯难。 当手书十卷，传于好事者。
chunks.translated_text:
In the third month of the year *xinchou*, the Khitans launched a massive invasion, encircling the city of Yan. The open fields were filled without a single empty space, covered entirely in white earth. The gentry and common folk were struck with terror, while officials and subordinates were seized with confusion. The young and the weak, women and children, could not be secured even from morning to night. With no one to appeal to, I burned incense and consulted the *Lingqi Jing*. The divination yielded a hexagram of three *yang* above, two *yin* in the middle, and two *yin* below, with the following judgment: "The land is at peace, without hardship or difficulty. Most suitable for sowing and cultivation; advantageous for travel and return."

The next day, the Prefect of the Bureau of Merit, the Lord of Boling, summoned me to drink and discuss the matter. Boling said, "Yesterday, I too received this same omen." At that time, the Khitan siege grew increasingly pressing. A monk from my clan, who had just taken charge of the household, came to offer comfort. We again devoutly prayed and cast the lots, and the previous hexagram reappeared.

By the fifth month, no relief forces had arrived. I and my peers—Magistrate Zhou of Changping, Magistrate Wu of Huailai, and Chief Captain Zhao Zonggu—lodged at the garrison post. Anxious that the reinforcements were delayed, we spoke of the *Lingqi Jing*. At the group’s request, we devoutly prayed and cast the lots, obtaining a hexagram of two *yang* above and one *yin* in the middle. Seeing the hexagram’s form incomplete, the entire company was stunned and sighed in dismay. The judgment read: "Entrusting matters to others, one awaits their intent day by day. Only now is joyful news obtained. Affairs will require delay, but the aspiration will ultimately be preserved." Yan said: "Due to its solitary and humble position, it cannot stand alone. If auspicious, it will remain so in the end, though the outcome will be slow."

By the sixth month, the peril and distress had grown even more severe. I again requested to cast the lots, but the group said, "Enough, enough. Even if a favorable hexagram appears, we dare not trust it. If it turns out ill, our sorrow will only deepen." I silently said to myself: "Just cast them. If the result is good, we will rejoice; if ill, I will devise my own plan to escape." Thus, I cast the lots and once more obtained the hexagram of "the land is at peace, without hardship or difficulty."

On the ninth day of the seventh month, my disciple, the physician Guo Tong, came to visit and offer comfort. I was not at home, so he spoke with my sons about the *Lingqi Jing*. They earnestly prayed again and cast the lots, obtaining once more the hexagram of "the land is at peace." I then made a vow: if I were delivered from this calamity, I would hand-copy ten volumes of the text to transmit to those of like mind.

Before the Great Ultimate divided,
There was profound obscurity.
Yin and yang blended,
Their forms indistinct.
Retreat in stillness, abide in silence,
To preserve integrity.
This hexagram’s fortune is undetermined;
No action should be taken.
Abide in quietude and self-restraint,
Then good fortune will come without misfortune.
For the querent who obtains this,
Hearing sorrow, do not grieve;
Hearing joy, do not rejoice—
Guard steadfastness, a hexagram without gain or loss.

The *Lingqi Jing*

chunks.original_text: 是年八月二十四日，大兵解围。 乃知至诚感神，至诚感灵。 敬叔其事，附余十卷之后云。 党紫团山叟韩运序 此经之名，见於《唐书·经籍志》中，又《南史》载，南齐红谧，亦用以占休咎，所载经文，亦皆符同。 本朝杨文公《谈苑》，亦载此经，占验如神。 先父尝手抄，为家藏书。 拭为职吁胎时，当丧师之后，且敌人探入，被命促行。 因卜之，得安若泰山之卦，后果无他害。 凡占之卦，无不应者，此经其神哉。 熟复繇辞，必汉人为之，非三国已后之占书也。 大抵每占必切中事机，非若他术泛泛示人吉凶者比然。 其繇文凶多而吉少，与《易》之言曰吉凶悔吝生乎动相类。 一动之问，一吉而己，其凶悔吝居其三焉，岂非消长盈虚之理然欤。 今世之占书，《易》与《六壬》为验，可占常道，而义深奥。 难於央择，甚则取舍万端，推步不一。 孰若此经之明白洞达，以简易示人，探切着明者乎。 南轩张栻题。

On the twenty-fourth day of the eighth month of that year, the great army lifted its siege. Thus did I know that utmost sincerity moves the divine, and utmost sincerity moves the numinous. With reverence, I record this affair and append it to the end of my ten-volume transcription.

—Preface by Han Yun, the Purple-Gathered Mountain Recluse of the Dang Clan

The name of this scripture appears in the *Tangshu Jingji Zhi*, and the *Nanshi* further records that Hong Mi of the Southern Qi also used it to divine fortune and misfortune. The text it preserves matches this one. In our present dynasty, Yang Wengong’s *Tanyuan* likewise records this scripture, attesting to its divinations as spirit-like in accuracy. My late father once hand-copied it as a treasured family text.

When I was still in the womb, my father had just suffered the loss of his teacher, and enemy scouts had already infiltrated our lands. He was ordered to depart with haste. Casting the lots, he obtained the hexagram "secure as Mount Tai," and indeed, no harm came to him afterward. In every divination, the hexagrams proved unfailingly accurate—how numinous this scripture is!

Upon close study of its prognostic verses, one must conclude they were composed by a Han-dynasty hand, not by any diviner of the Three Kingdoms or later. In essence, each divination invariably strikes the mark of affairs, unlike other arts that vaguely foretell fortune or misfortune. Its verses lean more toward the ominous than the auspicious, akin to the *Yijing*’s principle that "fortune and misfortune, regret and humiliation arise from movement." In any single inquiry, only one outcome is favorable, while three are fraught with misfortune, regret, or humiliation—is this not the natural principle of waxing and waning, fullness and emptiness?

Among the divination texts of our age, the *Yijing* and *Liuren* are the most reliable for discerning the constant Dao, yet their meanings run deep and obscure, difficult to grasp. At worst, their interpretations branch into myriad possibilities, and their calculations diverge. How could they compare to this scripture, so clear and penetrating, revealing its judgments with simplicity and directness?

—Inscribed by Zhang Shi of Nanxuan
